TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence to a motion to require the tabling of the departmental report on the evaluation of tenders for the supply of computer consumables referred to during Question Time on 7 May 1991.

The urgency of this matter should be apparent. There could be few more serious charges concerning a Minister for Administrative Services than the suggestion of some improper involvement in a tendering process. In this instance, that is the apparent circumstance from reports in the press of an exchange of correspondence between Senator Bolkus and his Department.

That is an allegation that gives rise to immediate concern among all Australians and, in particular, requires action by this Parliament to determine whether that allegation, as apparent from the press reports, can be substantiated. The Minister, in turn, answers this charge by going on the television program, the 7.30 Report, and saying that his position has been vindicated by an apparent inquiry which questions the tendering process-something that does not seem to relate at all to the exchange of letters that occurred, which was really a requirement by the Minister that an unsuccessful tenderer be included in the list of successful tenderers.

The 7.30 Report, apparently having had this internal investigation leaked to it by the Minister, says that the Minister has provided an adequate answer to the charge, and other press reports include that as well. Not surprisingly, in Question Time yesterday Senator Parer asked the Minister to produce the document which is the basis of his answer to the allegations against him, and, to our amazement, he refused to do so. Therefore, we have a circumstance in which the Minister says that an internal investigation has found that his action was reasonable, that that internal investigation is made available to certain elements within the press, but it is not provided to the Parliament for assessment. That is an unsatisfactory situation, to say the very least.

The Minister cannot justify his actions by secret internal reports. If he says that he has an answer, he should be prepared to put the whole of that answer before the Parliament so that a proper and reason- able assessment can be made. In those circumstances of urgency, I seek the suspension of Standing Orders this morning in order that I can move the motion that that internal report be put before the Parliament, in turn, in order that a proper judgment can be made of its contents.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night when this debate was interrupted I was making the point that allowing these amendments to the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), which alters the Industrial Relations Commission, is, to use the good old comment, like playing with the deck chairs on the Titanic, because this set of amendments does not deal with the basic problems of industrial relations in Australia. No matter how much the Government fiddles at the sides with the arrangements of the Industrial Relations Commission, the fact is that the Commission structure, the whole approach that this Government adopts to industrial relations, is, in fact, causing job losses and holding back Australia's economic recovery.

SPEECH.PARA: Last night I was arguing that the extent to which it has had a direct impact on job losses can clearly be seen by looking at the statistics for one section of the community which does not have the opportunity to argue in front of the Industrial Relations Commission, that is, the young people of Australia. Last night I was making the point that job losses over the last 12 months have been concentrated on the under-20s, the young people of Australia. Even though they make up only about 5 per cent of the Australian work force, they have suffered almost 60 per cent of the job losses in Australia.

The majority of jobs lost in Australia over the last 12 months-jobs wiped out in this recession that the Treasurer, Mr Keating, said we had to have-has been concentrated in the under-20s. This clearly indicates that the methods adopted by the industrial relations club-the big union, big business, big government operation which is perpetuated in these amendments-work to the clear disadvantage of individual groups such as the under-20s. There is nothing in the industrial relations law that does anything to help. On the contrary, it massively hinders the young people coming into the work force searching for jobs.

One of the disasters we face is that when there is an economic downturn-a recession like the one Mr Keating says we had to have-the people in the firing line of that recession are the under-20s, as the statistics I have just outlined clearly slow. When something like 25.7 per cent of all jobs for the under-20s is being wiped out in one year throughout Australia, there is a real crisis.

The result of wiping out those jobs has not been effectively reflected in the unemployment statistics because, as I have noted in the past, there have been some governmental gimmicks to hide the true level of unemployment. One could describe these gimmicks as doctoring of the unemployment figures for the under-20s. Certainly, the recent unpublished official regional labour force statistics for March 1991 show that over the last 12 months 110,700 full time teenage jobs were lost in Australia. That compares with something like 82,500 adult jobs lost.

Even though 110,700 full time teenage jobs have been lost in Australia, total teenage employment has gone up by only 41,000. This leaves something like 70,000 young people disappearing from the unemployment statistics. When we add these disappearing people back into the figures, we see that the real unemployment rate among the under-20s looking for full time work in Australia is probably 36 per cent rather than the 25 per cent or one in four young people out of a job in the official figures. That is the worst ever recorded.

The number of jobs being wiped out is a far more accurate indicator of how the recession is hitting young Australians than the official unemployment statistics, which, while horrific, nonetheless, as I have demonstrated, massively understate the problem. This has emerged through a combination of the Government's $300m a year extension of Austudy to secondary school students to get them out of dole queues and back into school and a statistical gimmick which now excludes from the definition of `unemployed' anyone who works more than one hour a week for no pay-for example, on a family farm or doing job experience. This means that there is a huge level of hidden unemployment, the size of which is indicated by the massive job loss statistics.

It seems clear that the present system-which is tinkered with in these amendments-does nothing to give a fair go to young employees. Clearly, they are losing their jobs, are not being employed, and are bearing the brunt of the recession. It is not economic for employers in difficult economic situations to provide jobs to young people, particularly when the differential between young wages and adult wages-in other words, between relatively inexperienced people's wages and experienced people's wages-has been reduced as a result of continual decisions by the Industrial Relations Commission and deals struck between big government, big unions and big business, rubber-stamped in many instances in the past by the Commission. When the Industrial Relations Commission refuses to rubber-stamp what the Government wants and determines, it is subject to pretty violent public attack by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Ministers of this Government.

It is interesting to note that the impact of State governments on the economies of the various States has a clear impact on the level of youth unemployment and the extent to which young people are being priced out of jobs in the various States. Clearly, the best way to resolve this would be to enable people to come to employment agreements which hopefully would bear a greater relationship to productivity than to formal things such as across the board pay rises irrespective of whether an industry or business can afford it.

If we had pay rates by productivity, people who are relatively inexperienced, relatively untrained, and whose productivity was clearly lower than more experienced people-in other words, young people of Australia-would probably claim lower pay rates but many more of them would be in jobs. In the rigid structure of the Industrial Relations Commission and the Government's approach to industrial relations generally, there is no capacity for young people to have lower productivity-I am not criticising lower productivity; it is a function of experience-reflected in lower relative wages. If we had the choice of either employing many more young people or having the present wage structure, surely all Australians would prefer to see a change in the wage structure.

It has become intolerable in places such as Melbourne where the official figures show that there has been a 35 per cent job loss for people under 20 years of age. That has led to an official unemployment rate of about 27.1 per cent. Worse than one in four Melbourne people are out of work, according to official statistics. When we look at the number of jobs that have been wiped out and the enormous gap between the number of jobs wiped out and the increase in unemployment, we find that the real unemployment rate of young people in Melbourne is about 45 per cent. This 35 per cent job loss for the under-20s in Melbourne has chopped the number of teenagers in full time work from 70,600 to only 45,800. That is a loss of 24,800 jobs. Melbourne is the capital city in Australia with the highest youth unemployment, with 33,100 young Melburnians still looking for full time or part time work.

The collapse of the Melbourne job market means that more than half of the 96,400 people in Melbourne aged between 15 years and 19 years with jobs have been able to get only part time work. Even that is getting harder to find as 6,700 part time jobs have also disappeared over the past year-lifting the total job losses in Melbourne in the last 12 months to 31,400. It is extraordinary that this loss of 24,800 full time jobs has resulted in only a 5,800 job rise in the official under-20s unemployment figure for Melbourne, causing 19,000 jobs for young people to disappear.

As we did with the Australian figures, when we add back these disappearers into the figures, the real full time unemployment rate in Melbourne for 15- to 19-year-olds is about 45 per cent-a record. If we compare that with the Sydney situation-I mention in passing that Sydney is in the only State with a Liberal Government-the official unemployment rate for young people is 18.1 per cent as against 21.7 per cent in Melbourne. When we add back the relatively few jobs which disappear from the statistics in Sydney, there is a real unemployment rate for the under-20s in Sydney of about 29 per cent, which is still horrific, compared with Melbourne's 45 per cent. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I have been caught a bit short. Senator Baume was rising to make his final point and I was listening to the tone of his voice as well as the content of his contribution. We have before us this morning the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, and that rather arcane description of the Bill hides the fact that this is not a Bill which deals in a full-blooded, wholehearted way with major industrial relations amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill serves to improve important functions in industrial relations in Australia. While I would shrink from saying that this is a tinkering piece of legislation-it is not; it is much more than that-it is, as I have said, not a substantial recasting of any of the industrial relations institutions or a substantial review of the operation of industrial relations in this country.

There are four elements embraced by this Bill, known in parliamentary parlance as an omnibus Bill. These are to enact the recommendations of the Gleeson inquiry into the operation and functioning of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission; to deal with modifications to section 202 of the Industrial Relations Act-that section dealing with registration of unions and in this case, where unions are of a federal registration, dealing with amalgamations or sorting out affairs with unions of a State registration-to deal with amendments to the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal; and, importantly, to deal with changes to the Trade Union Training Authority Act-changes which reflect an element of restructuring in the Act.

I thank all honourable senators for their contributions to this debate. I certainly wish to identify more with the contribution made by Senator Paul McLean, the industrial relations spokesperson for the Australian Democrats. While it is true that he certainly did not endorse the Government's position fully-and as foreshadowed, I understand it is his intention to move amendments in the committee stage-he nonetheless generally, on behalf of his Party, has indicated that the core direction of these amendments is acceptable and that they will not be opposed outright as the Opposition has indicated it will oppose them in this debate.

I turn now to the comments by the Opposition. Firstly, much of what has been said in this debate has not been about the specific amendments proposed. As is not unusual in matters of industrial relations, this Bill has provided an opportunity for honourable senators to make remarks that range wide from the actual proposed amendments and go to the broad subject of the industrial relations debate in the community.

To the extent that that has gone on, many of the speeches have not been specifically relevant to the issues under consideration by the Senate, but that is not an uncommon feature of second reading debates. However, some of the comments on the generality of things cannot pass unanswered by the Government, lest it be assumed by anyone that lack of a comment in reply is taken as any form of acceptance of what has been said.

We heard a speech from Senator Baume dealing, in essence, with youth unemployment. The invitation, explicit at various points in that speech, is that we are meant to assume that youth unemployment in this country is high because of the nature of industrial relations regulation. That is an extraordinary premise. It is not a premise widely supported outside the conservative parties in this country and it is not a premise supported by major employer institutions-to name one group-unions and indeed this Government, which have a close working knowledge of what in fact are the provisions of the Act and the flexibilities provided in the Act and which, by a decision of the Commission, set a precedent to deal with issues of hardship in industry, if those conditions are genuine and if there is a real need to review minimum standards because of them.

The most celebrated example of what I refer to, in recent memory, concerns SPC Ltd. This company had suffered considerable losses because, as the shareholders of that company recognised, its previous management had engaged in all the speculative whimsy of the stock market in the period leading up to the crash in 1987 and had seen this small regional canning company as some sort of incarnation of the Alan Bond or Robert Holmes a Court type of concept of industrial takeover and share trading, and had embarked ambitiously on that course of action for itself, and had run the company into debt.

The shareholders cast out that management and appointed a new management. That new management coming in faced a very difficult balance sheet. It had discussions with the employees about a rescue package and took that rescue package to the Industrial Relations Commission and, with the assistance of the Commission, finally came to a conclusion to which the unions, the workers and the management all happily agreed. That did not, as the Opposition or indeed as some pundits and writers in the press would have it, and as may unfortunately be the popular legend at the moment, result in any significant change to the award structure at all.

The only condition in the award that was forgone was that, instead of paying wages weekly in a wage packet handed to workers, wages would be paid by electronic funds transfer into the bank accounts of workers. That was the only award change that was made. However, significant savings were made because over-award payments were forgone, put back and rearranged and, without the awards being varied, with the assistance of the Commission that company is now fighting its way back into the black out of a very doubtful balance sheet brought on by the previous management of the company, not by the workers or their capacity to produce product out of that company. I appreciate that that may not, in all of the debate that has been generated, be well understood as a true statement. However, whether it is well understood or not, it is my obligation to tell the truth and that is the truth.

The popular fiction may be, as Senator Baume would have it, that because there are not sufficient flexibilities in the system, all of these troubles flow. The truth is that there are sufficient flexibilities. I have given an example of a celebrated one, and it is an example of how changes can be related to the specific circumstances of a company.

The important element that this Government identifies is that there must be an authority which says, `These outcomes are fair' so that the rule of the jungle does not apply-that when there is unemployment, employers can threaten workers with dismissal if they do not agree to the conditions of employment or the remuneration for work imposed by the employers and say, `If you do not like it, get out. You will take what we can give you, and it will not be a living wage. That is your problem, not ours'.

That type of system, which applied last century, would have applied this century had there not been an umpire to say what is fair. The refereeing of those outcomes is important. So what Senator Baume is talking about is a return to the removal of that type of check and balance and allowing the market to determine wages without reference to fairness, and that means that the bargaining power of the parties becomes the central determinant.

With high unemployment, the bargaining power of employers to force down wages is strong. With the recovery of the Australian economy in prospect for the second half of this year and employment picking up further because of that, bargaining power will shift from where it is now, with employers, to unions. If the law of the jungle is applied now, and employers wish to maximise their bargaining power and exploit the market, they can expect that when the recovery comes along unions, in recognition of what employers have done, will emulate them, exploit the market and push up wages accordingly. That is the law of the jungle: if one has a market position, one exploits it to one's own advantage.

The role of the Commission, underpinned by the accord in our period of government, is to provide some sanity to that situation, to provide respect and dignity for workers and to provide an opportunity for wages to be determined against some rational criteria. As I say, the flexibilities are there where there are specific hardship cases and so on. In summary on this point, I do not accept the allegation that the industrial relations institutions of this country, and the way in which they operate, are directly responsible in any way for the level of unemployment, or youth unemployment, as the Opposition has been propounding.

I will go on and answer a couple of questions that were raised in the debate. It seems to me that no substantial debate was entered into on the changes to the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal. Therefore, there is nothing for me to say on that. No real debate was entered into on the changes to section 202 of the Act although, in terms of industrial relations law, it is a quite important amendment. It will have the effect of rationalising the union structure in this country, given the differences between Federal and State jurisdictions, quite importantly. By doing that, it will minimise the potential for demarcation disputes, which is something that all of us lament the incidence of and wish to see diminished. I must say that the incidence of demarcation disputes has fallen markedly in recent years. The amendments to section 202 will be quite important and significant in the industrial relations landscape.

The amendments to the Trade Union Training Authority Act, as I have said, restructure the Authority to guarantee that it performs its tasks with greater efficiency. It also guarantees that the investment that there is in trade union training to provide minimum skills at negotiation and representation for workers in the workplace who do not have access to management training schemes is discharged properly. I think these are commendable amendments and I have commended them to the Senate.

Most of the debate was about the Gleeson report. The debate, if I might characterise it, fell into two categories. The first was that the legislation arose at the behest of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and that the Government is nothing more than-if I might characterise it in the terms that the Opposition would use, not us-the ACTU's poodle, doing its bidding.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's the truth.
—Have I captured, in essence, what the honourable senator was saying?
—One of the main points.

—I have. I thank the honourable senator. I want to demolish it and I am glad that Senator Chapman has reaffirmed it. That is the concept and I will deal with its demolition in a second. The second element of the Opposition's contribution was that somehow or other these amendments are a stalking-horse for the Government's evil intent to introduce a labour court into this country, which is not something that the community wants. Those are the two issues.

SPEECH.PARA: On the first issue, the Gleeson inquiry was conducted by three people, the first being the person after whom the inquiry was named, the chairman of the group, Mr Gerry Gleeson, a former head of the Premier's Department in New South Wales and a distinguished public servant in this country, honoured by an Order of Australia. No-one has criticised Mr Gleeson in terms of his public standing and his competence for this position.

One of the other members of the inquiry was His Honour Mr Justice Olsson, a judge of the Supreme Court of South Australia and a former President-appointed, as I recall, by a Liberal government-of the South Australian Industrial Relations Commission, as it now is. He is a distinguished industrial relations authority as well as a judge of significant standing in the South Australian court. No-one has criticised Mr Justice Olsson as being an unfit person to make the judgments that have been delivered in this report.

The third member of the inquiry team was Professor Alan Fels, the Chairman of the Prices Surveillance Authority and a professor of economics at Monash University in Victoria. No-one criticises his economic expertise or his knowledge of these institutions. It is from these three people, after investigation involving submissions from the Government, the Confederation of Australian Industry, the ACTU and the Commission itself, that this report emanates and it is in recognition of their findings that the Government now moves to legislate. The characterisation of that process as a process in which a government is answering the bidding of the ACTU is within the capacity only of someone who wishes to besmirch or besmear the process and to try to achieve a political point rather than recognise in fact what has been the process.

The findings of this inquiry recommend that the Commission be restructured to recognise that this Government has taken a critical and vital initiative in industrial relations. We have succeeded now in doing something that has defied Commonwealth governments since Federation. We at last have an agreement between the Commonwealth and the six States of Australia, all of which maintain their own separate and distinct industrial jurisdictions. So there are in this country seven arbitration tribunals.

We have achieved an agreement between them to cross-appoint the members of their tribunals to our tribunals and, if you like, blend the six State tribunals with a Commonwealth tribunal in a network which makes some national sense of the industrial relations structure and enables matters coming up in one jurisdiction to be heard by the same person crossing into the next jurisdiction and back. It simply streamlines the process. It is not the ideal outcome but it is certainly a very innovative and intelligent application of what is possible in a country which is made up of a federation of States with an essentially weak national government but with a Constitution that provides that government with the power to make laws on industrial relations for disputes going beyond one State.

The restructuring of the Commission arises in part because we have appointed the heads of State tribunals to our Federal bench. The recommendation to create the position of a senior deputy president is partly in recognition of that and partly in recognition that some members of the Federal bench hold the honorific of judges, are legally qualified people who specialise in industrial law and, it might be considered, ought to be of the character and standing for appointment to a court dealing with industrial matters, in whatever form.

This is not a stalking-horse for a labour court, but it may turn out that a labour court is agreed to. Let me make the distinction that this is an amendment that ought to be made because of the changes we are bringing about in rationalising industrial jurisdiction in this country. But it may turn out to be convenient if there is agreement between the industrial relations partners-employers, unions and the Government-about a labour court. We have not sought to impose a labour court on people or to have a perfect view of the ideal structure of such a court, if there were to be one.

Let us look at what we have done. We started notifying all the parties in April of last year that we were reviewing the Act. In January of last year we sat down with the ACTU and the Confederation of Australian Industry and, in view of what the parties to the Act had said, started a process of discussion. We published discussion papers looking at various options. We are now in the midst of canvassing those options and considering what the outcome should be. We are seeking a consensus of parties who are normally divided over industrial relations matters as to what the right structure of the law is, so that when the law is enacted there is a commitment to it and a preparedness to work through it. That is the process we are engaged in.

This is not Viner legislation from the Fraser years in which a government sitting in the perfect isolation of Canberra imposes on the industrial relations parties its view of what it wants. This is a government working with the major parties to bring about a central commitment, cooperation and a structure of law that reflects their interests. It is interesting, if not indeed passing strange, to see that earlier this year-a month or six weeks ago-when the shadow spokesperson for industrial relations, the former Treasurer in the Fraser government, Mr Howard, attacked us over the prospect of a labour court, the Confederation of Australian Industry, a group from which the Opposition would expect to gain succour in industrial matters, said that it supported the prospect and disagreed with Mr Howard.

Let us get this matter into context. If there is a labour court-a matter yet to be decided because we are still insisting on rational discussion and the discovery of a consensus-then it will be there because the parties seek it and not because of preconceived views of the Opposition about what it might be. On the public record there is now a clear disagreement between the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Opposition. This raises the question, if the Opposition is not speaking for employers in this country, not speaking for the unions and not speaking for governments, of who the hell it is speaking for other than its own warped version of ideology.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's not sectional interests we're concerned with but the whole country.
—There is no support for its theory.
—It's the nation's interests; you won't acknowledge that. Why don't you acknowledge it?
—Good, honest Australian families.

—In view of the interjections, let me just go one step further because this is an interesting question in the industrial relations debate. We had Bills before the New South Wales Parliament that arose from an inquiry into industrial relations in New South Wales by Professor John Niland. While it is true that the Greiner Government did not pick up all of the Niland recommendations-it modified those recommendations-nonetheless, the core of the Niland recommendations is to move the Australian industrial relations system into a collective bargaining structure rather than an arbitration structure, along the lines that apply in the United States.

SPEECH.PARA: That system involves a recognition that unions and employers negotiate at company level. It also involves a recognition of a right for employers to lock out workers in those negotiations and a right of unions to go on strike in those negotiations-a right on both sides. That is based on the American system. I think it is wrong in terms of its application to Australia because it is alien to our custom and practice in this country. But those, in essence, were the Niland findings: a right to strike and a right to lock out.

When the subject of a right to strike was being canvassed publicly some months ago, the spokesperson for the Opposition, Mr Howard, condemned it. Therefore, he is further to the right of the New South Wales Government than the Niland recommendations suggest, which I think, by the way, is unacceptable in industrial conduct in Australia and ought not be enacted here. I make the point that the Opposition is to the right of even the Greiner Government in this debate and seemingly wishes to go down the road of the New Zealand National Party Government. I conclude my remarks and commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: EVALUATION OF TENDERS FOR COMPUTER CONSUMABLES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That there be laid on the table of the Senate, at or before 12.45 p.m. today, a copy of the departmental report on the evaluation of tenders for the supply of computer consumables referred to at Question Time on 7 May 1991.

I outlined this morning in the debate on the suspension of the Standing Orders the basis of the requirement of the Opposition that this document be tabled in the Senate. Let me put the matter in more explicit terms by specifically referring to what seems to be an exchange of correspondence between the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, and his Department as referred to in some detail in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 19 April. It is really this correspondence that raises the very major concerns that I mentioned this morning.

The matter relates to a tender for computer consumables which had been let by the Department of Administrative Services. It seems that the process of tendering had been concluded; one of the unsuccessful tenderers apparently made representations to the Minister; and the Minister then took action, demanding that this unsuccessful party be included in the list of successful tenderers, although the process had closed.

Specifically, I refer to an apparent letter from Senator Bolkus. When I say `apparent', I mean apparent to the extent that I have seen press reports. The contents of this exchange have not been refuted by the Minister in Estimates Committee D or in debate in this chamber since. In that letter of 4 March, Senator Bolkus wrote to his Department:

Following representations from Nashua and the offer of new . . . price list, it would seem that Nashua have unfortunately hurt their own case by not submitting their best price at the time of the tender.

That is astonishing in itself because it seems that Nashua acknowledged that the process had closed, but-as we heard yesterday-had gone through an intermediary to the Minister and indicated that it could have submitted a lower price and would now like the opportunity to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wouldn't everyone!
—So would everyone else!

—That is a point that is subsequently raised by the Department in response to that. If we are going to reopen the tenders to benefit one, what about others? What is the point of the first tender process if we are not going to make decisions on the basis of it? Continuing with Senator Bolkus's letter, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It concerns me that an established and satisfactory supplier to the Government can be put off the contract without the department wanting to satisfy itself that it has not unfairly treated the company.

Indeed we should be making every effort to satisfy ourselves that Australian suppliers have put forward their best offer. My view is that we should be actively seeking out competitive Australian suppliers to put on the common use contracts and elsewhere, in line with the Purchase Australia Campaign.
Here comes the incredible statement from Senator Bolkus to his Department after tenders have closed; the tender has been let:

I direct that you reconsider Nashua's bid with a view to putting Nashua on the contract, subject to their new prices meeting the criteria used in the initial assessment of the bids. Please advise Nashua immediately of the decision in writing . . .

Tenders have closed; the tender has been let; but one of the unsuccessful tenderers says to the Minister, `We want a second go, offering lower prices.' The Minister then writes to his Department saying that Nashua apparently did not put forward its lowest price and, therefore, it has unfortunately harmed itself in the tender process. He then directs that the Department now reconsider Nashua's bid with a view to putting it on the contract and, further more, that it write to Nashua immediately, advising it of this decision.

On the face of that, that is a blatant interference by the Minister for Administrative Services with the tendering process and the basis of very serious allegations. It is those allegations that require an answer. What was the response of the Department to that letter from the Minister, directing it to take this course of action? We understand that Mr S. J. Palywoda wrote back to the Minister in these terms:
. . . the requirements of the Finance Regulations and Directions were complied with, as were the Commonwealth's Procurement Guidelines.
He said:

We have reconsidered Nashua's bid but believe it cannot be accepted as to do so would totally compromise the tender process and place Nashua at an unfair advantage . . . we do not consider that cancelling the contract and calling new tenders is appropriate because there is no evidence to suggest that the tender or the evaluation was in any way flawed.

The Department has said that there was no flaw in the process. There was therefore no reason to cancel the tenders. Nashua is a very experienced tenderer. I think the Minister mentioned yesterday that it has been successful on previous occasions. It understands the tender documents and understands the basis on which it needs to put forward its best price in the first instance. It did not do so. It therefore was unsuccessful, and the Department could see no basis on which it could properly reopen the tender.

On the question of Australian suppliers, which is a point that Senator Bolkus has tried to raise, the Department advised the Minister that, of the two Australian bidders, one had been successful. Quite correctly, it said that the policy did not extend to discriminating against foreign suppliers. In effect, what the Department said was that it properly took into account the guidelines, including those which related to Australian suppliers, but it could not give benefit to Australian suppliers over a foreign bidder if the price did not warrant that. As the Department officer said, giving preference to Australian suppliers did not extend to `discriminating against foreign suppliers'. On the face of the documents that we have before us, the Department has refuted the Minister's claim and has rejected his requirement that Nashua's bid be given the benefit of hindsight and that Nashua be able to revise its prices accordingly.

What has been the Minister's answer to this very serious allegation? Regrettably, to find his answer to this charge we have to turn to the television program, the 7.30 Report, or to an article that appeared in the Canberra Times on 7 May, written by Tony Wright. It seems that the Minister's answer to the charge of improper interference was that the tender process was flawed, that subsequent to his intervention-which, on the face of it, was improper intervention-there was a review of the tender process and that it was found that that process could be done better. I presume that Paul Lyneham of the 7.30 Report had this internal inquiry report before him.

TALK.START.PARA: —You presume?
—I just said that.
—Why do you presume?

—Why not just listen? I presume that he had that internal inquiry report before him because I do not believe that he would make conclusions on the basis of the Minister's simply saying that there was an undisclosed internal report that vindicated his position. My conclusion is supported by the fact that the article by Tony Wright in the Canberra Times quoted part of the internal report, and I cannot see that it would be leaked to the Canberra Times and not to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, which principally had to run the story that the Minister had been vindicated.

SPEECH.PARA: There is an argument as to whether this question of revisiting and improving the tender process is in fact an answer to the charge in any event. I have no doubt that all tender processes can be improved. If we look to the Minister's letter to the Department, we find that he said nothing about a need to improve the tender process. I have quoted what he said. He said nothing at all about that. On the face of it, that was an afterthought to try to justify an improper intervention by the Minister at the time. But that is a debate that we will have another day.

All we are seeking in this debate is for the Minister not to be permitted to justify his position on the basis of some secret internal document. If that is to be his defence, he should put down his defence in the chamber, and not do as he did yesterday when he answered Senator Parer by saying, `I have been vindicated by an internal report; I am not going to put it before the Senate because it is commercial-in-confidence; but I will quote selective parts from it which prove my defence'. That is an improper way of attempting to defend the charge that is brought before him by anyone who looks at his original letter to the Department, which, as I said, on the face of it is blatant interference in a tender process after the tender has been let.

So we have brought this matter before the Senate this morning to seek of the Senate a resolution that it require the Minister to table that internal document. I would not have been surprised if, in answer to the question yesterday, Senator Bolkus had said that there are aspects in this internal document that may be commercial-in-confidence or may cause some embarrassment to a party. I wonder about it, because what we are talking about is a process. Apparently the Department revisited the tender process, not this particular tender or the application of the tender.

Nevertheless, if the Minister had come back and said, `The Department has put the names of some unsuccessful parties in it' or `There is some reason why, in the interests of third parties, I would feel uncomfortable about putting it before the Senate and I wish to speak to Senator Parer and to Senator Powell, as the Leader of the Australian Democrats, to see whether it can be agreed that the names be excised from that document before I table it', we would have understood that. But he did not do that. What he did yesterday was come into this place and say, `I will not let you have it but I will quote from it those parts which I say benefit my case'.

After the debate started this morning and during the intervention of other business, I understand that the Minister was out in the corridor, not wanting to come in to answer the case in the first instance-he was skulking in the corridor, not prepared to come in and answer. In the meantime, he has had the benefit of Senator Ray and his advisers and he is now in the chamber. He has also had the benefit of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who has now written to the Opposition and said that he, the Prime Minister, is prepared to intervene and, as I interpret this letter, require Senator Bolkus to make available the letter to Dr Hewson and the appropriate shadow Minister-I am sorry to say to Senator Powell that there is no mention of the Australian Democrats- understanding that they would respect commercial-in-confidence; that a departmental officer could explain to them what the document would be; and so the matter would end.

We regard that as an unsatisfactory response, firstly because although we have an interest in this matter, so do other parties in the Parliament and so does the public. It is not simply for the Minister to say, `This is commercial-in-confidence and therefore I am not going to table it'. What happens if we accept this invitation, look at the document and are of the opinion that nothing is commercial-in-confidence in the document? In those circumstances, we do not see that it is an adequate response to our demand that this document be tabled before the Australian people.

If the Minister stands up today and says, as he should have said yesterday, `There is some aspect that causes embarrassment to third parties that we would like to talk to you about', obviously, as sensible people and not wanting to harm third parties, we would speak to the Minister about that. But he has not ever said that.

So on that basis, we put the case today that the Parliament is entitled to have this document before it in order to judge properly the defence that Senator Bolkus has sought through the media to raise in defence of his clearly, on the face of it, improper intervention in this tender process. Do not tell me that the Prime Minister has not given him a copy of the letter.

I have noted Senator Robert Ray's comments subsequent to Senator Parer notifying me of correspondence between the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Dr Hewson. Obviously, having had a claim by the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) of commercial confidentiality of certain documents, that subsequent correspondence is significant. Senator Hill has made the point that there may be aspects of the relevant documents which are commercial-in-confidence and that other aspects may not be. As has already been pointed out under other processes, such documents with deletions are often made publicly available.

SPEECH.PARA: In this instance it is important that the relevant people involved have access to those documents and should be able to make judgments on those matters. There has been a lot of the flurry on this issue, which has largely been played out in the media. I do not want to get into questions about whether people have had documents, have had bits read over the telephone, have seen parts of them or whatever. I certainly would not stand here and mount an argument in a situation such as this based on a handful of press clippings or a television program. One would want much more detail and evidence than that.

A couple of points are worth making. One is that the original leaks on this issue to the Opposition came from the Department of Administrative Services. Also, there have been a number of conflicting responses from the Department. We should bear in mind that the Department ranges from those senior officers who made an eventual decision, which has been made public, to support the Minister's action, down to other officers in the tendering process who had obviously made different decisions earlier. When we talk about the Department, we are not talking about just one or two people. The fact that, at different times, different points of view and different opinions have been put simply reflects the fact that they are coming from different sources within the Department. Ultimately, in our process here, it comes down to what the Minister decides. In essence, that is what the Opposition has taken up.

I welcome the opportunity to see the documents, as the offer has been made. At this stage it is probably sensible for this chamber to adjourn consideration of Senator Hill's motion so that those documents can be viewed by the people to whom that offer has been made-Dr Hewson, no doubt Senator Parer as the spokesperson, and me. Therefore, I foreshadow that, at the conclusion of the debate, I will seek leave to move that consideration of this motion be adjourned. I do not want to prohibit the opportunity for others to speak in the debate. I will therefore move as an amendment to the motion that the debate be adjourned to a later hour this day. I do not want to put a time on it, as I am on my feet and do not have the information about the availability of Dr Hewson and Senator Parer and whether they are able to read them by a certain hour. At the conclusion of the debate, I will be moving an amendment to the motion. A claim of this kind having been made by the Minister, it is important that it be taken seriously by the responsible people. I certainly accept the offer to look at the documentation. I will then consider the question before the chamber or the possibility of any other action which might seem to us to be more appropriate in the circumstances.
