SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning we are debating whether the Government will provide the Parliament with some documents that the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) says justify his actions, those actions being an interference in the tender process. It is a document that we are not allowed to see. The Minister claims that that is on the basis of commercial-in-confidence. I will come to that matter later.

SPEECH.PARA: This morning I want to deal with six points raised by Senator Robert Ray and three raised by Senator Bolkus that go to this argument. The first relates to interjections by Senator Ray to some of my colleagues in the National Party of Australia and, certainly, to my colleague Senator Macdonald about the tendering processes in Queensland, which interjections sought to associate those honourable senators with what has happened in the past in Queensland.

We all know that the best form of defence is attack, but I think it is a pretty low level attack and one which does not offer any substance in this argument. For example, because I know by Brian Burke's own admission that he has taken $18,000 worth of stamps that are Australian Labor Party stamps and has mixed them in with those in his own collection, I do not suggest for one minute that Senators Giles, Cook, Beahan, McKiernan and Walsh are guilty of the same crime. Because Brian Burke had Brenda Brush collecting hundreds of thousands in dollars and carting that money around Perth in a bag or a suitcase, I do not say that Senators Giles, Cook, Beahan and McKiernan do the same thing. It is a preposterous allegation to be making. It is absolutely preposterous to suggest that because somewhere there is a defalcation in a process everybody else of that political persuasion should be judged accordingly.

If that is the way that Senator Robert Ray wants to play it, that is fine. I do not think that is what he really wants. I think that was just a simple cheap debating point. If there is any impropriety on this side of the chamber, in the Australian Democrats or on the other side of the chamber, let us talk about that impropriety as it relates to this chamber and this Parliament.

It gives this chamber no credit to simply get into a slanging match about what somebody's colleague in another State has done. Having regard to what has been going on in Western Australia, I would have thought that the whole of the other side of the chamber-in particular the Western Australians-would not want to hear an allegation that they mix up their funds, that they know which is their private money and which belongs to the Labor Party. It would be outrageous to make an allegation that they were collecting stamps and ferreting them home. We do see anyone on this side of the chamber making that sort of cheap debating remark. It is not one that befits someone such as Senator Robert Ray, who normally makes a more sensible contribution than that.

A subsidiary point is the allegation of both Senator Robert Ray and Senator Bolkus about the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill, when they said, `I haven't seen you come in here on some tough and difficult issue'. I remind them of several occasions on which Senator Hill has made difficult decisions, where he has chosen, after much consideration, to part company with the rest of his colleagues. That is never an easy decision and is one which Senator Bolkus has never ever made. Senator Bolkus just goes along with the group line. I well know what happens to Labor Party people when they disagree: look at what happened to Senator George Georges.

I remind Senator Bolkus of those occasions. Senator Bolkus might raise them as soft issues. As I recall, one of them was a tax matter, which I do not regard as being a soft issue. If one makes the allegation that someone is weak and he is weak, that is fair enough; if he is not weak, the debate is only cheapened by making the allegation.

The second point that Senator Robert Ray made was that Senator Bolkus was entitled to defend himself on the 7.30 Report on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), that he was entitled to do so because Dr Hewson raised the matter, and, because Dr Hewson raised the matter, ipso facto, everything else was okay. That is just manifestly ludicrous. The fact that someone raises an allegation does not entitle that person to go tittle-tattling off to the press, letting it see bits of documents that the Government will not put before Parliament and using bits and pieces to justify the claim. It is absolutely outrageous to suggest that, just because an allegation is made, the manner in which the allegation is answered should not be open to question. That is what we are doing today: we are questioning the manner in which these allegations have been answered.

We are saying that it is not good enough to go off to the ABC and give it, in whatever form it was given, bits and pieces of a document that the Government will not let the Parliament see. That is the whole focus of the debate. The allegations have been raised. We are not happy with the way in which they have been answered. We do not believe that a secret document does that. Consequently, the point made by Senator Ray fails.

Senator Ray also said that the ABC was not given the document. I noticed that he avoided making any remarks as to how Mr Lyneham, and the other reporter from the Canberra Times, got his information. The Government has been strangely silent on this. Is it suggesting that some junior official in the Department of Administrative Services has leaked this material in defence of his Minister? Why did Senator Bolkus not tell us what information he was prepared to give to Paul Lyneham and if he was prepared to let Paul Lyneham see the full contents of this report?

It is just not good enough to come in here and say in a very technical sense, `Well, no, these documents have not been given to the ABC', without telling us how it is that the ABC and the Canberra Times know more about these documents at this stage than the Parliament does. That is just an inadequate defence to offer.

The third point, namely, that the ABC has not been given these documents, raises the fourth point in Senator Ray's comments. The Minister under question at the moment, Senator Bolkus, proposes to ban political advertising on the electronic media. He says that we should all be satisfied with that, that members of the public should be satisfied with that, because through the electronic media they will find out what is going on in politics. They will be able to find out what Labor Party policies are, what Liberal Party policies are, what Democrat policies are, because the electronic media will tell them. The electronic media will tell them the truth.

Yet we are being asked to believe that the 7.30 Report ran a program in defence of a Minister without having access to the entire document on which the Minister seeks to rely. I think that that is a pretty solid damnation of the ABC and its practices. The Government is saying that it can just go to the ABC and say-nudge, nudge, wink, wink-`We cannot show you the whole thing. Here are the good bits. Run a program in favour of us'. I think that is what it is saying; it is saying that the ABC has not been given these documents. Senator Bolkus is saying that it has not been given the documents, but it has managed to gets bits of them. Somehow, you and I, Mr Deputy President, and members of the public are meant to believe that the ABC had full knowledge of what was in those documents without being given them.

The Minister comes here on another occasion and says, `But you can rely on the electronic media to tell you the truth'. Those propositions do not sit happily together. Either the ABC has been given or shown these documents, or it has run a program without having full access to them. That says something about its own competence. It certainly says something about the propriety of the Minister's plan to ban political ads on the electronic media.

The fifth point I raise is the offer to Dr Hewson and Senator Parer to look at these documents so that they will appreciate the meaning of `market-in-confidence'. This is yet another example of a typical attitude by the Labor Party that what government and the Parliament are all about is the Executive. In other words, if the Minister and the Prime Minister agree that something is the case and if the equivalent shadow Minister and the Leader of the Opposition agree that it is the case, then you, Mr Deputy President, and I should be quite happy with it. So Senator Powell need not bother getting elected; the Democrats need not bother coming. If this is just an Executive-to-shadow Executive bunfight and the backbenchers, the independents and the small parties are just here to go along with whatever the Prime Minister and Senator Bolkus choose to say, in agreement with Dr Hewson and Senator Parer, then the rest of us may as well pack up and go home. If that is the case, this whole institution is a gross waste of taxpayers' money.

I for one never have and never will totally give the right to speak on my behalf to my Leader. The day that happens is the day I should give up my job. If I went to South Australians and said, `Elect me; I will go along with whatever the leader of the day says', I would not get elected and nor should I. That is the fundamental problem with what the Government is offering. It is offering Executive-to-shadow Executive chitchat over a cup of tea or a couple of beers and that is totally inadequate. Parliament is here to scrutinise the Executive. That includes the backbenchers, the Democrats-and I regret that on some occasions-and the Independents. Decisions are not meant to be made through Executive-to-shadow Executive chitchat.

I turn to the question of commercial-in-confidence. This question has been raised in Estimates committees and it comes up again and again. Whenever the Government does not want to tell anyone what a boo-boo it has made, it just says that something is commercial-in-confidence; a third party will be hurt. Of course, anybody who is reasonable does not want to put third parties at risk in the examination of what the Executive is doing. Therefore, there is a tendency to say that if something is commercial-in-confidence, it is okay.

But we have seen that happen before. It is the greatest trick in the book, used to cover up some evil. It happened with the ABC. When it was asked what Geraldine Doogue was paid-some people had a particular interest in the substantial salary that I believe she was paid-the ABC slipped clauses into its contracts which said that these matters were in-confidence and so the parties to contracts would not release the details of them. That meant that taxpayers who wanted to know whether the ABC was wasting their money would not be able to find out. They would not be able to find out whether Geraldine Doogue was being paid $500,000 a week. It is manifestly ludicrous to claim baldly that commercial-in-confidence means that the Parliament is not entitled to know about a matter.

As outlined by Senator Hill, the proper course of action is that these documents be shown to the Opposition and the Democrats and that some agreement be arrived at as to how any items in the documents that might affect third parties can be taken out. That offer was made by Senator Hill when he first got up to speak this morning. We are not seeking to have the whole lot. It has been indicated that there are some commercial-in-confidence matters in the document and it has been indicated on our behalf that we would be happy to have those parts taken out. But we want an undertaking that when they are taken out, this document will be tabled. That is all I care to say about the remarks of Senator Ray.

I turn briefly to some of the remarks made by Senator Bolkus. The Minister said that he was on about `good government'-another motherhood phrase drummed up by the Minister so that everyone will say, `That is a good thing; Senator Bolkus is in favour of good government'. But he did not go on to explain why it is good government for him, in order to defend his case, to be able to give titbits to the ABC and the Canberra Times and then come in here and say that there is some in-confidence report, a secret report of his Department, which justifies his actions. If he thinks that that amounts to good government, I would like to see him debate it. That is his definition of good government-a Minister being able to come in here and say, `I know I interfered with the tender process, but it was a good idea. The Department has this secret report and it says that it is all okay, so the rest of the Parliament can go home; it is okay'. That is not what good government is about. If Senator Bolkus goes and asks primary schoolchildren, they will tell him that. Good government is not parliament simply accepting what the Executive says.

The Minister says that he wants responsible government. That is what we want; we want the Minister to be responsible for what he has done. We want him to table these documents so that we can see whether what he says is true. If it is true, well and good; he will get the Parliament's backing.

I should not need to repeat-but I do-that there has been an undertaking that any in-confidence matters in the document that might affect third parties would be excluded. So all we are asking is that once third parties are not at risk, we want to see this report that the Minister says justifies his actions. That gives credence to our jobs. We have no credence if we do not seek that. This place has no credence if it does not get that by virtue of the numbers; if it just takes what the Minister says as being the case.

The Minister says that his actions in meddling in this process are justified because he wants to ensure that the tender process is fair and accurate. I understand that a huge wad of guidelines exist on the tender process, arrived at after many years of constant debate. As Senator Hill said, these guidelines can always be improved. No-one believes that the Government tendering processes are perfect; they can always be improved. But Senator Bolkus seems to be saying that, irrespective of the guidelines-do not worry about what they say-he, Senator Bolkus, the possessor of all knowledge of what is fair and accurate, can bypass these guidelines and with his personal intermeddling he will ensure that we get a better result.

That is simply not an appropriate course of action for a Minister to be taking. If he thinks that the guidelines are inadequate and that he has some better way of going about it, he should seek to have the guidelines changed. He should not just personally intermeddle in matters to get what he sees as a better result.

Even if it were the case that in this one instance his intervention resulted in a fairer response to the tender process, surely we are not going to say, `Well, that is okay. As a Minister, you can continue to meddle all you like'. We then have to say that we believe he is the possessor of all knowledge of what is fair and accurate, and I for one do not accept that. I imagine that a few other people here do not accept that either. I am pretty damned sure that there are a few honourable senators on the Government side who do not accept it, either.

So it is not good enough to say, `In this case doing the wrong thing was okay because a fair and accurate result was achieved'. If the process is wrong, the process should be fixed up. Because the Minister gets caught up in his own argument, he thinks it is appropriate that he intervene to get a fair and accurate result. Yet, in the same breath-standing right next to that argument-the Minister puts forward another argument-that his actions are justified because there is something wrong with the tender processes in the Department.

On the one hand the Minister says, `I am the Minister and I can intermeddle because I keep things fair and accurate' and, on the other hand, he says, `But, you know, sometimes I do not intermeddle properly and the tendering process has not been followed properly'. He cannot have it both ways. If he wants to say he is the responsible Minister and his intermeddling fixes things up, how does he explain the existence of a secret report that says he has not, on a number of occasions, fixed things up? The arguments do not sit happily together. The reason they do not sit happily together is that they have been cobbled up at the last minute. The Minister was skulking around in the corridors hoping to get out of having a debate while someone could write a speech for him.

The last thing I want to say about the contribution by Senator Bolkus relates to another motherhood statement. Firstly, the Minister said, `I am in favour of responsible government', without any adequate explanation of why it is responsible for him to meddle in tender activities. Secondly, he said, `I am in favour of fair and accurate tender processes. Therefore, go along with me'. The Minister gave no adequate explanation of his intervention there. Thirdly, he said, `I am in favour of buying Australian. We all like kangaroos, boomerangs and anything else Australians produce, so you should be happy with my interfering in this process so that we can buy Australian'.

Those of us who support the concept of buying Australian do not think that buying Australian means that the Minister should be allowed to intervene at will on behalf of Australian products. We do not mean that at all. We mean that, where the Australian product is as good or is better, and the price differential is not substantial, one should buy Australian. We do not mean that Ministers should have a licence to intervene at will.

I look forward this afternoon to the result of Opposition senators having had a look at these documents. I sincerely hope that we can come to an agreement whereby those parts of the documents that might prejudice third parties can be taken out and the remaining parts of the document, which the Minister says justify his actions, can be tabled in this place. Anything less than that really means that Parliament has simply become government of the day, executive to shadow executive and the rest of us may as well go home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This issue arose out of a proper question asked by the Opposition and a proper answer. In his answer, the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) quoted from a document. The Opposition, quite properly, asked the Minister to table that document. On the basis of his assessment, the Minister properly declined to do so. As a result, a debate is under way.

SPEECH.PARA: It is proper for a Minister, on occasions, to decline to table a document. I say that on the basis of what this chamber has done in the past and on the basis of the Standing Orders under which it operates. The longer I am a member of this place the more impressed I am with the good sense of those who preceded us and, of course, with the good sense of present senators. Standing order 168 states:

A document relating to public affairs quoted by a Minister may be ordered to be laid on the table, unless the Minister states that the document is of a confidential nature or should more properly be obtained by address.
Those who preceded us in this place quite properly understood that there are instances where a document should not be tabled or made public.
I have listened to the excellent contributions made in the debate here and to the quite passionate speech by Senator Vanstone upholding--

TALK.START.PARA: —And a good speech, too.

—It was a good speech, too. It properly put forward the fact that no information should be denied to this chamber on a prima facie basis; that Parliament should have all the information that it wants-not only that it needs but that it wants-and, indeed, that there should be free debate and free discussion across this chamber. There is nothing constitutionally to stop it getting that sort of debate. Indeed, the privilege we have against being sued for defamation for whatever we say in this chamber is another indication of how it is right and proper that debates should go across the chamber based on full facts and based on a situation where nobody can be sued for libel.

SPEECH.PARA: But, if we have got these incredible privileges-and they are incredible privileges-we should use them responsibly. If in the course of a debate we damage people outside this chamber who do not have a proper means of vindicating themselves, we act irresponsibly. That does happen in this chamber from time to time and we have got procedures in place to correct it.

What has happened here is that there has been a dispute about whether or not this document ought to be brought forward. What Senator Powell is very sensibly going to do is to suggest that people look at it to see whether or not the debate should go forward to the point where a motion is passed compelling that production. For the life of me I cannot see what is wrong with the process that has been pursued so far and why anybody should be getting disturbed about a very proper course that has been taken to date.

The fact is that, if everybody in the chamber were given a look at the document to see whether or not it is of a confidential nature, the confidentiality would disappear. That is the problem with making this document available to the Senate generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not even offer to make it available.
—Senator Reid has quite properly said that he did not offer to make it available, but what the Minister did yesterday was to make a--
—He treated the Senate with contempt.

—No. What he did was to give an answer which is regularly given by Ministers in this chamber. We have been here again and again when there has been a request for a Minister to table a document and the Minister has declined on the basis of standing order 168. It is hard to see how we can say that a Minister is treating the Parliament with contempt when he is simply relying on the orders that this chamber has made-on standing order 168, which has been made by and has become a traditional part of and a traditional rule used in this chamber. It is impossible to accuse the Minister of acting irresponsibly or in contempt of Parliament or of this chamber when he pursues a course of action which is set out for him by the chamber. In other words, we cannot be contemptuous of a chamber which has given us rules which we have to follow. So the Minister has acted very properly in all of this. To repeat myself-but it is a point worth making-the very reason we have standing order 168 is to meet the very situation we have here.

SPEECH.PARA: The way around it, of course, is not to rely on what the Minister says. We are not relying on what the Minister says. We are relying on people from the various parties represented in this chamber having a look at it and saying, `Well, yes, we understand what you said, Minister; we accept what you say and we will go on from there' or saying, `Look, we do not accept what you are saying', and then to take the next step.

The preliminary step that has not been gone through yet is the decision of whether or not this document is of a confidential nature. Until that is decided it seems that the rest of the rhetoric that the Opposition has engaged in is premature. It is my view that we should proceed as soon as pos- sible to the proposition that is about to be put by Senator Powell and go on from there.

What has been shown in this debate is that the Minister has not acted improperly in any way; he has acted responsibly and has simply made use of the orders that this chamber itself has established. The proper carrying out of those orders is the next step that we have to take and that can be done by the leaders of the various parties having a look at the document and for us to see what happens from then on. Otherwise, we are jeopardising-or may be jeopardising-the commercial viability of all sorts of companies which cannot properly put their defence in the chamber today.

It seems to me fairly harsh of us to go on demanding this document before the leaders have had a look at it because, if we were all to look at it, the very purpose of the order and the very purpose of confidentiality would be defeated and people could be seriously injured.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the reasons the Opposition does need the full documents, if necessary with some names excised if there really are commercial-in-confidence considerations, is that we must have the capacity to reveal where these documents correct the totally false impressions that have been created by the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) about this matter. If we have private access to the documents we do not have the capacity to reveal where this Minister has misled the Parliament. We do not have the capacity to do so if we have only private access to these documents.
—Why do we have standing order 168?

—The fact is that this matter could be resolved very simply if the documents were provided, with appropriate excisions if-I understand `if' and underline `if'-there are commercial-in-confidence matters relating to specific suppliers. But not to give us the opportunity to present material which destroys this Minister's case is, I think, absurd.

SPEECH.PARA: We have already seen this morning how the Minister set out to mislead the Parliament. If the Minister would stop chatting across the table I am certain he would be interested in this. This is how this Minister set out this morning to mislead the Parliament, as he did yesterday. He suggested that what he was trying to do with Nashua was nothing more than what had happened to another supplier. He said another supplier was given a second go. I quote from his answer in yesterday's Question Time:
. . . one supplier was given a second chance and was subsequently put on the panel after the close of tender.
He repeated it this morning, saying that Senator Parer did not understand because he had not listened and had not understood the burden of this comment by the Minister.

What the Minister does not understand is that the tender procedures, as they existed before his review, provide specifically for the capacity to negotiate before the tender is let, but after the tender procedure has closed. What the Minister was trying to do with Nashua was after the tenders procedure had closed and after the tender was let.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two months after.

—It was two months after the tender was let. The one supplier who was given a second chance was subsequently put on the panel after the close of the tender but not after the tender was let. For this Minister to come in here and pretend that the Nashua fiddle that he has perpetrated is anything like giving the other supplier a second go is a disgrace. It is a deliberate attempt to mislead this Parliament and this Minister should apologise to this place for doing so, because the facts-they are revealed in the document that Senator Parer tabled-are these:

SPEECH.PARA: Post offer negotiation-
in other words, before the granting of the tender-

involves independent discussions with one or more potential suppliers to clarify, reach agreement on or settle terms after bids (i.e. quotes, offers, proposals, or tenders) have been received and before a contract is formed. The aim is to improve those bids and clarify uncertainties through a structured and ethical process.

That is what the other tenderer went through-the one that Senator Bolkus now cites to defend himself-but Nashua and Senator Bolkus did not go through a structured and ethical process. This Minister took Nashua through an unstructured and unethical process. He demanded that Nashua be put on the list two months after the contracts had been let.

For this Minister to pretend there is any similarity between the other contractor who was given a second go and Nashua is a disgrace. If he seeks to mislead the chamber like this I am certain that his status, which is already appallingly low, will go even lower in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will never get to the bottom of the harbour.
—I acknowledge that interjection because it shows what this Minister is all about. He has no capacity to respond except to try a bit of personal abuse. I want the facts dealt with here.
—He doesn't understand.

— The Minister does not understand the difference between a post-tender discussion and adjustment, and a post-letting of the tender discussion. He is so incompetent that he cannot understand that difference.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, what the Minister is now stating by his actions is that an Australian supplier can have a special second go. In other words, it can put in a tender bid at a high price, aiming to rip off the Australian taxpayer, knowing that, under the Bolkus rules, if it misses out it can come again at a lower price. In other words, if it gets away with the attempted rip-off-great-the taxpayers of Australia have to foot the bill. If it does not get away with the attempted rip-off, Senator Bolkus will help it to get the tender. That is what the simple consequences of this situation really are. I must say that there are also some, I believe, clear attempts to mislead the chamber on this matter, because Senator Bolkus said:
I was informed of the results of the review-
this is by the Department-
. . . and was advised, both in writing and verbally-
I suppose he means orally. Maybe the writing was not in words; it might have been in hieroglyphs-
that I should act and not let the status quo continue.

We recognise that that was long after Senator Bolkus had already acted without advice-in fact, contrary to the advice. This is the important matter. The suggestion made by Mr Lyneham in his questioning of Senator Bolkus was quite interesting. Senator Bolkus was asked this by Mr Lyneham:
I mean, any Ministerial fingerprints on it anywhere?
This is about the internal inquiry. Mr Lyneham said:

And now you've had, or they've had, an independent internal inquiry that says, basically, you were right and they were wrong. How independent was this. I mean, any Ministerial fingerprints on it anywhere?
Listen to Senator Bolkus's response. Does he say, `No, there were no ministerial fingerprints on it anywhere'? Not on your nelly. He says:
Well, let me say the matter was brought to the attention of the Secretary and the Deputy Secretaries involved.

By whom? When? It was certainly brought to their attention. In other words, the Secretary and the Deputy Secretary of the Department knew perfectly well that the Minister had gone out on a very public limb at this stage and had written a very strong letter demanding that Nashua be reinstated. Obviously, the Secretary and the Deputy Secretary would have faced a very difficult situation indeed if, after that event, they had come up with something that had no ministerial fingerprints on it anywhere. Senator Bolkus then went on to say:

They went through it with me, very exhaustively, and I think they felt very strongly that, in fact, I'm sure they felt very strongly, independently of any view that I might have had, that the process really had to be looked at.

All this suddenly happened after the Minister had written demanding that Nashua be added in an arrangement which had offended the operatives in the Department, and in a system that clearly broke the accepted rules. The Minister cannot possibly claim that the other tenderer had not fitted the rules. It clearly did. Senator Bolkus said he felt that the departmental officers were strongly and independently of a view. If Senator Bolkus could say with honesty that there were no ministerial fingerprints on it anywhere, why did he not say that to Paul Lyneham?

TALK.START.PARA: —There weren't. Why don't you acknowledge that interjection?
—I acknowledge the interjection. Senator Bolkus now, on reflection, some days later, says there were not. I wonder why he did not say it at the time. I have got it all here:

SPEECH.PARA: That led to the review team, which was set up by the Departmental secretary, and I think its fair to say that . . .
Question: Did you have any meetings with the review team?
Answer: I didn't.
That is what Senator Bolkus wants us to know: he did not have any meetings with the review team. Did he have any meetings with the Secretary and the Deputy Secretaries? Yes, he did.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course I did.
—Of course he did. So we have a totally independent review following discussions between the Minister and the Deputy Secretary. How wonderfully independent.
—Ask him what he said.
—What was that interjection, Senator?

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: — The interesting thing is that Senator Bolkus says that this team was set up `because senior officers felt that the processing in this particular area . . . had to be looked at exhaustively'. They only got this feeling after Senator Bolkus said that, against all the rules, Nashua had to be reinstated. Is that not a magic and extraordinary situation! We have, firstly, Senator Bolkus being totally wrong about the other firm, making a quaint suggestion that he felt maybe it was independent and that it had come to this determination independently. Then, of course, he also seeks to mislead us on the question of the average price of the four products. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The average price of four products was assessed without weighting being given to items likely to be procured in greater volumes. In fact, in Nashua's case-the case that got some publicity-one of its products which failed to get on the contract was in fact 35 per cent cheaper than another supplier's successful product.

If Senator Bolkus is going to give us these exciting little glimpses of information, how about he tells us the full story. How much of the contract is to be made up of the items that are 35 per cent cheaper? In terms of volume, to what extent does that have any real impact on the final outcome?

Here we get this little suggestion that maybe it was in Australia's best interests to pay more to Nashua, to give Nashua a second chance, because one of its items was 35 per cent cheaper. But unless we have the letter, unless we know the facts and can reveal those facts, we have to put up with the sort of deliberate misleading of this place which has already been demonstrated here today.

That is one of the reasons why we must have the documents. We must have access to them so that information will be available for us to dispute and deny the propositions that Senator Bolkus has put up clearly in quite a mischievous way at some stages to mislead the Parliament and the people. I notice, too, that Senator Bolkus in Question Time yesterday said:
It has to be understood also in this context that suppliers can and do change their prices after these standing offers are issued.
He went on:
This is specifically provided for in the tendering document.

I am advised that Nashua, as a previous supplier, had often reduced its prices in favour of the Commonwealth during previous contracts, as have other suppliers. I am advised that such price reductions are proper. I would be astounded to know when price reductions have not been proper. That is an extraordinary and nonsensical comment.

One of the regular suppliers to departments, Dysan, a supplier of magnetic tapes, missed out on being one of the successful four tenderers. That is revealed in Inside Canberra. It missed out purely on price. But the people using the equipment are unhappy about changing from Dysan. They apparently have some problems about quality and supply. As Inside Canberra points out, if it is in Australia's best interests to reopen the Nashua application, why does the Government not reopen everything? You cannot have one without the other without destroying the integrity of the tender process. This Minister has not demonstrated, at any stage, why Nashua alone should have its tender re-examined, and why the benefits that he says come to an Australian manufacturer of having it done are not massively outweighed by the damage done in terms of the cost to the taxpayer and the destruction of the tender process by what the Minister has done. The facts are that he may get a cheap shot; he may get a quick trick. He may be able to wave his hands, as he has here, saying, `All I was doing was trying to give a benefit to an Australian supplier'.

TALK.START.PARA: —He can do that by reopening it.

—He could do that by reopening the tenders. But he cannot do it by destroying the tender process by not giving other contenders an equal opportunity to lower their prices. We should remind the Minister that another Australian producer got on the list because his price was right. We have to recognise that Nashua did not get on the list because it put in a price that was above the price that it was capable of putting in if it really wanted that tender. Nashua has now said that it can put in a lower price.
—Why didn't it do so in the first place?

—I thank Senator Patterson. Why did it not do it in the first place? Why has this one company got some special relationship that enables it to have another go? Until these documents are available, we cannot provide the information to deny the mountain of rubbish that this Minister has come out with. Certainly, I have been able to deny some things today. I have been able to deny them because I have had access to the commercial-in-confidence material that was leaked to the Opposition, about which the Minister has complained. We know-this document reveals it to us-that the Minister was misleading us. We need the report itself to establish just exactly where else the Minister has misled us on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing this subject, we must determine the most important principle: whether it is a matter of tenderers' confidentiality or of the principle of keeping intact the tendering system. The actions of the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) in this case have certainly put the tendering system in jeopardy, and maybe in jeopardy forever. So if there is any question whatsoever that the tendering process has been compromised in this case, the document must be tabled. Of course, commercial confidentiality must be addressed. However, the unsuccessful tenderers may have no objections in this case to being named or tabled. Has anyone bothered to ask them?

SPEECH.PARA: If I were a tenderer in this or any other case and I was denied the chance of being a successful tenderer and not given a second chance like Nashua was, I would not be worried about commercial confidentiality one iota. I would want it exposed that I was a successful tenderer that was pushed out by an illegal act of a Minister. That is the principle that we have to address this afternoon. Commercial confidentiality must be supported; but when it comes to a case of wrecking a tendering system that has been the cornerstone of public purchasing in Australia, we must examine the matter.

Why do we have a tendering system? It is to prevent rorts in the buying system. There have been accusations across the chamber today, between Senator Faulkner and Senator Macdonald, about Queensland purchasing. If we do not have a public tendering system, how shall we keep tenderers straight, and how shall we keep purchasers straight? How shall we keep Ministers straight, and how shall we keep the Government straight? As I said before, public tendering is there. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.
