INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of Mr Alexander Dubcek, Chairman of the Federal Assembly of the Czech and Slovak Federal Republic. As all honourable senators will be aware, Mr Dubcek is in Australia as the guest of the Parliament. On behalf of all honourable senators, I take great pleasure in welcoming you, sir, to the Senate. As your visit is now almost at an end, I trust that your time in Australia has been both informative and enjoyable. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I propose to invite Mr Dubcek to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Dubcek was thereupon seated accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade how he can retain for one day longer Brian Burke as Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See; a man whose behaviour the Prime Minister has described as `unwise in the extreme and improper on some accounts'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the reason that there is some behaviour which is unwise or, in some respects, improper but which is nonetheless not so improper that it justifies involuntary termination of the appointment. That was the case in terms of my assessment of Mr Burke's behaviour in relation to the conduct of a political account, the full details of which are not, of course, before us-only some aspects.

ANSWER.PARA: The decision that I made was based on departmental advice, as I have made clear, and as the Prime Minister has made clear. That advice, while characterising the behaviour in some respects as improper as well as, indeed, unwise, did not suggest that termination of the appointment would be an appropriate response.

On the contrary, the advice to me was that in any similar circumstance involving anyone else, or had this come to light earlier otherwise than in the context of Mr Burke's resignation, the Department's advice would have been to warn the ambassador in question that the behaviour was totally inappropriate for someone continuing to hold the office of ambassador and to require him to cease and desist the behaviour in question immediately. I responded to that advice and acted accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —In light of the Minister's answer, Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Where does the Minister place Mr Burke's taking of stamps-purchased with Australian Labor Party funds-to Ireland and integrating them within his personal stamp collection? Where does he place that in this order of `range of improper behaviour'?

—Mr Burke's conduct, in relation to the stamps matter, is very much one for determination by the Royal Commission. The circumstances involved-Mr Burke's state of mind in relation to the stamps in question-are not something that I am proposing to make any judgment about or any characterisation of in terms of either impropriety or illegality. Accordingly, I think it is one of those numerous matters, which were properly characterised by Senator Hill in his commentary on PM last week, which should be left to the determination of the Royal Commission.
—Can the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs tell the chamber what recent measures the Government has taken to protect dolphins from the odious practice of driftnet fishing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many honourable senators will have received petitions and letters, not only from children but also from adults around Australia, protesting at the way in which the walls of death driftnet fishing method captures dolphins in those nets and leads to their strangulation and death. Many thousands of dolphins die annually in this infamous fishing practice. Therefore the Australian Government has decided to introduce a mandatory labelling system for all canned tuna products sold within Australia. Obviously, this will capture those products that are imported from overseas and those which are processed within Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: This will allow consumers to use their purchasing power in our supermarkets and in the marketplace to ensure that processed tuna purchased in Australia is not such that it involved the killing of dolphins by the use of a fishing method as horrendous as the walls of death driftnets. We have agreed to introduce a scheme for the compulsory labelling on all processed tuna sold in Australia. This will mean that all cans of tuna must show either a positive statement such as `dolphin safe', `dolphin friendly' or something similar, or a negative statement to the effect that the container may contain tuna which has been caught by a method which harms dolphins. I expect the regulatory machinery for the new labelling regime to be in place by the end of this year.

This will provide significant information to consumers in the supermarkets in the marketplace to enable them to use their purchasing power to carry their environmental concerns into positive effect. Certainly, Greenpeace, the consumer organisations, the tuna fishing fleets based in Australia and the importers and processors have all been on a working party advising me in this respect. I pay tribute to them in coming to this particular recommendation, which I have accepted.

I believe that consumers want to have this sort of information to enable them to make decisions which will favour the fishing methods for tuna which do not endanger the lives of dolphins. By the end of this year or sooner, I believe, because of pressure in the marketplace, this information will be available to them as they carry out their weekly shopping.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to constant Government statements that Mr Brian Burke was not sacked as Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See but in fact resigned. As this assertion leads to the conclusion that the sum of $28,000 to be paid to Mr Burke is not a termination payment but some form of ex gratia or act of grace payment, and given that such a payment can only be made pursuant to section 34a of the Audit Act, I ask the Minister to inform the Senate how he will be able to pay the money to Brian Burke, as he promised, when section 34a (1) requires that such payment must be authorised by the Minister for Finance or his appointee and when, in answer to my question on this matter in Estimates Committee A on Monday morning last, Mr Pat Barrett, the Deputy Secretary of the Department of Finance, replied:

QUESTION.PARA: I must say that I would be very hesitant of using an act of grace in such a circumstance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The payment in question is not an act of grace payment in the way that Senator Bishop is describing it. The payment in question, as I have made perfectly clear, was determined pursuant to the authority vested in me by the Governor-General quite specifically in the context of this appointment, and there is similar authority in respect of other such appointments, to determine the terms and conditions of the employment as ambassador. The language of the determination that I made is open-ended to the extent that in the last paragraph it makes provision for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade-not the Minister for Industrial Relations, as Mr Peacock in his gloriously inexact account of the law involved here intimated, but me-within the context of that determination itself to make any appropriate determination relating to matters of terms and conditions. Even if it were thought that that particular paragraph-and the document has been tabled in Estimates-was not so explicit, the open-ended authority vested in me by the Governor-General confers ample authority.

ANSWER.PARA: That was the view of my Department in written advice that I received on this matter. That has been confirmed subsequently by advice from the Attorney-General's Department. There is no question but that the payment in question was properly made-not only properly made legally speaking, for the reasons I have just indicated, but also properly made in all the circumstances of the case, for the reasons that were well articulated by Mr Costello at the time of the Estimates Committee.

The extraordinary excursion into legal analysis that we have had from Mr Peacock as shadow Attorney-General, and now from the egregious Senator Bishop on the same subject, demonstrates nothing more than the total incapacity of any Opposition spokesman, or backbencher for that matter, to get his or her legal analysis right.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his gratuitous comments, but when he reconsiders his answer in the light of the legal position and the advice that is available to him from the Audit Office, how does he believe his answer fits within the requirements of acts that have to be approved by the Minister for Finance? The advice is that section 34a (1) applies to all kinds of amounts that are not payable in pursuance to the law or are not payable under a legal liability or not payable under the terms and conditions of a non-statutory scheme of payments approved by Cabinet or a Minister. I ask the Minister at the same time whether, if Ambassador Burke-and he still is Ambassador, as I understand it-is found to have committed an impropriety or indeed illegalities, the $28,000 will still be paid.
—Tiresome repetition is no substitute for intelligent legal analysis. Until I get some of the latter, I have nothing further to add to my answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware of the recent decision by the British Government to increase the standard rate of value added tax (VAT) in that country from 15 per cent to 17.5 per cent? Does this tendency to increase the rate of consumption tax conform with the experience of other countries which have introduced similar taxes? What lessons does this increase in Britain's VAT hold for the proposals to introduce a consumption tax in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Strange to say, but I am aware of the British Government's decision in this matter. Senator Childs was good enough to draw it to my attention. In the recent Budget the VAT rate was increased from 15 per cent to 17.5 per cent. Looking at the situation of the British economy-and they might say this about us-they had to do something. This decision underlies the contention that the Government has pointed to in the past that a consumption tax, once introduced, can become an easy out for governments not willing to take the hard decisions on the expenditure side of the Budget-a comment made by the Treasurer earlier this year and I think last year.
—It is a worry to your Government.

—That is a silly interjection, because it does not accord with the facts. The point I am making is that a consumption tax or VAT can be an easy vehicle for governments to avoid hard decisions. The general experience of other countries with consumption taxes has been for tax rates to rise, suggesting that there is every reason for concerns on these grounds. For example, the rate of goods and services tax, the GST, in New Zealand-the country on which the Opposition is apparently basing its proposed system at this stage; we do not know what ultimately will come out from the Opposition-has already increased 25 per cent since inception, from 10 per cent to 12.5 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: In answer to Senator Child's question, in the Australian context that means that a consumption tax could well become a vehicle for increasing the relative tax burden on low to middle income earners to accommodate the fiscal laxity of the coalition parties, which was so evident in the period of the Fraser Government, or alternatively to trowel tax cuts to higher income earners.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. In view of the Minister's decision to review the business migration program and to suspend accreditation of business migration program agents, I ask the Minister: first, how many business migration program agents are currently accredited and how many are currently seeking accreditation; secondly, what checks are made on the money brought into Australia by business migrants with regard to its use and investment and who makes these checks; thirdly, why is the business migration program set apart from all other migration programs and managed by private agents and not by government officers; and, fourthly, why will the Government not suspend the business migration program during the review, apart from those applications already in the process of assessment, since the review may well show, as the Australian Democrats believe, that the business migration program, as it currently operates, should cease?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Powell has asked a number of questions of detail on the numbers of agencies, checks, and so on, which I will obviously forward to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Other than referring the question to the Minister, all I can say is that Senator Powell is quite right about the Government's announced review. Media reports have distorted the announcement of the Minister on the business migration program. We are still committed to providing an avenue for successful business people to migrate to Australia as part of the overall migration program.

ANSWER.PARA: However, as honourable senators would know, a variety of allegations criticising the current program and its integrity and effectiveness have been made in the press and put to the Joint Committee on Public Accounts, which has been conducting an inquiry into the program. Obviously, they have had the effect of undermining some aspects of the program. As a result of these concerns and of the Department's own experiences, the Government considers that it is desirable to act now to review the program.

In the review, we will focus on the most appropriate mechanism for allowing business people to settle here. I should also add that in the Minister's announcement he indicated that he was keen to have the views of the Joint Committee on Public Accounts form part of his deliberations. In the context of that, I am sure that the Australian Democrats' views will also be taken into account.

I am further advised that the reporting date of the Joint Standing Committee has slipped by several months. The Government has decided that it would be inadvisable to delay our review any further, so we have written to the Chairman of the Committee to request that the principal findings of the Committee be provided to the Government in advance. We will get the details requested by Senator Powell. Also her views will be welcomed by the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I wonder whether in this review the Minister will ask the responsible Minister to consider treating business migrants in the same way as those who seek permanent residence in Australia, for instance, on the grounds of having become a spouse of an Australian citizen or permanent resident-that is, the granting of permanent residence after a two-year period to decide whether the relationship or, in this case, the business investment plan is a genuine one.
—I will pass on Senator Powell's views to the Minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Can the Minister explain the reasons for his announcement today that the deeming rate will be lowered to 8 per cent? Can the Minister also outline what this means for pensioners and what it might mean for banks?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some honourable senators may be aware that this morning I announced that the 10 per cent deeming rate which has been--
—You said you weren't going to make a ministerial statement.

—I am not making a ministerial statement. I am answering a question from an honourable senator, which I shall continue to do. The deeming rate will be changed from 10 per cent to 8 per cent. Senator Walters and some of those opposite, who were so concerned last August when the deeming announcement was made that 10 per cent would be impossible to get, now have to face the fact that there are 62 accounts around Australia offering 10 per cent at call.

ANSWER.PARA: That having been the case now for some time, pensioners have not had difficulty getting the 10 per cent. However, one cannot hold a rate artificially high for too long. Mind you, Mr President, rates for pensioners were artificially low for decades. Until the Government took the stance that it took last August, pensioners were always behind. For the first time in Australia's history, they have been in front of market rates and that is something of which I can be justifiably proud.

Nonetheless, since August, there has been a reduction in market rates and I think it was appropriate that the Government ought to acknowledge that. Obviously, no full rate pensioners-and they make up the vast majority of pensioners-are going to be affected by today's decision. It means that some 25,000 fewer pensioners will be affected by deeming. The rates of $20,000 for a single pensioner and $36,000 for a married pensioner couple change to $26,000 for a single pensioner and $45,500 for a married couple. These are the amounts that pensioners can have before their pension will be affected.

As I have said, this will mean that far fewer will be affected; it will mean some pension increase for quite a few who will be in that category. It means that we now have a rate which I think we can maintain for quite some time and which will be reviewed twice a year. Most importantly, I think it is very close to the rate for which the banks asked. The banks had, of course, asked for a formula rate. I do not believe that we could explain to pensioners any rate that varied every month and, in some cases, every week. So I could not agree to a formula. But I have, I think, come up with a suitable compromise which, while it may not be greeted with glee by the banks, will nonetheless satisfy them.

Finally, it should also be noted that in savings terms there are far greater savings for the taxpayer in this than were estimated in the Budget. I have made the point several times in the chamber that I thought the Budget estimates were low. In fact, $95m is now the case for a full year's saving. So even though 8 per cent almost halves the amount that can be saved for the taxpayer, there will still be a saving of almost $50m, which is very close to the $56m figure in the Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to his answer to a question yesterday concerning Ambassador Burke's `continuing role in respect of Australia's trade with eastern Europe' and to the document tabled in connection with this matter. I refer further to Ambassador Burke's visit to Geneva with Mr Lang Hancock in September 1988 to meet with Soviet representatives. I ask the Minister: who paid for the cost of Ambassador Burke's trip? What was the nature of the business discussed with the Soviet representatives referred to by the Minister? Were any departmental representatives involved in this meeting?
—This is right back in September 1988. I have no more knowledge of what that trip was about than was contained in the departmental advice to me which I tabled yesterday and which I--
—But Burke telephoned you two days before he went, didn't he?

—Yes, to seek general permission to assist, on behalf of Australia, some business transactions. But I did not discuss in any detail what he was proposing to talk about with the Soviet representatives or Mr Hancock in Geneva. I simply do not have any further information on that. I will see what further information is available and let the honourable senator know accordingly. There is no secret about it. I mean, we told Mr Peacock about this when he asked in January 1990; we told members of the Opposition about it in the Estimates Committee; I am telling them about it now.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. There are a whole lot of questions in my original question that Senator Evans has chosen to ignore. Who paid the cost of Ambassador Burke's trip; what was the nature of the business that he was informed about by Ambassador Burke when he telephoned to ask permission to go-as my colleague just said, it is not as easy to get leave from the Whips' Office as that-and were any departmental representatives involved in this meeting?

—My recollection is that no departmental representatives were involved in the Geneva meeting, although they were in the meetings in Romania, which were the subject of the trip in April 1989. It is the case that the trip was paid for at official expense. It is the case that while Mr Burke did speak to me, as I am reminded by my annotation on that particular submission, it was simply in general terms, as I recall, to ask about my and the Government's attitude to the appropriateness of his continuing to assist with putting together some commercial transactions manifestly in the national interest which, on his-

—I do not know how the lot opposite think that trade is conducted except through entrepreneurs going out there and doing business. I do not know what they think that Austrade does, that high commissioners do and that ambassadors do in facilitating the conduct of business between particular businessmen engaged in entering into projects, selling commodities and making profits which will flow back to the benefit of this country. There is no principle of quarantining the private sector from the public sector. The whole point of the amalgamation of the Department of Foreign Affairs and the Department of Trade was to utilise the available professional expertise, which does unquestionably exist in the public sector, and to mobilise it for the advantage of the national economy in this particular way. The advice that I received from the Department addressed these issues. I responded accordingly. It was not a matter without difficulty for reasons clearly articulated in the departmental advice. I have nothing more to say.

—I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade: what contribution will Australia make to the international measures established in order to implement Security Council resolution 687 to oversee the process of destroying Iraq's weapons of mass destruction?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia has been a strong supporter of resolution 687 under which, as Senator Giles said, a special commission has been established to oversee the destruction of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction and its ballistic missiles. We indicated, through the Prime Minister in Parliament on 16 April, that Australia was prepared to assist with staff in the conduct of that special commission's activity. That offer has now been responded to in a way of which we in Australia can be proud. The United Nations Secretary-General has decided to appoint a senior Foreign Affairs officer, Dr John Gee, who is Director of Chemical and Biological Disarmament in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, to be the Chairman on the special commission's working group on chemical and biological weapons; in other words, to be one of the most senior people in the entire special commission with the responsibility for that whole area of weapons of mass destruction.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has also offered to assist the International Atomic Energy Agency in the implementation of its tasks under that resolution, which is something I referred to yesterday I think in answer to Senator Coulter's question. I am pleased to advise the Senate that today Mr Kerin and I jointly announced that Mr John Bardsley, head of the international safeguards section of the Australian Safeguards Office, has been assigned to the team that will carry out the first inspections of Iraqi nuclear facilities. It is an appointment which testifies to the recognition of Australian expertise in the safeguards field. Mr Bardsley's selection, following that of Dr Gee, will be acknowledged by all honourable senators as a further clear recognition by the international community of Australia's expertise in the fields of arms control and disarmament and our active contribution to preventing the proliferation of nuclear weapons.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of two former senators-a former President of the Senate, Sir Harold Young, and former Senator Don Jessop, from South Australia. I am sure they are here for the former members' meeting tomorrow. On behalf of all honourable senators, I wish them well.

—I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to information made available to Senate Estimates Committee B last week concerning special arrangements for Ambassador Burke's residence phone bill in Ireland. I ask him three questions. Firstly, will the Minister table the full audit comments in relation to the residence phone bill arrangements, and can the Minister assure the Senate that all audit recommendations have been carried out? Secondly, will the Minister also table the letter that he wrote to Mr Burke varying the phone bill arrangements? Thirdly, how many other ambassadors have had residence phone bills as large as Mr Burke's, and why were the special arrangements authorised for Mr Burke?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the audit arrangements, there is documentation bearing upon that which I am willing to table, and I will do so as soon as I can find it in the bundle of material I have with me. As I recall, that consists of an audit report of December 1989 dealing with a wide range of matters, as these do, which concluded generally that the administration of the post was perfectly satisfactory but that some attention needed to be paid to a number of specific matters, one of which was the method of recording private calls and the level of head of mission contribution accordingly for the residential phone. That matter was subsequently addressed, as will appear from subsequent documents in the mat- erial that I am happy to table.

ANSWER.PARA: As to correspondence that I have subsequently addressed to Mr Burke in this respect, I am also happy to table that. It is perfectly straightforward, drawing attention to the nature and size of the bills for both the chancery and the residence, making it clear that the level of contribution, while apparently correct in terms of the procedures that had been hitherto required and agreed upon, was nonetheless on the face of it fairly small, and seeking confirmation of the rate of personal usage involved.

I followed that letter of 6 May with a further letter of 7 May, which I am also happy to table, following the revelation which has been communicated to members of the Estimates Committee that a logging facility was available from 1 January last year for the residential phone, making that information available to Mr Burke and suggesting that he get hold of-and we would assist him-the call log concerned and that that might help him in evaluating his level of contribution.

I have also drawn attention to the size of the chancery bill as distinct from the residence bill, which is large, and asked for his confirmation that the rate of personal usage in relation to that was as first indicated, and also seeking any further explanation, if possible, for why the bill is as large as it is. I table those documents now as requested. I would be prepared to table all sorts of things if the Opposition were sensible enough to ask for them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for his cooperation. I repeat the last part of my question: how many other ambassadors have had residence phone bills as large as Mr Burke's, and why were the special arrangements authorised?

—One cannot talk in terms of ambassadors at large; one has to look at ambassadors in terms of the size, character and nature of the mission and so on. I do not think that there has been any residential phone bill as large as Mr Burke's. I would need to check that. When given information of this kind I can do no more than seek explanations for it.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer to a report in the Australian Financial Review indicating that Australia risks losing a large part of its $6 billion coal export business. Is this a possibility, as suggested by the article, because leading coal companies are lagging in the use of clean coal technologies? If so, what action is available to the Federal Government to encourage coalmine owners in Australia to preserve or increase the 32 per cent share of the world market which it already has achieved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the article in the Australian Financial Review, which is based on reported comments by Dr John Stocker, the Chief Executive of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. The first comment that I could make about Australian coal is that we export from Australia high calorific black coal.
—And low sulphur.

—Exactly. In particular, if the Europeans burnt our coal, not only would it be cheaper for them, because it is mined more efficiently, but also it would produce less greenhouse gases per unit of coal. It is much more calorific in content and thus produces more energy. Therefore, Australian coal and the grades we produce in this country, compared with that produced in other countries, is a better buy for coal consuming economies than coal from almost anywhere else. That is not just simply an unashamed booster statement for the Australian coal industry; that is an objective fact.

ANSWER.PARA: I turn to the article that has been referred to. I can assure Senator Colston that the Australian coal industry is aware of the challenges presented by the advent of new clean coal technologies. The industry is also aware of the role that technology packages are likely to play in the marketing of coal, particularly in developing country markets, which, in our view, are likely to expand rapidly in the future.

The Government is working to strengthen our dominant world market share by providing the correct domestic industry framework with an emphasis on the micro-economic reforms that we have canvassed at some length in this chamber; it is also doing so internationally by fighting the protectionist measures that dominate or close some of the overseas markets; and it is promoting the use of coal in Australia and elsewhere in an environmentally responsible manner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Administrative Services aware that the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) has pursued all commercial radio stations, even those in Darwin and Albany, to provide returns of political advertisements during the Menzies by-election in Victoria? Is it normal procedure to extend such returns beyond the area covering the by-election and has the same request been made to all newspapers and television stations in Australia in respect of the Menzies by-election? Will the Minister satisfy himself that the relevant provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act properly authorise these actions of the Australian Electoral Commission? Is this part of the Hawke Government's campaign to block the John Laws advertisements and similar advertisements attacking the Government's undemocratic legislation to ban political advertisements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say at the outset that this action was taken by the AEC and brought to my attention after it was taken. It has advised me that section 310 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 requires broadcasters to lodge a return with the Australian Electoral Commission showing details of electoral advertisements if they broadcast such advertisements during an election period. I am further advised by the Australian Electoral Commission that no geographical limit is prescribed within the Act.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Electoral Commission has advised me that it is compelled, through the provisions of an Act which was passed by this Parliament, to ensure that returns are made. It has taken this action. As honourable senators know, I do not have, nor should I have, any power to direct the Electoral Commission in the way that it sees its functions and it performs its functions under the Electoral Act. There is no connection between its action and anything else that Senator Michael Baume wants to raise in the context of his question.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the newspapers and television?

—In terms of newspapers and other expenditure in election campaigns, I will get further advice from the AEC. The advice is that it extends to broadcasters because of that specific provision of the Act. I shall also pass on the honourable senator's question and my answer to it.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to a report that the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) has been engaged by the Government to assist the commercial viability of the Cape York spaceport project. Will the Minister now say when the AIDC will report its findings and what the Government anticipates the subsequent steps will be in this process?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report that Senator Maguire referred to was contained in the Brisbane Courier-Mail a week or two ago. The Government has engaged the AIDC to establish a single substantial proponent with the necessary skills and resources required to further the Cape York spaceport project. I must say that a hundred flowers have bloomed in respect of interest in this project, but none of them has in the past been a strong bloom and not all of them have sweet smells.
—Have you watered any of them? Have you encouraged them to grow?

—Senator Boswell tempts me to water him! As preparation for this process, the AIDC is required to review both the project and its commercial viability. This phase should be completed in a matter of weeks when the AIDC will report to the Australian Space Office. If the report confirms the project's commercial viability-which I think is fairly well established, given the right proponent-the AIDC will prepare an investment package and will conduct negotiations with commercial and industrial interests to establish the proponent.

ANSWER.PARA: Last October the Government invited a number of companies or groups to come forward and establish their ability to progress the project quickly. More than 20 companies and organisations from Australia and overseas expressed interest. The AIDC will hold discussions with these companies as part of the overall negotiations.

The restructuring of the project is essentially a commercial matter which the Government expects to be handled within the marketplace. The role in which the Government is currently engaged is to prevent the project lapsing by default and to see that all avenues for investor participation are explored. This does not signal a change in the Government's original position that the venture would need to proceed without government investment or subsidy.

United States and Soviet officials have been informed of the spaceport restructuring exercise and steps have been taken by Australian officials and by United Technologies-the proposed United States participant-to ensure that intergovernment negotiations connected with the project continue as scheduled.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EVALUATION OF TENDERS FOR COMPUTER CONSUMABLES

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Administrative Services to his statement on the 7.30 Report that, after an internal inquiry by his Department, the tender process for computer consumables had been found wanting. I ask the Minister whether that is his justification for interfering in the tender process and, if it is, why did he offer a different reason in his letter to the Department of 4 March? That letter says:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . it would seem that Nashua have unfortunately hurt their own case by not submitting their best price at the time of tender.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I made it very clear yesterday that I had three motivations-and still have three motivations-for being involved in this particular process. One motivation was to ensure that the Government and, in turn, the taxpayer got value for money. Getting the cheapest item is one factor, but getting a quality item is another factor. I also made it clear yesterday that another motivation was that Australian companies should not be unfairly disadvantaged by the process, and I also made it clear that I felt that there should be a fair tendering system.

ANSWER.PARA: In my communications with the Department, those three factors have been known from the start and they have driven me. On those three grounds, the outcome of this process vindicates the position that I took. Any inference that Senator Parer would like to build on a platform of sand just will not hold up.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister saying that what he said in his letter of 4 March, that is, that it would seem that Nashua has unfortunately hurt its own case by not submitting its best price at the time of the tender, is incorrect?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I am saying is that the Opposition can selectively choose one line out of one document that it has selectively leaked. What I said in my answer to Senator Parer initially was that the motivations were threefold, and they were communicated. One aspect of those motivations was cost but I go back to this particular point in terms of Nashua. Its first price on an item which constituted an important part of the overall contract panel therefore was some 35 per cent cheaper than an item which was included at that time from another company.

ANSWER.PARA: The question of price was raised early in the piece but the question of price was raised in comparing Nashua both in terms of those that were cheaper than it and in terms of those that were more expensive. The basic fact that did concern me was that we should get the best value for money for the taxpayer and that Australian suppliers should not be unfairly excluded. Those views were made clear at the start. However, Opposition senators will not accept that I have been driven by those considerations from the start. They think that I would behave like their mates in Queensland, and I would not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce outline whether the reductions in tariffs necessary for Australia to accede to the Florence agreement and its Nairobi protocol will have any harmful effects on Australian manufacturers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer is that one hopes not but there is a longer answer than that. Many items under the terms of the Florence agreement, which is an international treaty of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation, with 70 signatories, have no tariffs imposed on them. They include exercise books, works of art, goods designed for people with disabilities, films and slides, scientific instruments, educational aids of one kind or another and so on.

ANSWER.PARA: More than 80 per cent by value of these items already enter Australia duty free so there will be no negative effects on local industry. The Australian Scientific Industry Association has supported the proposals as accession to the agreement would result in the removal of 50 per cent tariff barriers to the Thailand market. Some companies seeking business in Thailand have been told that, if Australia accedes to the Florence agreement, that tariff will no longer apply.

Under the terms of the Florence agreement the Government will reduce tariffs on prerecorded audio and video tapes from 17 per cent to zero. The Government has resisted pressure to abandon its agreed program of tariff reductions for blank audio and video cassettes and computer diskettes. There was concern that immediate removal of these tariffs would damage some local manufacturers of these products.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the percentage of manufacturing?

—Twenty-five per cent, I think. Given the manner in which these local businesses are already coping with progressive tariff reductions and their increasing export focus, it is my belief that these manufacturers will become stronger competitors in the regional market.

ANSWER.PARA: I must say as Minister that I am therefore very disappointed to learn that some of the multinational record companies, which originally pushed for the immediate removal of tariffs on blank media, have punished one local manufacturer by withdrawing their orders. The manufacturer was one of those who expressed concerns about the harm that immediate tariff reductions might cause, contrary to the record companies' stance. I must say that, if this is the manner in which multinational recording companies treat local suppliers, I cannot see them winning much sympathy from the Government in other matters which affect them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The Government has allowed seven years for the disposal of the wool stockpile. If at that point proceeds from the stockpile are insufficient to meet Government guaranteed loans and other sums being advanced to the industry by the Government, is it the intention of the Government to leave the 15 per cent levy in place until all moneys are repaid? Has the Government calculated the additional numbers of growers forced into bankruptcy by the imposition of a levy considerably higher than the maximum recommended by the Vines committee?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The operational plans of the Wool Realisation Commission will be reviewed, as we have announced, every 12 months. So the tax rate needed to enable the wool industry to settle its debts will, of course, be reviewed then also. I understand that our current expectation is that, based on the debt reduction schedule and a 15 per cent tax rate, the industry will be able to trade its way out in the seven-year period.

ANSWER.PARA: We are confident that the Wool Realisation Commission will be able under its operating guidelines to dispose of its wool stockpile in the seven-year period without a residual debt. The imposition of a 15 per cent tax rate, rather than the 12 per cent recommended by the Vines committee, will result in a tax higher by hundreds rather than thousands of dollars. At a time when growers will already be experiencing very tight incomes, our view would be that a few hundred dollars extra will not be the decider in terms of bankruptcies, as the honourable senator's question implies. The difference between a 12 per cent and a 15 per cent levy on growers' viability is also, in our view, insignificant in comparison--

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask Opposition senators to wait for the sentence to be completed before they draw a conclusion.
—You are insignificant.

—I may well be insignificant in the honourable senator's eyes but that is a fault in his perception, not a fault of reality. Mr President, let me complete the sentence if I may, before Opposition senators draw an erroneous conclusion, for I would not like them to draw a wrong conclusion and be humiliated when that is revealed in public. The difference between the 12 per cent and the 15 per cent levy on growers' viability is insignificant in comparison with the impact on their operations of the other variables that affect their well-being.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for his answer, but it was a little convoluted. Can he tell me whether, if at the end of seven years there is money owing or money not paid to the Government, that tax will run on-yes or no?

—At this point we are saying that the scheme is to be reviewed every year. The expectation is that it can be cleared within seven years. If, when we come closer to the end of the expiry time, another judgment arises, it will then arise in the circumstances of the day. The honourable senator is inviting me to speculate as to what will happen if the assumptions upon which this decision has been made are wrong. I think it would be idle of me to do that, given that we think the assumptions are right.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, and it concerns Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) funding. I refer the Minister to an article by Tom Burton in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald in which it is alleged that the Government is going to cut the ABC's funding by $16m, on a base which has already been severely eroded over the last three years. I ask the Minister whether he can confirm this report, and in general terms I ask: how can the Government justify not giving a funding increase, or at least bringing funding into line with inflation, given the very high performance and productivity levels of the ABC as measured against commercial alternatives?

—I am aware of the press article. I read it. It is pure speculation. I do know that the Minister for Transport and Communications has conducted discussions in a general sense with both the ABC and the unions representing the workers of the ABC about funding for the ABC. The question of funding for the ABC is a matter that will be considered by Cabinet in the near future.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. The Minister would be aware that a census is to be held on 6 August 1991. Is it a fact that at the last census a respondent could not claim to have worked more than 49 hours in a week? If that is so, will that restriction apply to the new census?
—There is one good reason why I do not know: it is not in my portfolio.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Given the fact that the Government has had over a decade's notice, can the Minister inform the Senate how much longer the old Parliament House will lie idle and empty to the public?

—The Government announced some 18 months ago that the old Parliament House would be used as a constitutional museum. In the last Budget process, some money was allocated towards the design work to be developed in the initial stages for that. Any further consideration and financing for the building will be considered during the next Budget process.

—Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware of the infestation of ringspot which currently threatens to destroy the Australian papaw industry? Has any consideration been given by the Minister or by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) to a breeding or genetic engineering program to produce edible papaws which are resistant to ringspot? If no consideration has yet been given to the problem, will the Minister kindly undertake to do so for the sake of the Australian industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really do not know why Senator O'Chee always roughs me up with bananas, papaws, sugar-all these things. Pineapples will be next-no, Senator Boswell is pineapples. But I really get a sort of fruit salad of questions from these fruits over here. I am of course aware of ringspot as it has appeared in papaws, because Senator Boswell once mentioned it to me in the passage. The important point about ringspot, as Senator Boswell mentioned to me, is that it has not appeared before in south Queensland. The disease is an insect transmitted virus. There are some sources of resistance to it, but they do not exist in the commercial varieties available in Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: A quarantine zone which has been placed over the south-eastern corner of Queensland has slowed the spread of the disease to other papaw production areas. The papaw industry is seeking research proposals which can begin to address this disease problem. CSIRO and the Queensland Committee of Direction of Fruit Marketing are discussing the possibility of CSIRO carrying out some work on this disease. If CSIRO agrees, its scientists will probably adopt an approach involving molecular biology. This method will equip the papaw with the capability to resist the disease by inserting a reverse copy of the disease organism.

That is the best I can do at the present time. I concede that it was a superficial answer, but as soon as we get some further feedback from CSIRO I will be able to provide Senator O'Chee with something more profound.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support aware that the shadow Minister for waterfront reform has issued a press statement claiming that 300 workers have left the industry while 200 new workers have been recruited, leaving a net reduction of around 100? Are those claims true?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Mr Sharp did issue a press release, I think last night, claiming that. He has kept up his extraordinary duck by getting it profoundly wrong once again. As I have said on previous occasions, Mr Sharp has now developed quite an extraordinary record: he has not issued a single public statement that has been factually correct in respect to the waterfront-not one. The inaccuracies in his statements are so great that it is very difficult to understand why he continues to do it. As I said before, he should be prepared either to do the slightest bit of homework or, if he cannot, to employ at least a research officer or a member of his staff who can.

ANSWER.PARA: The statement made by Mr Sharp is absolutely wrong. It is not 300 workers that have left the industry since the reform program started; around 1,200 have actually left the industry. The facts are that 360-odd have left National Terminals (Australia) Ltd under the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority program; that 310 gangway watchmen have left the industry under the WIRA program; and that some 600 workers have left the industry over the same period of time by natural attrition-that is, by using the voluntary redundancy programs that have existed in the industry for many years.

Some 265 workers have been recruited under the WIRA program; some 1,000 are required to be recruited, but they are recruited on the basis that the workers who are being retired are those whom the Inter-State Commission quite sensibly found should be aged 55 and above. The new workers who are being recruited into the industry must be 30 years of age or younger. Therefore, once again Mr Sharp has got it absolutely wrong. The figure of those having left the industry is not 300 but 1,200.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Administrative Services tell the Senate why the Commonwealth is constructing a new office block at Woden town centre, an area already oversupplied with office space? Why is it not being built in the Tuggeranong town centre, an area which needs an economic boost? Did the Minister consult with any of the four Federal members in the Australian Capital Territory as to where would be the most appropriate place to site this building?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have some information for Senator Reid on this matter. The short history is that expressions of interest have been called by the Department in relation to a proposed new office development in Woden. Media reports have mentioned the Australian Patent Trade Marks and Designs Office as a potential occupant. While this is valid, a number of potential Commonwealth tenants are being considered. The expressions of interest are seeking initial private sector response to the possible development and subsequent leasing to the Commonwealth of approximately 20,000 square metres of office space on block 1, section 4, Phillip.

ANSWER.PARA: My Department advises that this is simply testing market reactions to the proposal. At this stage no decision has been made to enter into any firm agreement for additional accommodation in Woden arising from this proposal. In fact, 1991 is shaping up to be the worst year for the automotive industry in this country for many decades.

. . . but whether this projection is realised will depend on the strategies adopted by Plan producers in response to the Government's announced policy for the industry through to the year 2000.

That policy announcement, which was part of the Government's industry statement in March, was of considerable concern to the industry. The process of continual tariff reduction through to the year 2000 was announced. That was not a decision with which the Opposition disagreed. The problem with the decision was that it looked at just one side of the coin in relation to the package of measures that are required to be put in place if the industry is, as we all wish, to be profitable and thriving, albeit subject obviously to structural change that will be required over the next 10 years.

I turn to the issue of the economic potential of Coronation Hill. It is important not to assess only the figures plucked out of the air or even used by Mr Justice Stewart. It does not take into account the wide effects this would have on an ongoing basis in so many other areas to do with the Northern Territory economy. In fact, it has been estimated by the Northern Territory Treasurer, the Honourable Barry Coulter, that the value of the minerals known to exist at Coronation Hill is about $500m at today's value.

There are also many other opportunities in this area for our overseas debt to be addressed. The economic potential flows right through the Northern Territory and national economies, and we cannot walk away from that. The benefits of salaries and other expenditures would flow through to the Northern Territory Government and to the Commonwealth Government and, of course, to all of the areas of significant infrastructure.

The very important issue that we must always address is that in today's society Aboriginal people must be given full and equal opportunity to participate in all of the major and significant development projects that are under way.

We need to recognise that often the underlying factor with Aboriginal people is their fear of having to address the social consequences of change in the economy. Over the years, Aborigines at Gove, Groote Eylandt and Ranger in the Northern Territory have successfully reconciled mining with their spirituality. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Kakadu conservation zone inquiry final report, volumes I and II and the associated report to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on the Kakadu conservation zone, to which Senator Tambling has referred, are very important reports. They are important not only in terms of the Kakadu area but also in terms of the much wider implications for the question of mining in national parks and mining associated with national parks.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) last week said rather coyly that while he was opposed to mining in national parks, he felt that the solution to the problem was simply to excise those areas that are highly prospective or exploitative from the national parks and then to proceed to mine them outside the parks. That would eventually produce a series of national parks rather like a Swiss cheese.

A number of quite important considerations arise in relation to the question of the values of national parks. Senator Tambling just mentioned that there would be an economic benefit of $82m from mining this particular national park. It is a totally false analysis to say that one becomes wealthy by mining a mineral resource. That observation is made because the method of accounting which we use does not take account of resources in situ. When we mine a resource, we simply take the resource out of the ground and we turn into cash what is a capital asset. Once it is mined, it has gone. As Amery Loven said many years ago, `You do not develop a bank account by taking money out of it'. Nor do we become wealthy by mining; we become wealthy by the extent to which we value-add to the minerals which we get out of the ground. If we simply mine them and export them, we do not become wealthy.

In terms of the stated urgency of Australia's present indebtedness, I simply observe that we have been mining extensively in this country for well over 150 years and we are in dire financial straits with massive national debts; whereas a country such as Japan, with essentially no in situ mineral resources is regarded, by ordinary standards, as a wealthy nation.

Let us dispose of this nonsense that we become wealthy by mining our capital assets, exploiting them and simply wasting them. I draw attention to a letter which I received on 10 May from the Executive Director of the Australian Mining Industry Council, Mr Lauchlan McIntosh, in answer to a letter from me, in which he says:
I am concerned that you consider that minerals are non-renewable. This is not the case . . . .

If that is not the case-and I have taken up this matter subsequently with Mr McIntosh-and if in a finite world resources are infinitely available, I put to Mr McIntosh that resources are therefore logically infinitely available from any part of that finite resource, and he agreed. The question then arises: why do we need to mine in national parks? Clearly, under such logic it is possible to go and mine somewhere else.

The situation in relation to sustainability becomes even more urgent when one observes that if, with only about 5 per cent of Australia's land area in national parks and with less than 200 years of exploitation, it is now necessary to go into that last 5 per cent to exploit those resources, we should be thinking very carefully about whether our civilisation is sustainable at all. Quite clearly it is not. Moreover, if that 5 per cent is the only bit that we have left, we are not going to survive very long as a civilisation if that is the bit that we need to go in and exploit right now. The whole question of mining in Kakadu National Park raises some much wider issues. These are the issues that need to be thought about very carefully when the Government makes its decision in this particular case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that, in the eyes of the environmental movement, Coronation Hill and conservation zone should become a part of the wider protected area, a large part of which already has World Heritage status. As the Resource Assessment Commission (RAC) report points out in the executive summary:

SPEECH.PARA: The dilemma facing the Australian Government is clear: should it set aside the environmental risks that cannot be eliminated, and the strong views held by the Aboriginal people responsible for the Conservation Zone, in favour of securing increases in national income of the order that seems likely from the Coronation Hill project and possibly from other mineral resources in the Zone?

It is a hard question. However, as the former Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, stated in September 1989 when he was hell-bent on wooing green preferences, we need to get away from the mentality that we rely on Australia as a quarry. He was referring then to Kakadu as one of the potential quarries as the Coronation Hill issue was being hotly debated.

That is precisely the point. When the financial pressure is on, it is not sound economical or ecological management to rely on exploiting natural resources in the short term as an export oriented buffer against the recession. The Government failed the first test by allowing resource guarantees to be introduced so that Australia's native hardwood forests would continue to be used for the production of woodchips to feed pulp mills, largely overseas.

The Coronation Hill decision will be the second litmus test for the Hawke Government. It faces the clearly stated opposition of both conservationists and Aborigines to a decision to mine. The decision will also be seen in the wider context of the Australian Government's support or lack of support for Aboriginal claims when they conflict with mining interests.

The Government response to the RAC report on the Kakadu conservation zone will also reveal what weight the Government affords its own Resource Assessment Commission and environmentally sustainable development processes. Is it any wonder that people are seriously questioning the value of a lengthy process of working groups, submissions and public consultation when decisions such as the enactment of the resource security legislation cut across the whole concept of ecologically sustainable development in the face of widespread community opposition?

The conservation movement can only hope that this economic and political expediency is not pursued over Coronation Hill. There is too much at stake in terms of the biological data in the area which has not yet been identified, and because of the immense cultural and religious meaning the area has to the Jawoyn people. The resources of the Kakadu conservation zone, including the vital catchment area of the South Alligator River, which needs to be protected as a whole, as an integral system, are not expendable because of their intrinsic conservation and cultural values. I hope that the Federal Government will concur with this position and make the right decision not to go ahead with mining.

But most of all, this decision will represent the potential reinforcement or destruction of community belief in the whole process of national park preservation which has been callously disregarded recently in Western Australia, with mining being allowed in three national parks under the leadership of Premier Carmen Lawrence. With a national park there can be no trade-offs to allow mining to go ahead, because the conservation movement believes that the integrity of the whole area is at stake in the ecological context.
According to the International Union for the Conservation of Nature, as the report points out, a national park is:

. . . an outstanding natural area managed by a nationally recognised authority to protect the ecological integrity of one or more ecosystems for this and future generations and, to eliminate the exploitation or intensive occupation of the area and to provide a foundation for spiritual, scientific, educational and ecotourism opportunities . . .
That is what national parks are meant to be all about.

The first report I have just tabled deals with Stage 1 of the redevelopment of the Singleton Military Area in New South Wales. The limit-of-cost estimate for the work is $29.3 million at November 1990 prices.

* living facilities for 198 staff and 552 students
* working facilities for Depot Company Headquarters
* redevelopment of roads and provision of car parking
* construction of new Range Control buildings
* extension of area engineering services
* site works
* furniture and fittings
The Singleton Military Area was acquired during the Second World War and some facilities from that time are still in use. Temporary facilities were constructed in 1965.

The works recommended by the Committee form Stage 1 of a plan to redevelop the whole Singleton Military Area. It is currently Army's highest priority because of the emphasis on improving living-in accommodation for all personnel.

* construction and extension of living and working accommodation
* upgrading the sewerage system and the water supply
* upgrading of the railway siding.

Army's wholesale ammunition holdings are stored in five depots in eastern Australia. These were established in the Second World War. Many of the explosives storehouses are not suitable for the storage of the most hazardous types of ammunition in accordance with the United Nations/North Atlantic Treaty Organisation principles. Many of the living and working facilities are inadequate and constitute a repair and maintenance liability.

Studies recommended that, in the medium terms, Army reduce its national wholesale depots from five to two; Myambat and Wallangarra in Queensland. The Committee is concerned about this decision because Myambat is in a relatively isolated location. It believes there should be a study of the costs and benefits of retaining Wallangarra as a second national wholesale depot, and that it should receive a copy of the results of this study.

The Committee was told that energy consumption for the proposed buildings will not be great compared with many military establishments. I have already referred, in my comments on the Singleton report, to the Committee's belief it should receive copies of the analyses of energy usage on all projects referred to it. The same recommendation has been made in the report on Myambat.

The Committee noted the work done by Army personnel at Myambat to sustain a good relationship with the local community. It believes it would be worthwhile to hold another public meeting to explain all the impacts the proposed works will have on that community.

Rosemount Estates winery raised a number of concerns with the Committee, including the inclusion of land in the safety arc from the depot, the adverse impact of the destruction of explosives, the location of the sewerage plant and fires being started in the depot. Defence will advise Rosemount of the results of computer modelling which will determine the location of the safety arc; it has also ceased demolishing the explosives causing Rosemount problems. The Committee is satisfied that the sewerage plant is in a suitable location. While there have been fires in the past, depot staff take appropriate measures to reduce their causes and deal effectively with those which start. Nevertheless, the Committee has recommended Defence continue to resolve outstanding issues with the winery.

Works in this project will provide the most urgently needed facilities and engineering services. The project has been divided into two phases and a further stage will be undertaken, when funding is available, to complete the redevelopment of Myambat.
The Committee would like to thank personnel at Myambat for the work which went in to the visit on 30 January 1991.
I commend both reports to the Senate.
