TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Albury-Wodonga Development Amendment Bill 1991 is to place a chief executive officer on the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation and to give effect to an agreement between the Commonwealth, New South Wales and Victoria. This Bill gives effect to aspects of a range of reforms to the Albury-Wodonga project agreed amongst the Commonwealth, New South Wales and Victorian governments as partners in this joint project. As we know, the genesis of this project was during the time of the Whitlam Administration, and Minister Uren was closely associated with the policies developed with regard to a cities commission and a different policy period relating to urban and regional development in Australia. Most of the Bill is devoted to amending the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation's membership. It introduces arrangements to separate the responsibilities of the board and the staff. The Bill replaces the full time chairperson and two deputy chairperson positions with part time equivalents, and transfers responsibility for day-to-day management to the Corporation's most senior staff member.

SPEECH.PARA: Local government representation on the Corporation is changed from being the mayors of Albury-Wodonga to a representative of each of the councils. The amendments will enable the Commonwealth and State Albury-Wodonga corporations to produce one annual report instead of three-one for each government. Provision is being made for Corporation staff to have reciprocal mobility rights within the Australian Public Service and other statutory authorities. It was on 23 October 1973 that the then Prime Minister and Premiers of New South Wales and Victoria signed the Albury-Wodonga area development agreement. The objectives of the agreement are contained in the preamble, which states:

. . . the intention of the three Governments are-that a development Corporation will bring about in the Area (Albury-Wodonga), by the development of a growth complex, the creation of a city with a high quality of environment, appropriately planned and developed having full regard to human requirements and the involvement of the public; and that the development corporation, will involve, as far as possible, the established Australian, State and local government authorities in the development of the growth complex.

The development of Albury-Wodonga was an element of the Whitlam Government's decentralisation policy. On 21 January 1974, the Albury-Wodonga Area Development Act 1973, the principal Act, which gave effect at Commonwealth law to the agreement, was proclaimed. Complementary State legislation established separate New South Wales and Victorian development corporations. The three corporations act as one integrated Corporation.

The Corporation is responsible to the Ministerial Council on the Development of Albury-Wodonga, which comprises the Commonwealth Minister responsible for local government, the New South Wales Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, and the Victorian Minister for Industry and Economic Planning. The main function of the Ministerial Council is to supervise the development of Albury-Wodonga. In addition, the Ministerial Council has the power to give direction to the Corporation on how it performs its functions. The functions of the Corporation include: to carry out and supervise certain development works; to negotiate with Commonwealth, State and local government authorities for the purpose of arranging or providing services and facilities to Albury-Wodonga; and to create job opportunities by encouraging the setting up of industries and other investment in Albury-Wodonga.

In 1988 the Ministerial Council established a review committee to examine and report on the role and structure of the Corporation, as it was then some 15 years after the initial establishment. The report of the review committee, which was presented to the Ministerial Council in 1989 and approved by the Ministerial Council on 8 June of that year, is the origin of the amendments proposed in this Bill. Included are the following proposals:

- in the next 12 months the corporation should undergo a period of change, on the basis of a revised mission statement which would be to facilitate the continuing growth of Albury-Wodonga in cooperation with Commonwealth, State and local government and community agencies;

- the Corporation's new goals would be to: contribute to the physical, economic and social planning in Albury-Wodonga, in partnership with local government and the community; promote Albury-Wodonga in cooperation with appropriate agencies; and to develop and market corporation land holdings;
- that an Albury-Wodonga Region Planning Committee . . . be established to overview and coordinate the preparation of a regional plan covering physical and social planning in Albury-Wodonga;

- that the committee review the physical plan of Albury-Wodonga and once agreement has been reached on revisions to the plan, amendments to the legislation and planning be arranged and the Corporation relinquish its local planning powers;
* the social service program delivery become the responsibility of local government and the community.
* that the financial operations of the Corporation be improved through the adoption of more commercial practises; and

* that the membership of the corporation be restructured to comprise a part-time Chairperson nominated by the Commonwealth, two part-time State nominated Deputy chairpersons and two regional members, one from each State, agreed by the Commonwealth and States.

The Government has been particularly tardy in relation to this particular piece of legislation. As I mentioned, the Ministerial Council gave approval and direction back in 1989. In effect, these amendments, which are now validating the operations of the Corporation, are arrangements that have been in place and operating since October 1990. There is also a degree of concern about the lack of Ministerial Council meetings, which average less than one a year. That is an issue which should be addressed.

We saw that in the House of Representatives the Government also had to propose a number of minor amendments to the Bill that it put forward to the Parliament, even after such considerable time lags, delays and frustration. These amendments, introduced into the House of Representatives by the Government and now incorporated in the Bill that we are looking at here, were for the purpose of interpreting and possessing powers under the New South Wales planning legislation; a matter that had been requested by the New South Wales Government.

The other amendments that Ms Fatin introduced were to deal with the commencement of the Albury-Wodonga development agreement amendment agreement (No. 2). The Bill was initially drafted on the basis that the amendment agreement would be approved and executed prior to receiving royal assent. Any inconsistencies in the commencement of the Bill and this amendment agreement were also removed at that point. The final amendments that the House of Representatives dealt with were correcting the different use of wording in a range of areas.

Much has changed in regional parts of Australia since the Whitlam Administration. I am sure we would all acknowledge that not only have there been trends throughout the world with regard to regional development and regional policies in many countries but also, as technology has improved, the relationships and sociology of so many areas have also changed. We must continually address these issues.

I note that the Government has recently released an information book entitled The Rural Book, a 1991 edition, which the Government claims to be part of the country link program. That book is listed as a guide to major Commonwealth services and programs for people who live away from the capital cities.

It is an indictment of the Government that such a hodgepodge of policies and issues has had to be pulled together in such a difficult and different form to enable people who live in regional and remote parts of Australia-areas such as Albury-Wodonga-to come to grips with the policies of this Government, which are so loose, so unstructured and so uncoordinated. It now has to issue guidelines for people as to which programs to look at and how to address the different issues. In looking at that so-called rural book-which the Government is obviously passing out as the new gospel according to Hawke, or probably according to Kerin if it were paid for through his Department-I am concerned that the Government has moved away from decent, proper coordinated policies that recognise the priorities of remote and rural Australia and has not been able to address so many issues that require policy assistance and policy help.

I am sure that any of us who represent rural and remote parts of Australia will also be well aware that the Government's mismanagement not only of the economy but also of all the social programs impacts very dramatically on the lifestyles, the budgets and the future opportunities of young people and the future generations as to where their employment opportunities will be. The fact that we are now moving to a stage when it will be necessary to accept that initiatives such as those taken by the Whitlam Government and Mr Uren are no longer relevant, and to address the areas of regional Australia and remote parts of Australia more specifically with regard to business development, social disadvantage and social welfare policies, shows that there has necessarily been a shift in so many programs. What we must ensure is that policies of government in themselves do not act as impediments to other areas of the delivery of government services. We always need to ask government: what are the roadblocks to development, whether it is on a personal level or a community level, that are placed in the way of so many communities throughout Australia?

It is for this reason that the Opposition has very seriously looked at the future of the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation. It is important to flag that there should be a change in the structure and that Albury-Wodonga should be returned to the normal forms of administration and participation in government policies as soon as possible. With that in mind, I have circulated an amendment to add, at the end of the motion for the second reading, that the Senate:
(a) is of the opinion that the functions of the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation be phased out as soon as practicable; and
(b) notes that the Bill does not provide for such cessation.

It is important to recognise that the Commonwealth, the State of New South Wales and the State of Victoria have all a considerable investment in the Albury- Wodonga area. We need to ensure that in the future the Commonwealth, in particular, receives an improved return on the very significant investment that it has made to the Albury-Wodonga project over time. Therefore, the Opposition will support the legislation, and I move:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate:
(a) is of the opinion that the functions of the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation be phased out as soon as practicable; and
(b) notes that the Bill does not provide for such cessation.''

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Tambling has rightly told us, the Whitlam Government's decentralisation policies gave birth to the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation. That Corporation had admirable aims-aims which to a considerable degree have been met or are being met in terms of the growth complex of the area. It is our belief that regionalism must be supported as a concept. This concept deserves support for many reasons, not the least of which are the social, economic, environmental, strategic, community and other advantages which derive from decentralisation.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that at the moment in our society there are also considerable disadvantages which arise from urbanisation. I will not attempt to list them all because I would be here forever, but the ones which we are witnessing more often in our society these days are the urbanisation disadvantages that are manifested in social anonymity, the alienation of people from our society, the tendency for greater crime rates in urbanised areas and the infrastructure problems-especially problems of transport, sewerage and other services.

There is also, of course, the plethora of environmental problems with which we are all too familiar these days. The Australian Democrats would like to see this Government encouraging regional groupings of councils and local government bodies in their cooperation with each other. Such groupings offer citizens a great deal in terms of administrative efficiency. They also offer Australia a great deal in terms of the opportunity to take best advantage of the resources that are offered by this continent. We believe that such an opportunity is not best offered by increasing urbanisation.

We know, for example, of the ridiculous commuter times that are suffered by residents of our major cities and that they are only really an indicator of the inefficiencies of those large cities. There are many other indicators of the ways that large cities alienate their inhabitants. Even within cities that are supposedly well planned, there are examples of compromises in living standards which are caused by the simple fact that cities are too large. Here in Canberra, only last night I heard evidence of considerable public debate about pollution caused by home heating. We often hear even in this city discussion about such matters as waste disposal, water shortages, infill housing, vandalism, transport inefficiency and homelessness-and I could go on.

All those issues sound quite familiar to those of us who live in large cities and they are examples of compromises which are mainly due to the size of urban areas. But I would suggest that regional groupings of councils-the regionalisation of our activities-offers us the opportunity to best use Australia's resources. Regionalisation offers us the opportunity to live in closer harmony with the country. Just as large cities alienate residents, regional centres facilitate practices which are in greater harmony with our environment. Living and working in regional centres, we have a greater opportunity to conduct or reorganise our affairs in a sustainable manner, a manner which can be continued indefinitely.

Let us take as an example waste disposal, particularly sewerage. The present system of reticulated and centralised sewage collection for Sydney cannot be continued indefinitely; it cannot be sustained. The problems with that system are directly related to the size of the collection area. The capacity to develop alternative disposal methods is simply overwhelmed by the sheer volume of matter which is committed to the present disposal methods. It is simply a matter of the inertia of size of the urban area.

We know that this problem is significantly reduced in regional areas. The regional areas of Australia have shown many examples of alternative disposal methods which have been developed, installed and are working successfully. I suggest that regional areas are not subjected to the inertia of size and that this allows greater flexibility in all manner of community enterprises. I refer to recreational facilities, public housing initiatives, and public transport developments. All manner of planning and development initiatives can be undertaken in a flexible manner and can take advantage of new technologies or new techniques of social organisation.

We hear more these days of examples such as neighbourhood houses, community land, shared energy generation facilities, shared domestic child minding facilities, playgrounds, facilities for the elderly and the disabled-any initiatives which might involve a reorganisation of social structures or the geography of a suburb. Any of those initiatives which may require an alternative approach are more easily accommodated within an area which is not committed to existing infrastructure in the same way as are our large urban areas. I suggest that regional centres have a greater flexibility in accommodating such developments.

I am seeking to remind the Senate of a long-standing Democrat philosophy and policy. We support the strengthening of local governments, especially where they are based on community of interest. That community of interest could be defined as a community in geography, a climatic community, a cultural community, a social community, an economic community and so on. We believe that such a bioregional government is logical, sensible, efficient, relevant and most democratic.

There would be some sort of threshold or minimum population size-perhaps an optimum size, and perhaps even a threshold geographical size. I would not attempt to define that here, nor would it be appropriate in this short debate to suggest what that population size should be. I think it is sufficient to say that these are the sorts of issues which are part and parcel of the whole debate about regionalisation. The essence of this is the need that local governments and local communities have for this Commonwealth Government to encourage the process of regional cooperation between local governments. That should be done so that the decentralisation or regionalisation is not typecast by the model which was the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation.

With a considerable degree of agreement we accept the Opposition amendment. Although it adds to the Bill, there is not a great deal of compunction about it. It is noting and forming an opinion, but at least it indicates that the development corporation should not continue indefinitely simply for the sake of continuing the life of a quango when the aims of that authority may be better met by other means. Therefore, we accept and endorse the amendment and support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has been debating the Albury-Wodonga Development Amendment Bill 1991 dealing with one of those attempts of past decades to create a decentralised area within Australia where people could work, live and carry on their commercial trading and their social activities away from the major concentrations of population in the capital cities and major provincial centres of Australia, particularly on the south-east mainland.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard from the Opposition and from Senator Bell representing the Australian Democrats their current view of the worth of a decentralised, regionalised Australia. There is much to be said for those concepts although, having heard Senator Bell waxing lyrical about the wonders of living in small centres of population away from the major urban areas of Australia, I will be heretical for a moment. I could not help thinking of a Woody Allen line when he said, `People say I should enjoy going out and sitting on a mountain top, meditating and enjoying the view. But give me the smell of bitumen any time'. I must confess that I am one of those Woody Allen people. I like big cities. I like plenty of activity and all the advantages that come from being in a city with a population of some millions, with all the excitement that goes with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You rager, you!

—Yes, I am a bit of a rager secretly, but only when I go to Sydney, never in Devonport. Nevertheless, the Albury-Wodonga Development Amendment Bill is an essential part of the Federal Government's recognition of the fact that the original hopes, aspirations and plans for the Albury-Wodonga area have not in the event proved to fulfil those original hopes and aspirations. It has been decided that the corporation should now concentrate on the profitable development and marketing of its landholdings and keep a role in relation to the land use, social planning and economic development of the area, but on the whole hand back to the people electing their local governments the determination of much of the planning of the Albury-Wodonga area, which at present is undertaken by the corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that to use local government bodies answerable to the local electors in this way has many advantages in being responsive to those expressions of local interest and concern so that the physical and social infrastructure-roads, sewerage, open space and so on-can reflect what the people really want rather than what is imposed upon them by those who perhaps have a vision or a view as to what is good for people in a particular local government area. I am told that it is important, nevertheless, that the role of property developer should not be the sole remaining task of the Corporation. Indeed, it ought to take some responsibility for the regional planning in Albury-Wodonga.

Senator Bell said that the Government should encourage processes of regional cooperation between local governments. I believe that in a modified way that is what the Corporation will be asked to do. Rather than imposing its model of regional development on the local government areas, it will be drawing them into a cooperative style of arrangement, and collaboration between the local governments areas will, I am sure, be fostered by the Corporation. It will be its role to encourage those processes that Senator Bell correctly identified as being so important.

It is not as though the old model is being continued. The model is being changed not only to give more responsive democratic local autonomy to the Albury and Wodonga areas, but also to enable the Corporation to encourage regional cooperation. I believe that that is a worthwhile objective, and I believe that that regional planning and expertise should be made available as a service to the people of that area and not taken away from them, as would be the effect of the Opposition amendment if it were ever translated into an amendment which carried real legal force, for example, at the committee stage.

I believe that the Albury-Wodonga Ministerial Council, which is made up of the cooperating governments and, I would imagine, the local governments, too-and I do not know whether Senator Bell has had an opportunity to speak with the mayors of those local government areas-would welcome the continuation of a modified role of the Corporation, as I suggest.

In addition, the continuation of the Corporation's operations will enable the Commonwealth to obtain the best return for its very substantial investment in the area. Some $120m was invested mainly in the 1970s. I believe that it is only proper and part of good policy, in the protection and management of the financial contribution which Australian taxpayers nationwide have made, that there be a mechanism to properly ensure that the assets are managed and perhaps sold or dealt with in a way which enables those Australian taxpayers to get a better return on the considerable investment in the project. Surely, the Corporation has a proper role there.

We believe that for these reasons it would be unwise to set a date for the winding up of the Corporation. We have to see how it works in this modified fashion. I do believe that it has a role to play in the development of this non-metropolitan area of Australia and therefore I commend the Bill for the amendments it does make to the operation of the Corporation.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Tate)-by leave-agreed to:

That Government Business order of the day No. 3, Defence Force Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill and Government Business order of the day No. 4, Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill, be taken together for their remaining stages.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEFENCE FORCE SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991MILITARY SUPERANNUATION AND BENEFITS BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debates resumed from 16 April, on motions by Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Bolkus:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Defence Force Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill is a housekeeping Bill which makes amendments to the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act as a result of the passing of the military superannuation benefits scheme (MSBS) legislation and for that reason I intend to concentrate today on the Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: There has long been a need for a new superannuation scheme for Defence Force personnel, and it has long been recognised by the Opposition. Our defence science and personnel policy, which was released in November 1989, stated that we would ensure that service personnel were not disadvantaged relative to the civilian community in relation to superannuation benefits and that we would address the anomalies that existed at that time. As the military superannuation scheme does address those anomalies, I congratulate the Government for putting our policy initiatives into place.

The defence forces have waited long enough for treatment that is fair and equal to that of the rest the community in relation to superannuation. For too long they have had to put up with an antiquated superannuation scheme, known as the Defence Force retirement and death benefit (DFRDB) scheme, which was introduced back in 1973.

The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) said at a press conference in June last year, when the DFRDB Review Committee Report was released, that the DFRDB was an `illegal scheme in terms of today's superannuation standards'. The DFRDB scheme required a 5.5 per cent compulsory contribution of salary from all Defence Force personnel, but it paid no interest on those contributions. The money was not paid into an earning fund. It was paid directly into Consolidated Revenue.

For those serving for 20 years, the scheme provided a very acceptable indexed pension, and when it was introduced most people served those 20 years. Superannuation then acted as an incentive to stay in the services. However, with today's more mobile work force, coupled with declining standards within the services, people are not staying for 20 years. The DFRDB scheme has not kept up with the times.

A service man or woman leaving the service before 20 years, which is almost always the case for women, receives only his or her own contribution back when he or she leaves. To make matters worse, officers who leave before 20 years of service reduce their lump sum by 3 per cent for every year they leave earlier than the nominal retiring age for rank. This means that they actually retire with less than their own contributions.

Before I deal specifically with the Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill, I would like to speak generally about the direction in which the personnel for whom this military superannuation scheme will be applicable are heading. In just a few weeks, we are told, we will receive a statement from the Government as to the future shape of the Defence Force. The Government, however, is not prepared to take the people or the Parliament of Australia into its confidence to share in the important decision making which is now taking place. It is very important, if any major changes are being made to the defence of Australia, that the trade-offs are well understood by those who are entitled to be defended.

We should be told whether this review is totally budgetary driven. If so, what are we trading off in terms of readiness and capability and for what savings? We need to know how any cuts in personnel are to be achieved-are personnel being made redundant, are they to get golden handshakes or are they simply being wasted out over time? If the latter is the case, what will that mean to the morale of Force personnel if they see the Force dying around their feet? Will the units remaining be fully manned or will they continue, as now, to be seriously undermanned?

Alternatively, is there any real growth contemplated and, if so, to what extent and in what areas? We all remember Dr Dibb and the subsequent White Paper-the Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities-which was predicated upon a real growth of 3 per cent that was never achieved under Mr Beazley. What can we expect under Senator Robert Ray?

Will we continue to pursue a policy of a two-ocean navy? Will we continue to increase our presence in the north? If we intend to do both these things, what will be the increased pressure on the Defence budget for new facilities? What effect on manning levels will this policy have?

Have we re-examined the question of warning time? The debate about warning time has bedevilled defence planning and has directed attention from the main issue-that is, the need to be prepared. Like the boy scouts, our Defence Force has to be prepared. It needs to be ready to go and it needs to be able to be sustained.

I remind the Senate of the speedy response which Australia gave to the need for ships in the Gulf. But those ships had to be equipped with weapons systems and communications systems on their way to the Gulf. Not only is that not desirable but also it meant that 19 and 20 years old young men who had not been in the service for long suddenly had to turn around, on their way to war-or the possibility of war-and train on new equipment of which they had no experience. That is no way to send people to war. Unfortunately, it is exactly the situation which occurred at the beginning of the Second World War when we sent men to the Middle East without sufficient ammunition and inadequate training. Surely this country has learned from that. We could only send two ships. The choice was to send four ships straight away and have nothing to replace them with or to send two ships which could be rotated with another two for as long as necessary.

That is exactly the situation we face with the use of infantry battalions. We must have sufficient battalions in order to sustain a force in the field. Contrary to what is widely believed, a low level contingency, which is what we are told is the most likely situation that we will have to face, is extremely labour intensive. A low level of contingency does not mean that a low level of commitment is needed. Such a commitment is heavily labour intensive, particularly in a country as vast as Australia, with so many areas that need defending in the north.

It appears from selective leaking by the Minister to certain journalists that we are to become more dependent upon our reserves. If that is so, how can that not be at the expense of our readiness? What effect will that have on our readiness? What saving, if any, does the Government expect to make by this action? The Auditor-General's report, which we received only a few months ago, gave an indication that the reserves option could well be a more expensive one-up to 50 per cent more expensive. From what we have been able to learn to date, the ready reserve proposal, which has been floating around Canberra over recent months, appears to entail large costs in the areas of recruitment and incentive measures.

Other questions need to be asked if we intend to place a higher and heavy reliance on reserves. What impact will this have on the remaining regulars if we have to provide substantial cadre forces and extra training personnel to cope with the intake of ready reserves? What effect will those considerations have on the readiness of the remaining regulars? Will we been getting rid of the limitations on our ability to call out the reserves? Surely that is a critical matter in assessing the effect on the readiness of a substantial reserve force.

We will also be looking to see whether there will be reductions on training, exercise time, flying hours, fuel costs et cetera. All of those things affect our readiness. We shall be waiting to see whether there will be cutbacks to planned capital expenditure. Will we be able to improve our surveillance ability, our mine countermeasures, the mobility, the night vision or the communications for our army? Once again, cutbacks in these areas would clearly mean a reduction in our capability.

Will we be able to maintain our commitment to the United Nations peacekeeping forces which has been such a feature of Defence Force service in recent years? The Federal Government is continually talking about the need to commit peacekeeping forces to Cambodia in due course. We have just despatched another 70 people, on humanitarian assistance grounds, to the Gulf. But we have already disbanded one engineer squadron. Will we maintain a substantial engineering capability in the future? What impact will the review have on our defence cooperation projects in our region and our ability to assist our neighbours?

The Opposition shall be awaiting the Minister's announcement with enormous interest and concern. The most important resource our Defence Force has in its arsenal is its people; and their training and retention is of paramount importance in any plan for the defence of Australia.

It is in this context that we welcome the new superannuation scheme which will go some way towards giving Defence Force personnel a better deal. The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) said in the House of Representatives that I would speak about the details of the scheme. I intend to do so. However, the complexity of superannuation is not something that can be easily dealt with in the confines of a speech. For that reason, I intend to cover the Bill in a less detailed manner than might otherwise be the case.

Like other Commonwealth schemes, the MSBS will be established through a trust deed and an enabling Act managed through the Retirement Benefits Office. The MSBS meets all of the occupational superannuation standards. By all accounts, it is a good scheme on a par with the new public sector scheme. It provides for existing serving Defence Force members to transfer to MSBS, with attractive transfer rates, and it provides the option to take a lump sum or pension on retirement. The reversionary and invalidity benefits provided by the scheme are also generous and equate with the public sector scheme. The MSBS, DFRBD and the earlier Defence Force Retirement Benefits (DFRB) scheme will all run alongside each other as separate superannuation schemes. However, the DFRDB will no longer accept new members, as was the case with the DFRB when the DFRDB was introduced.

The MSBS is made up of two components: first, the superannuation benefit and, secondly, the retention benefit. The MSBS is a split benefit scheme comprising an unfunded defined employer benefit and a non-defined funded benefit incorporating a member's contributions and a 3 per cent industrial award. The member contributes a compulsory 5 per cent of salary and can voluntarily contribute up to an additional 5 per cent in increments of one per cent, so long as a period of three months elapses between varying the contribution rate. These contributions, plus the Government's 3 per cent industrial award, will be lodged with the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust, as funds manager.

The funded member contributions may be accessed or preserved on resignation. If they are accessed, they are paid to the member as an eligible term payment and may be spent or preserved in a roll-over fund. They can also be preserved in the MSBS fund, where the value of the benefit is linked to the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust earning rate. The 3 per cent funded productivity award is preserved until age 55, as is the unfunded employer benefit.

The employer benefit is a defined benefit based on length of service and final average salary over the three years preceding resignation. So the serving member knows now what he or she will be eligible for. For those who opt to transfer from DFRDB to MSBS, all time spent as a DFRDB member, which is since enlistment, is credited at notional value to the member's MSBS account based on the long term bond rate phased in over two years. This means that if, for example, a sergeant who has now had 12 years service decides to leave the service, he will receive approximately $11,500 DFRDB contributions-and that is all, after 12 years of service. But if the same sergeant elects to transfer from DFRDB to MSBS, his MSBS account will be credited with approximately $22,000; that is, $11,500 DFRDB contributions and $11,100 interest on those contributions over 12 years. This is the member contribution and it will increase as the sergeant continues to make contributions while he or she is in the service. At that same 12-year mark, if the sergeant is transferred to MSBS, he or she is also entitled to receive approximately $48,000 in employer benefits when he or she reaches age 55. This will also grow as the sergeant continues to be employed.

The 3 per cent productivity award is also part of the member contribution and grows in the same fund but, like the employer contribution, it is not available until age 55. There is a big difference between the sergeant leaving at the 12-year mark under DFRDB with a $11,500 return and under MSBS a possible $70,000 return, albeit some of it at age 55. It is therefore easy to see that it is most important for all defence personnel to make sure that they carefully weigh up their options when deciding whether to transfer. It is quite clear from the different constituents who have come to my office that the different situations of different people require very careful consideration. These people require a great deal of help in making a decision as to what is in their best interests.

MSBS looks good for the sergeant in our example, but it may not be if he or she plans to stay in for 20 years and take a fully indexed pension for life. Every case is different and defence personnel must make their decisions wisely. It is very important that all Defence Force members receive individual consultation and help in what is the best for them for their future regarding the transfer option. I say this because it has been brought to my attention that some defence personnel, although they claim to have had consultation, do not know about the entitlement to employer contributions if they transfer to MSBS and then leave within two years. There is a phasing-in period of two years for the member contributions but not for the employer benefits. This misunderstanding could mean the difference of many of thousands of dollars in future benefits.

Cost estimates for the DFRDB and the MSBS have been prepared by the Australian Government Actuary in consultation with consultant actuaries. Overall, we are told that the MSBS will result in long term savings to the Government. There are costs associated with the introduction of the scheme in the short and medium terms. These result mainly from the funding of MSBS member contributions, but also from the funding of the 3 per cent productivity benefit; the provision of a retention benefit; the credit of notional interest to the DFRDB contributions of members transferring to MSBS; increased administrative costs during the initial MSBS implementation period; the change in the form of the primary superannuation benefit from a pension in the DFRDB to a predominantly lump sum in the MSBS; and the deferral of payment of the MSBS employer-financed superannuation benefit until members reach 55 years of age.

The estimated net impact of the introduction of MSBS on annual budgetary outlays for Defence Force superannuation during the transitional period-1991-92 to 1994-95-ranges from $151m to $209m. Budgetary savings are expected to commence in about 35 years from now. The expected net annual savings will be 2.8 per cent of future salaries of new entrants to the scheme. Savings are also expected to emerge from existing DFRDB scheme members who transfer to the new scheme equivalent to $690m in net present value terms. The actuaries have forecast that the expected net long term employer costs, after tax and social security clawbacks, for current members who join the scheme will be less than the projected long term employer costs of the old scheme for these members if they remain in the DFRDB.

The actuaries also expect a 10 per cent increase in retention. This leads to me to the final part of my speech-that is, the retention benefit. I have saved this for last because it is interesting that the Government has had to include a retention benefit in a superannuation scheme. The retention benefit component of the scheme seems a bit out of place in the structure of most superannuation schemes, private and public. But for some time the Opposition has recognised that retention is a serious problem, and a problem that is still very real despite the fact that there has been something of a reduction because of people getting out of the Defence Force prematurely.

As part of our defence science and personnel policy we stated that we would provide early access for selected personnel to limited lump sum benefits by way of an advance against the final retirement benefits during the service career. It was intended to use this procedure to retain those personnel at senior non-commissioned officer and middle ranking officer level whose experience and training were particularly important to retain the 20-year mark. We recognise the retention problem caused by the Government's mismanagement. It is good to see that the Government has now finally recognised the appalling situation created during its eight years in government. The Government has seen it as a way of arresting the high wastage rate it has brought about during those years in government. That is the only reason it is needed. Twenty-six per cent of the Force has been lost over the last two years. When this Government came to office in 1983 the total strength was 71,641. December 1990 had the figure down to as low as 67,469.

Wastage from the defence forces is not only a capability problem, as I said earlier; it is also one of cost. The extra training costs required to train new people to replace those that leave is quite substantial. It has been estimated that it would cost about $53m to get the Army wastage alone back to where it was before the increased wastage rates occurred.

It is only because the Government got the defence forces in this mess in the first place that it has needed to adopt a retention benefit. The retention benefit consists of one year's salary, taxed, and paid to the member at the 15-year service point in order to retain that member to the 20-year mark. The benefit is optional but if it is taken it contracts the serviceman for a further five years of service. If the contract is broken for other than invalidity, a clawback prevails on a pro rata basis. The tax advantages of the clawback are such that members would need to consider carefully whether they should break the contract. Assuming a member had a salary of $40,000 and elected to take the retention benefit, the after-tax payment would be in excess of $20,000. Subsequent resignation after contract commencement would lead to the respective clawback of $32,000 after one year and $16,000 after three years.

The Australian Democrats have several amendments to this legislation, one of which relates to the changing of the retention benefit from a lump sum retention benefit to a yearly retention benefit in order to escape a higher tax bracket. We are concerned that this may defeat the purpose of a retention benefit. Without the clawback or disincentive to not leave, the benefit may not act as a retention benefit. That is one of the reasons we will shortly move to refer this legislation to a standing committee for further investigation. The Democrats are also planning to move amendments to the Superannuation Act. I understood that my colleague Senator Short would be speaking about that aspect. I am not sure whether he will be speaking during the second reading debate.

As I said, the Opposition is planning to refer the Bill to a committee for further scrutiny. Concerns have also been raised by the Regular Defence Force Welfare Association, which has not had an opportunity to be tested by the questioning of officials. We in the Opposition believe that it is an appropriate place to have some quite serious matters looked at in greater detail.

Several months ago, before this legislation came before the House, I wrote to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) and drew his attention to the fact that this legislation would be very complex and that it would need a great deal of careful scrutiny if we were to avoid the situation which occurred with the new Commonwealth scheme, where a number of anomalies were found after the legislation was passed which may need subsequent amendment. In order to have the opportunity for close scrutiny by the Parliament, interested welfare groups and service men and women themselves, I asked the Minister whether he would be prepared to lay this legislation on the table for some months before it was taken through the Houses of the Parliament. The Minister did not see fit to take that course of action, which at the very least was a pity. Some legislation benefits greatly from having a longer time in the public arena. In that this legislation has not been given treatment, in that it is of such great importance to Defence Force personnel and in that it has a great impact on the morale of the Force and thereby to retention, we in the Opposition believe that it is appropriate that it be referred to a Senate standing committee.

I draw your attention, Mr Deputy President, to the fact that the amendments which are being proposed by the Australian Democrats raise matters that require detailed assessment in financial terms-for example, their effect on budgetary and taxation matters. It is for those reasons that we in the Opposition believe that the appropriate committee would be the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. In that way people with expertise in tax and public finance will have the opportunity to give the legislation the sort of scrutiny that it requires.

I believe that the Government has some view that it would more appropriately go to the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. Although this is a Bill relating to the defence portfolio, the matters which require further scrutiny at the committee stage are not truly matters directly relating to defence. They relate much more to finance and taxation. Therefore, I foreshadow that I will move a motion to that effect after the conclusion of the second reading debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is now debating two very significant Bills on superannuation as it affects members of the armed services or those who have served. The Defence Force Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 is being debated together with the Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: I made the point yesterday in an urgency motion that hope springs eternal. Ordinary Australians place hope in their governments to provide them with essentially two very important things. One is an assurance of an income now and the other is an assurance of an income in the future. Superannuation is extremely important to us all. Those who serve in our armed services and have done so have been, I believe, particularly vulnerable in this respect. They have been dependent upon those outside the service to get it right for them in matters of superannuation. However, the fact is that over the years those entrusted with that function have got it wrong. With regard to superannuation provisions, those who have served in our armed services have been hard done by in the past. A series of schemes that have served this requirement for them have not served them well. These Bills address some of the inadequacies in that and therefore they are to be welcomed.

In broad terms, the Australian Democrats will support the thrust of the Bills, although we will be attempting to improve them by amendment in the committee stage of the debate. As Senator Newman has pointed out, that is probably most appropriately done in a slower time in the context of a standing committee where witnesses can come forward and more intensively analyse what the Government and the Parliament is proposing on their behalf.

Australians used to be great savers, but with the scourge of inflation the habit of saving has long since died. The provision that we make for our income in our middle to latter years is now normally done through superannuation schemes. The ethos of the service, as I say, is a very special one. It has been in a non-unionised context and therefore it has been a very rare thing in mess halls and officers' and sergeants' messes to hear issues of superannuation and pay, et cetera, discussed by those who have been serving.

From my 10 years in the Australian Regular Army, I virtually recall no occasion when such issues were seriously discussed. We assumed that somebody was looking after those things for us. When I chose to come out of the Regular Army after 10 years of service, I got a surprise at what was not awaiting me at the end of that period. The message was driven home to me quite forcibly that those who had been attending to my needs in this respect had not served me well. Those in the services now would certainly welcome the fact that these processes are being reviewed. There is a very genuine attempt being made in these Bills to improve them. I acknowledge, as Senator Newman has rightly pointed out, the changing structure and changing motivations of those who served.

On the question of the Force review structures which are occurring now, Australia is at an absolute watershed-a critical stage. The deliberations and decisions of government will be put before the Australian public before they are put before the Parliament. We will all hear on 6 June what the future of our Defence Force is. We in the Democrats have made no secret of the fact that we believe it is an opportune matter for profound lateral thinking about how our defence forces are structured and the seeking of alternate models. We have attempted and quite deliberately been provocative in that respect because we believe that it is time to be provocative and lateral and to acknowledge that we are in many respects fortunate now to be able to do a rethink and a review.

In that respect we welcome the innovative thoughts of Mr Wrigley. I do not deny that what he has proposed is quite controversial or that his report was regarded, initially at least, quite negatively by those in the services. I remember as a member of the defence subcommittee of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade being on the road travelling through units in Queensland on the first two or three days the Wrigley report hit the deck, when we witnessed and heard the initial reactions. Wrigley was provocative. He said, `Let us at least be prepared to think in quite dramatic and lateral terms about the way in which we structure, fund and generally administer our defence services'.

These are very important times. There is no doubt that the morale in the services must inevitably be in shock. It behoves us to take very gravely the responsibilities that we carry for the people who put aside the privilege of fighting their own cause and their own battle in these respects and pass that responsibility across to us.

These Bills, therefore, are of extreme importance to those who are serving and to those who have served. In commenting on the first of the Bills, the Defence Force Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, in broad terms, the Government is amending the Defence Force retirement benefits (DFRB) and the Defence Force retirement and death benefits (DFRDB) schemes to generally improve some minor aspects of benefits payable and to simplify some administrative procedures.

The proposed amendments to the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act 1973 come under a number of headings. First are those that propose alteration to the Constitution and manner of appointment to the Authority which administers the scheme. Not surprisingly, in the past, appointments to the Defence Force Retirements and Death Benefits Authority have been made by the Governor-General. In future they will, as a result of the passage of this Bill, be made by the Minister. Terminations will be made by and resignations made to the Minister instead of the Governor-General. The meeting rules of the Authority will also be slightly amended.

The second general area of amendment is the compulsory cessation of contributions after 40 years of service. There has been an anomaly whereby people who have served for 40 years have been obliged to continue to contribute with no effect to the scheme. It is appropriate that that anomaly is addressed. Thirdly, the Bill enhances the classification and reclassification powers to be granted to the Authority in respect of invalidity benefits where circumstances change when the pensioner has died. In other words, what used to happen is that, upon the death of a pensioner, everything was locked in. The provisions associated with the pension entitlement were put into concrete and were not able to be changed in accordance with the general change in circumstances of others within the scheme.

The fourth area is improvements to benefits paid to surviving spouses. A surviving spouse will be entitled to payments for six full fortnights at the deceased pensioner's full rate immediately after the death of the pensioner. In addition, the administrative arrangements for recovering the amounts paid in the name of the deceased and then making a subsequent payment to the spouses will be effected by offsetting the amount within the Authority. This should help to lessen confusion which is often experienced by elderly grieving spouses. It was a very inappropriate and unsatisfactory arrangement. All of this coincides with recent improvements to the age pension and to the superannuation benefits payable to Commonwealth public servants.

The additional payments will also be available under the DFRB scheme. This highlights an anomaly which has been brought to the attention of my colleague Senator Meg Lees that special payments are not available under the old 1922 Commonwealth superannuation scheme. The Government will not reconsider this issue, according to our discussion with the Department of Finance representatives.

The estimated cost of extending the bereavement benefit to those covered by the 1922 superannuation scheme is approximately $200,000 per annum and most would acknowledge that that is not a substantial sum of money in the general context of superannuation schemes. This legislation provides an appropriate vehicle for us to address that anomaly in an amendment and we will attempt to do so in the committee stage of this Bill. The fifth area of change in the Defence Force Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill concerns the nature of the benefits payable to members who retire from the scheme for a second time. I will not go into the details of all of these changes.

There are a number of consequential amendments which arise from these provisions I have outlined and they affect the Defence Forces Retirement Benefits Act 1948 and the Defence (Parliamentary Candidates) Act 1969. Those consequential amendments are provided for in the Bill.

In essence, the Australian Democrats welcome this Bill. We do not see it as being necessarily perfect, nor necessarily in the final form in which it should be addressed by this chamber. However, it comes to grips with a series of serious anomalies, and we believe the referral of the Bill to a committee-as suggested by Senator Newman, the committee where the greatest expertise lies rather than to a committee where the lesser expertise lies-will provide an opportunity for both those who are in service and those in past service to come forward to address the provisions of the Bill and perhaps to espouse further amendment following their representations at the committee stage.

The second Bill is the Military Superannuation Benefits Bill 1991. Honourable senators will recall that the Government announced in the Budget last year that a new superannuation scheme would be established from 1 October 1991 for regular Defence Force personnel. The proposal stems from a report on the existing scheme-the DFRDB scheme-by the review committee, which was chaired by Sir William Cole.

The proposed scheme will be called the military superannuation benefits scheme (MSBS). Persons joining the regular Defence Force on or after 1 October 1991 will automatically join the MSBS. Those who are presently serving will have to make a choice between two options. Membership of the MSBS will also be available to reservists who render continuous full time service for a period of or exceeding three months.

It may well be a challenge for this Bill to accommodate any major restructure to the Reserve which could be announced or proposed as a result of the ministerial announcement on 6 June. But the nature of legislation is that it accommodates what is now and what is passed rather than what is likely to be and the unforeseen, even though that may only be about three or four weeks away. It may well give rise to a situation where the concepts which are inherent in these two Bills may possibly be rendered inappropriate by changes which are simply three or four weeks away in concept but may be further away in reality.

The MSBS will comply with the provisions of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987. In that respect, it is a very positive move. There is uniformity and, slowly but surely, superannuation provisions are being brought to common standards. The common standards proposed within the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987 are now complied with by the superannuation provisions proposed in this legislation.

What are the main features of the new scheme? First, the MSBS will establish a separate fund. That is significant in that in the past the DFRDB and the DFRB schemes were not separate funds and the money went into Consolidated Revenue. Those who were administering the funds went to the Treasury and sought back the necessary funds in annual allotments, allocations, of funds; in other words, subject to the whims of Budgets as opposed to the contributions going directly into a fund which was administered by the Authority itself. There will be a degree of autonomy available and a degree of detachment from Budget considerations which did not prevail previously.

The second significant feature of the Bill is that member contributions and the Commonwealth's 3 per cent award contribution will also be paid into the MSBS. Contribution rates will be variable at the option of the member in the range of 5 to 10 per cent of salary. Therefore, individuals are able to plan to accommodate their own specific needs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was reviewing the changes to military superannuation which flow from the Military Superannuation and Benefits Bill 1991 which we are debating cognately with the Defence Force Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. In general terms, I had been saying that the Australian Democrats welcome the changes that are inherent in these Bills and that there is a great degree of dependence on the part of service people on the Parliament and the ministry and those responsible to attend to needs of superannuation on their behalf. Essentially they are a non-unionised group of people who have great dependence on others to service their needs in this respect. I was reviewing the changes to the provisions resulting from this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The third feature of the new scheme that is proposed-which is known as the military superannuation benefits scheme (MSBS)-is that contribution rates will be variable at the option of the member, ranging from 5 to 10 per cent. This is similar to the arrangements for normal public servants, except that the contribution for public servants may vary between 2 and 10 per cent.

The new scheme is much fairer for members who retire after less than 20 years of service, as they currently receive no interest on their contributions. That is significant because at the moment people can serve up to 17 years and all they get is a refund of their contributions. As I said, after 10 years of service myself, I must admit that that came as a shock. Therefore, this is an extremely welcome aspect of this new Bill.

Benefits will be more varied, with members having the option of taking a lump sum, a generous annuity by commercial standards, or a combination of the two. Generally the employer benefit, including the 3 per cent award contribution, must be preserved-that is, it cannot be accessed until age 55. The scheme provides comprehensive invalidity benefits, which are to be welcomed.

Reversionary benefits will be payable on all benefits to a spouse or a dependent child or to the will beneficiary or a personal representative. A member will be entitled to appeal against any decision of the board of trustees or any of its delegates, and that right of appeal is a new provision in this legislation.

As indicated previously, a pension for life has been a strong incentive to complete 20 years of service before retirement. Since this will not be available under the MSBS and the benefit payable for less than 20 years service performed will be substantially improved relative to the DFRB scheme, the problem of retaining valued staff may arise. Senator Newman rightly cited the fact that people were tending to leave the services earlier than previously. To counter this, the Bill proposes a special payment called a retention benefit, which will be paid where members meet five essential criteria. We regard that as being a significant acknowledgment that there is a tendency for all sorts of reasons for people to leave before they have completed 20 years service. The wastage of expertise is very expensive and is dislocating as far as the services are concerned in many respects. So we regard this retention benefit payment as a very important innovation.

We also foreshadow an amendment during the Committee stage whereby a member who chooses to opt out after having qualified for this retention benefit could choose to receive the benefit either in a lump sum or five incremental payments. It is inappropriate that somebody be forced to take it in a lump sum and therefore bear the maximum tax impact upon that sum. We do not accept Senator Newman's observations that to stage it in five increments may detract from the effectiveness of the benefit payment. It has certain advantages in terms of recovery should somebody default on the scheme.

If somebody qualifies and opts to take this retention benefit, for example, at a 15-year service point-five years before the intended time of departure, namely, 20 years of service-there is a requirement for the authority to go through the process of recovery of what could be a quite substantial sum of money, which may impact very disadvantageously upon the person who chose, for what could be very good reasons, to go out at a 15-year point and to live with the recovery consequences.

An incremental provision, which somebody can opt for, has the benefit of considerably reducing those recovery requirements. Under this proposal the maximum benefit is equal to one year's salary. That is an extremely attractive incentive, and the Government is to be commended for building into this scheme the degree of flexibility that is inherent in that provision to opt for a lump sum of one year's salary after 15 years service.

Look at the realities of how that would affect, for example, the average serviceman enlisting at the age of 18 to 20 years and having that option available at 35 years of age; it is quite likely that that serviceperson would possibly have teenage children and it would be a period of life when it would be very attractive indeed to take a benefit of the equivalent of one year's salary. It becomes less attractive if the tax man gets 36 per cent or more of it. Therefore, in this incremental provision we propose that the tax impact be reduced and the attractiveness of the proposition increased. I foreshadow that we will move such an amendment during the Committee stage.

The Australian Democrats congratulate the Government on coming to grips with a series of anomalies and inadequacies associated with the Defence Force superannuation. We believe that both of these Bills are constructive and necessary and, in broad terms, we support them. We foreshadow the two amendments I have mentioned. We believe that it is appropriate that the Bills be approached in the Committee stages in slower time rather than quicker time. We also believe it is appropriate, as Senator Newman foreshadowed, that the Bills be referred to the committee which has the maximum expertise on superannuation and, therefore, we will support that reference proposition when Senator Newman moves it shortly.
