SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Sex Discrimination Amendment Bill 1991, which amends the Sex Discrimination Act 1984, the Marriage Act 1961 and the War Gratuity Act 1945. Part 2 of the Bill deals with the complex area of sex discrimination and the law relating to superannuation. These amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 are the most substantial in the Bill, and I will mention briefly the other parts of the Bill before returning to discuss these particular amendments in more detail.

SPEECH.PARA: Part 3 of the Bill provides for amendments to the Marriage Act 1961 so that the marriageable age for both males and females is 18. The amendments also provide for the age to be reduced to 16 by way of court order. Part 4 of the Bill amends the War Gratuity Act 1945. That Act is currently discriminatory in that it provides for differing benefits to widowers and widows and does not recognise de facto spouses. The Bill removes that discrimination.

Turning to the amendments relating to sex discrimination, the position under the existing legislation-the Sex Discrimination Act 1984-is that it is unlawful to discriminate on the grounds of sex, marital status or pregnancy in the provision of goods, services and facilities, for payment or not, by refusing to provide them. It is also unlawful to discriminate in the terms or conditions under which they are provided, and in the manner in which they are provided. The legislation provides for several exemptions to acts and practices that constitute discrimination on the ground of sex or marital status. These include exemptions relating to superannuation and insurance contained in section 41.

When Parliament passed the Sex Discrimination Act in late 1983, the intention was that the superannuation and insurance exemptions would operate only for a two-year period. However, because of the many complex issues involved it became clear that it would be necessary to extend the exemptions. It was agreed that there should be a comprehensive inquiry into the problems raised by the life insurance and superannuation industries in the various submissions they made on the proposed legislation.

The inquiry was undertaken by the then Human Rights Commission at the request of the Attorney-General in 1984. Its report was tabled in this place in November 1986. Various recommendations were made, the principal one being that superannuation schemes should be made to comply with the anti-discrimination provisions of the sex discrimination legislation. The provision of a transition period of three years was also recommended to allow superannuation schemes time to remove discriminatory arrangements. The question of the exemption relating to insurance was dealt with by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in a later report tabled in September last year. The purpose of this Bill's amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act is to reduce the number of circumstances in which superannuation and insurance funds and policies may discriminate on the grounds of sex or marital status.

This is the third time that a Bill seeking to remove the exemption relating to super- perannuation has been introduced. The Sex Discrimination Bill 1989 was passed by the House of Representatives but was not transmitted to the Senate, and subsequently lapsed when the Parliament was dissolved for the 1990 election. Another Bill was introduced in September 1990 but was withdrawn.

In clause 2 of this latest version of the Bill, provision is made for a two-year period from the date on which the Act receives the royal assent before the commencement of the sections containing the exemptions relating to superannuation and insurance schemes. The Opposition notes that this falls short of the transition period of three years recommended by the Human Rights Commission.

Clause 6 of the Bill amends the Sex Discrimination Act to provide for a new subsection 14(4), which prohibits discrimination on the grounds of a person's sex or marital status in exercising a discretion conferring a superannuation benefit. Clause 8 of the Bill repeals section 41 of the Sex Discrimination Act, which is the section relating to superannuation and insurance. It is replaced with three new provisions: sections 41, 41A and 41B.

The proposed new section 41 reinserts the current exemption in regard to insurance, which is currently section 41(4) of the Act. The effect of the exemption is that, in relation to an insurance policy, a person may only discriminate on the grounds of sex where the discrimination is based on actuarial or statistical data and is reasonable having regard to that data, and the discrimination is contained in the terms of the policy.

The proposed new section 41(4) deals with new superannuation policies. Pursuant to this section, there are four situations in which discrimination on the grounds of sex or marital status for the provision of superannuation benefits will not be unlawful: firstly, discrimination will not be unlawful where it is based on actuarial or statistical data and is reasonable having regard to that data. Secondly, non-payment of a dependent benefit-that is, a benefit payable on the policyholder's death to another person-to those who do not have a spouse, de facto spouse or child will not be unlawful. Thirdly, the vesting, preservation or portability provisions may result in discrimination, provided it is indirect discrimination. Fourthly, it will not be unlawful for superannuation fund conditions to include a provision that confers particular benefits, or more generous benefits, on a person who was a member of a fund before the commencement of legislation and the discrimination is in the superannuation fund conditions.

The proposed new section 41B makes provision for existing superannuation funds to continue to operate upon certain conditions without being liable to complaints of discrimination on the grounds of sex or marital status, even if they have not complied with the new provisions. This proposed section applies where a person or beneficiary was a member of an existing superannuation fund and had been given an option to obtain non-discriminatory benefits and had not exercised the option, and where the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has not issued a specific exemption under section 44 relating to that superannuation scheme. The exemption conferred by this section will not apply where the administrators of the fund require a member to exercise the option in a period of less than two months. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 9 of the Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has the power to grant exemptions to existing superannuation schemes to which proposed new section 41B applies.

The Opposition moved three amendments during the committee stage in the House of Representatives. The first of those moved by the shadow Attorney-General was to clause 6, which amends section 14 of the Sex Discrimination Act. Although this amendment was negatived, the subsequent amendment moved by the Government adequately addressed the same issue. We will therefore not be pursuing it.

The second amendment moved by Mr Peacock related to the option to transfer to non-discriminatory benefits. This is an important issue. I foreshadow that the Opposition will be pursuing that amendment and also the amendment moved by the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, Mr Ruddock, to clause 7 dealing with the relationship between section 40 of the Sex Discrimination Act and certain provisions of the immigration legislation.

The Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia Ltd has made several submissions in relation to this Bill raising a number of concerns with its drafting. Some of those were addressed in amendments moved by my colleague the shadow Attorney-General in the other place, but due to the detailed and technical nature of these concerns the Opposition will be moving at the end of this second reading debate for the Bill to be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. This will allow the Association and other interested parties to make submissions on the desirability of further amendments.

Finally, I would like to make some comments about the policy issues raised by this Bill. The Opposition is supporting the Bill, because the changes introduced in relation to superannuation will improve the position of women in full time and part time employment. The Bill goes some way towards redressing the entrenched discrimination against women, which is historically a part of labour force arrangements in Australia. But it is only a small step on the way towards achieving true equality for women in the work force.

For a start, this Bill will do nothing to improve the retirement income arrangements for those in casual or seasonal employment, and that is one of the major sources of employment for women. Another source of discrimination which the Government seems to accept as inevitable is the availability of the age pension for women at the age of 60, which has resulted in this becoming, in general, the age for retirement of women. This deprives women of potentially contributing to superannuation for a further five years, up to the age of 65, as their male colleagues can. The removal of this discrimination is a feature of the coalition's retirement incomes policy.

There is the further point that until recently women were discriminated against in relation to their relatively limited access to superannuation and the generally lower level of benefits to which they were entitled, even though their levels of contribution were similar to those of men. Even though these issues have now been addressed, it should not be forgotten that they still affect many thousands of women in the work force.

It is a simple fact that women do not participate in superannuation schemes at anything like the male rate. Sixty-three per cent of males in full time employment have superannuation, compared with 47 per cent of women. Thirty-seven per cent of women work part time, and only 19 per cent of them have superannuation. These are major issues in the area of superannuation which the Government has yet to address. An obvious issue is the question of the entitlements of women who have contributed directly or indirectly to the superannuation of their husbands but who are not covered by those superannuation arrangements. This becomes especially relevant in the event of marriage breakdown.

As our population ages, it is becoming more and more important that people provide for their own income in retirement through superannuation. Otherwise, we risk the burden for taxpayers of providing income support for increasing numbers of age pensioners becoming unmanageably large.

The coalition's retirement incomes policy introduces the concept of a retirement savings account. This is the flexibility to allow people, whether in full time, part time or periodic employment, to make contributions throughout their working lives. When, for example, women leave the work force for several years, their husbands may continue to make contributions on their behalf and thus obtain a tax deduction for doing so. The coalition urges the Government to adopt this policy initiative and thereby give many thousands of people, particularly women, financial independence in retirement, which they will not otherwise be able to achieve.

As I indicated, at the end of the second reading debate I will be moving that the Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, and that it be referred to it for consideration and report by 29 May. The Committee has been given notice of both our intention and also the witnesses that we believe can bring to the Committee's attention the necessary information so that it can deliberate properly on the matters that will be before this Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats wholeheartedly welcome the appearance of the Sex Discrimination Amendment Bill 1991 finally into this chamber and devoutly wish that this particular occasion will be its final appearance. However, as Senator Hill has said, the Opposition has taken the decision to refer the Bill to a committee for further deliberation, which is a matter of regret to us.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the third time that a Bill for this particular purpose, namely, to reduce the exemptions for superannuation which exist under the current Sex Discrimination Act, has been introduced to the Parliament. Yet only now do we find here in the Senate a Bill before us which has passed the House of Representatives and which in the end at some time-although not until after 29 May, given Senator Hill's reference to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs-will pass this place and become law. The Australian Democrats feel that the Sex Discrimination Act has always contained too many exemptions. This Bill that is now before us removes some of those exemptions, and for that reason is welcome. It has been an inexorable march since the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 to remove the exemptions in that original Bill. This is part of that march, another step along the way. There have been a number of amendments since 1984, and no doubt eventually we will get to the stage where we have genuine anti-discrimination legislation on matters such as superannuation.

The fact that this Bill will not pass expeditiously is a matter of regret to us because the process has been gone through so many times. We believe, however, that the exemptions which are being removed in this Bill do not go far enough. It provides for indefinite exemptions under section 40, in part II of the Act, to a number of Commonwealth Acts. These include the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, some other tax Acts and the Social Security Act 1947. These exemptions will remain and are not dealt with here.

It seems to me that an indefinite exemption is inappropriate in the case of the tax and social security departments. The Democrats will be proposing amendments which in a sense will put a sunset clause on those exemptions, suggesting a five-year exemption only. We would want, as part of our amendment, to ensure a review of the situation by the Parliament in five years time. The case for exemption for those departments would have to be argued at that time.

The Opposition's motion to send this Bill to a Committee rests largely, as I understand Senator Hill, on concerns raised by the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia-an association which has been consulted extensively over the years about moves to remove the exemption with regard to superannuation and which has no basic quarrel with the Bill, but some concerns about certain aspects. As I say, it is of concern to us that this Bill should not be delayed, that it should be passed and that the exemptions which are currently in the Act should be removed. Our concerns relate to the exemptions on superannuation insurance on the grounds of sex or marital status with the exceptions to which I have referred, because of the situation in which women find themselves.

Senator Hill raised the question of the retirement pension age difference between women and men, and that is a matter that should be addressed over time, but we must address it in the context of this Bill. That context relates to the fact that although 63 per cent of men are covered by superannuation, only 47 per cent of women are so covered. With such a high proportion of women in the part time work force-amounting to a figure of 37 per cent-and with only 17 per cent of them covered by superannuation, in that context it is not possible to say that men and women approaching retirement age do so on an equal basis. Although we see ourselves as a nation with legislation relating to sex discrimination and equal opportunity, it must be said that across the entire paid work force women are still only achieving 70 per cent of the pay received by men. Even though women have had the Sex Discrimination Act in place since 1984 and a range of anti-discrimination and equal opportunity legislation at State and Federal level, they are still not achieving economic equity.

To the extent that this piece of legislation improves the position of women in the paid work force in regard to superannuation arrangements-and that extent is by no means complete-this Bill is a welcome next step. We want to ensure that at least another significant step is taken in five years time in terms of the taxation and social security departments and their superannuation arrangements which remain exempted under this legislation. The Democrats welcome the Bill and will be supporting it when eventually it comes back to this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I basically support the Sex Discrimination Amendment Bill 1991 as an important step, particularly in the area of superannuation. The coalition supports this Bill and welcomes it as overdue. However, there are some aspects and details that the Liberal-National Party coalition wishes to be expanded through the committee processes. We believe that those processes can be dealt with quite expeditiously.

SPEECH.PARA: There are three aspects to the proposed legislation. I refer to the amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act 1984, the Marriage Act 1961, and the War Gratuity Act 1945. Part I of the Bill relates to the commencement of the various other parts of the Bill. The commencement date of part II of the Bill is two years from the date on which the Bill receives royal assent. The remainder will commence in August this year. It is part II which contains the important amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act, and that is the matter to which I will address my remarks.

Part III of the Bill relates to the Marriage Act 1961. The intention is to create parity between the marriageable age for men and women. At present the age for a female is 16 years and for a male 18 years. The intention of the legislation is to create a common age of 18 for both sexes, with provision for reduction to 16 by court order for both male and female, as opposed to the previous age of 14 for women and 16 for men. The need for this change is obvious.

The War Gratuity Act 1945 relating to the payment of gratuities to members of the armed forces who served in World War II and their dependants is also to be amended to remove discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status.

I intend to concentrate on the Sex Discrimination Act with regard to superannuation in particular because this is an important area in which there are still some problems to address, even though in principle the amendment is supported.

Clause 8 of the Bill proposes a new section 41A and 41B to replace the former blanket exemptions in section 41 which applied to superannuation. The blanket exemption to superannuation which has existed in the Sex Discrimination Act until now allowed discrimination to continue to exist by law across the board in this area. The new exemptions are more specific and should serve to remove much of the discrimination which was possible under the previous legislation.

I will now briefly recap on these proposed exemptions. They include a provision in fund conditions for the use of actuarial data upon which it is reasonable to rely; the provision of lesser death and disability benefits to members who have no dependants; where discrimination arises in relation to vesting, a provision for preservation and portability of benefits; and the protection of existing expectations of members of discriminatory schemes, where these members have been offered alternative schemes which are non-discriminatory.

It is now seven years since the concept of this legislation was initiated in the form of recommendations for change by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. We in the Federal Opposition had significant input into the initial proposals which came before the chamber, and I am pleased to see the legislation close to fruition.

As a coalition, we highlighted the needs of part time and self-employed workers. In the committee stage we moved amendments to delete a clause to allow the provisions of the Bill to be repealed by way of regulation. We moved amendments which addressed the continuity of discrimination provisions in existing trust deeds in order to obviate the necessity of amending 120,000 deeds, at a cost of an estimated $50m to the industry. While this commonsense measure has been taken, the Bill prohibits the exercise of discretionary powers in a discriminatory way.

These improvements now being proposed are necessary and are indeed welcomed by the coalition, the coalition having drawn attention to this sort of approach. However, it is now the third time that the Bill has come before the Parliament in a display of the Government's characteristic procrastination and failure to meet its commitments to the electorate. The initial concept has been seven years in the pipeline. Even now, there is perhaps an element of too little, too late.

At this point in time, it is necessary that the amendments are passed to reinforce the important changes taking place in the industry and to prevent further delays. To this end the coalition is pleased to give its consent to the proposed legislation. However, as I mentioned, there are a number of details which we believe are best flushed out by a standing committee evaluation.

However, there remains some concern with regard to the lack of superannuation for part time and casual workers. A failure to address this matter will result in continuing discrimination against women by default, as three-quarters of the part time work force is female. This represents approximately two million women.

If the purpose of the legislation is to remove discrimination and to enable more Australians to provide adequately for their retirement, there is potential for its failure at this point. There was a step in the right direction in July last year, when it became possible for part time workers working more than 10 hours a week to take personal superannuation and to claim this as a tax deduction and also for superannuation to continue for up to two years for people outside the paid work force. It is now necessary that workers become aware of the availability of this cover and that moves be made to encourage more people to take up this option.

To say that it is too complicated in terms of paperwork to establish greater options of superannuation for part time workers, seasonal workers and workers doing unpaid work, and to put the matter into the too hard basket just will not do. It will not do when such a large number of Australian women have their standard of living in retirement at stake. As has been pointed out before, it is essential not only for the purpose of preventing discrimination but also for the purpose of the economic health of the nation that there should be appropriate superannuation for female workers, both part time and full time.

Women form the greatest proportion of the aged and receive, therefore, a greater proportion of the age pension payment nationally. This figure has been placed at 70 per cent. These proportions are set to increase, not decrease, in the future. The pay-out will increase because the average age of the population is rising. With this in mind, superannuation for part time workers becomes a matter of some importance.

Unless there is accelerated change in the area of superannuation for more of the work force, especially in traditional women's areas, a discriminatory effect will become increasingly conspicuous as the average living standard for women in retirement falls in comparison with that of men in retirement. This is the area where perhaps these amendments are too late because for many women this change of events is already taking place.

I note the comment by the honourable member for Prospect, Mrs Crosio, in the House of Representatives. She said that the Government is extending superannuation across the labour force. However, while it is possible for the bulk of the part time work force to be without superannuation, this becomes somewhat a spurious claim. Women work patterns are notably of an interrupted nature, often by reason of raising a family and then with a return to part time work as commitments to children taper off. There is also still a problem for those in irregular part time work, such as seasonal workers. There is an even greater difficulty in the area of unpaid work, such as in the raising of a family, which is an important contribution to society. Unfortunately, these problems are yet to be addressed.

There needs to be provision for members of superannuation schemes choosing to continue their cover, perhaps by means of contributions by the continuing bread winner, whether this be a man or a woman. This need would go hand in hand with appropriate taxation concessions, whether for men or women. The existing two-year period should be extended to a realistic period which would allow a parent to choose to raise a family before returning to work. Clearly this would benefit many women, as they are largely the ones who have interrupted work patterns, including periods of unpaid work. Eventual benefits to the economy from having these people covered by superannuation would have a multiplying effect as the pension bill would be reduced and more people would have the benefit of increased security and a higher standard of living in their retirement.

The coalition's policy on retirement addresses these issues with proposals, such as the retirement savings account, to cover individuals with broken work patterns. This acts as a bank account not attracting the superannuation costs, roll-over charges and approved deposit fund charges which are normally incurred. This policy gives individuals in part time employment or anyone without superannuation cover the ability to continue to make contributions throughout their working lives by way of tax deductible contributions made by themselves or their partner during periods of unpaid or part time work. I therefore support the Bill and hope that it has a speedy passage through the committee to which we hope it will be referred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Sex Discrimination Amendment Bill and, like the previous speakers, I am very pleased to see that it has actually come into this place. Like Senator Watson, I also wish it a speedy passage. I am not quite sure of the status of the Opposition's reference to committee. I am not sure whether it will need a majority vote in this place to achieve this. I did not understand Senator Powell to make clear what the Australian Democrats might want to do on that, but I hope that, however that rides out, it does not cause a delay. Indeed, I think it is somewhat disappointing that that kind of delay, even if it be small, is envisaged by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: It has pointed out that this is not the first time we have seen this piece of legislation. Indeed, that point has been made by people on both sides and in both the other House and here. I thought that the amount of time available to deliberate on the proposed changes under this amendment legislation might have allowed for its conclusion in this place rather than its having to go to a committee. I guess that we will have to wait to see the outcome of all that.

I am very pleased to support this for a number of reasons, partly because I remember the debates we had at the time of the introduction of the sex discrimination legislation and the concern a number of us on the Government side had with the allowance of the exemption for superannuation funds back in 1983-84. As I remember it-and I think Senator Hill said this in his comments in this place today-there was proposed then a two-year period before the amendments to not allow the exemptions for superannuation funds would be introduced. It is a little longer than two years. Indeed, the exemption clauses still give time to the superannuation funds to allow them to adjust and to do the necessary rearrangements of their actuarial equations and so on.

I think what is clear with this legislation today is the message being sent to superannuation funds which is that now is the time they have to start to do that work. I presume-indeed, I hope-that some of them have done some of that work to this point, but it is no longer possible to say that there is an exemption. From now on, superannuation funds have to address that and make sure that those prospects for discrimination against women in this area are no longer allowed.

I am delighted, too, because I think this legislation fits in very well with the other areas of policy for women introduced by the Government. These areas include encouragement to work and increased job opportunities enjoyed by women. Women in employment have been assisted in terms of necessary child-care, tertiary education training of all sorts and a number of other programs that have been spelt out in this place by Government senators. They have elaborated the Government's commitment to the right of women to look for income security during their working life and to be able to provide for some sort of financial security in retirement over and above the age pension. It is particularly important that this legislation is now before us. It is part of a package of legislation that this Government has introduced on behalf of women.

I was very interested to hear Senator Watson's comments. I think that they were very thoughtful. He acknowledged-it seems that his colleagues do not want to-the right of women to be in the work force, to make choices and to expect to enjoy the economic benefits of that work force participation, including the opportunity to contribute to a superannuation scheme. I sincerely hope that I do not have to use Senator Watson's remarks to remind his colleagues that they sometimes need to adjust their thinking. But I think Senator Watson's comments are appropriate. I think they acknowledge, first, the reality that there are so many women in the work force and, secondly, that it is not unreasonable for them to be making those sorts of choices.

The challenges that still face us in dealing with opportunities for women, even in respect of superannuation, cannot be overlooked. Some of them have been spelt out by previous speakers today. I am concerned about the small number of women to this point who are taking up their superannuation opportunities. I believe that we still have to press, educate and encourage women to see the value of appreciating the benefits of superannuation. We simply need to inform them of their rights. That is probably the main reason women are not participating. The problem is not so much one of women making a choice about what they do with the income they earn.

My other major concern is that women's salaries and wages are very much behind men's salaries and wages. The contributions they make and the tax concessions they enjoy are, as a consequence, lower. That, of course, is always going to be the case for people-men or women-in lower income brackets. But it is a matter of concern that the very large majority of women are in those lower paid situations. This is another area of concern for those of us who are looking at ways in which women can be assisted to enable them to gain financial security in their working life and in retirement. That is something that has to be addressed.

I notice that equal pay is on the agenda again. I believe the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission has been receiving submissions on the question of equal pay. I will be interested to see whether that debate will lead to any initiatives being implemented.

A number of people have referred to the challenge that women face as a result of being expected to retire at the age of 50 when they become eligible for the age pension. Some curious discussions have taken place in this chamber and in other forums about women being the subject of favourable discrimination as a result of being able to enjoy early retirement. I was interested to read the speech that Mr Connolly made in the other place in April this year. He took us through some of the history of why women have had to, or have been expected to, retire early. I will not run through all of that now but I would suggest that if people are interested in yet another fascinating piece of history, they take up Mr Connolly's contribution in the other place.

The arguments for why women should retire early ranged from what was morally good for women, usually determined by men, to the injustice of women being able to retire early and the discrimination in their favour. If ever there were a time when women should be allowed to speak for themselves, it should be on the question of when women retire and are eligible for benefits. I heard former senator Janine Haines speaking about the right for women to enjoy benefits at the age of 50. She saw it as a matter of equity and justice that women, who have been denied benefits during their working life, should be eligible for pension at that earlier age.

I might say that a Senate standing committee examined the issue of retirement income. Whenever the question was raised of removing the discrimination between men and women in respect of the age at which they were eligible for pensions, I rarely heard it argued that men should be eligible to receive benefits at an early age. Indeed, I often heard it argued that men should be eligible only after they had reached the age of 65. I think to a large extent Government outlays were driving that argument; but there were other arguments which I will not take the Senate through. I am sure that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, would know them all.

One of the other points raised by Senator Watson-this very important concern has been raised by others-is the question of the ageing of the population of Australia and what the consequence would be if all aged persons' income were dependent entirely on the age pension. The expenditure outlays, of course, would be very large and would be expected to increase dramatically. So it is very responsible of governments to be encouraging people to take up superannuation now. People should have the ability to provide entirely for themselves financially in retirement or supplement their pensions. In this way, the contribution to aged people which will have to be made from public sector outlays will be spread. The demographic figures suggest that by 2021 we will have to face the great concern about this increased outlay to an ageing population. However, some people are suggesting that it will cut in earlier than that.

Even though I have voiced some concern about the rate of take-up for superannuation, the figures are encouraging. The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures released on 13 August 1990 indicate that superannuation coverage for Australian workers had dramatically increased in 1988-89. The proportion of employees covered by superannuation rose to 54.6 per cent in that period compared with 44 per cent in 1987-88. Public sector employees had a much higher coverage of superannuation, with something like 90.4 per cent covered in 1988-89. This was an increase from 68 per cent in 1987-88. In the private sector, the total proportion of coverage had increased to 40.6 per cent in 1988-89 from 44.1 per cent in the previous financial year.

It is a matter of concern that despite these increases in the numbers covered, nothing like 100 per cent of people eligible for superannuation are actually taking up that entitlement. Indeed, the figures might suggest that about only 75 per cent of people eligible actually have superannuation coverage. I think some of the reasons for that have been spelt out by other speakers. Certainly, Senator Watson canvassed a number of those concerns. I do not mind saying again on the record that the pattern of women's work is one reason that women may not be able to participate in continuous superannuation. They are not encouraged to participate because of the view that they might rapidly have to withdraw from the work force.

I commend the Government for the changes that it made last year to allow women to be absent from the work force for up to two years and still participate in superannuation, provided that contributions continued. This allows for continuity of superannuation. It is true that the pattern is that women make up a high proportion of the part time work force. Their irregular participation in the part time and full time work force is still the main reason that they are still not sufficiently represented within superannuation schemes.

The encouragement that will follow from the exemption under this legislation should not be understated. It will allow the promotion of superannuation. It will target particularly those women, and perhaps men, who have not taken up superannuation. It will also serve as an initiative for the large funds to, first, appreciate the requirements when doing their own work and, secondly, contribute to the requirement for providing the community with the information it needs to have about superannuation opportunities.

There was a concern-I believe that it has been said in other places and it is covered; maybe the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) will be able to advise me of this-about actuarial sums being done simply on figures and thus disadvantaging women because of early retirement in terms of the charge that they might have to bear for their superannuation. As women are expected to live longer and as they may take up their superannuation earlier, there is the prospect that we will not eliminate the discrimination that we were asking for. I would like clarification on that. I hope the Minister can provide it. That is a measure of my insufficiency here; not the Government's. I would appreciate it if that were covered.

This legislation is part of a package of policies and legislation for women introduced by the Government. It is a very important one. The highest priority of women who talk to me and other government senators is income security. They want that income security not only during their working lives-whether they are in the paid work force or not-but also during their retirement. The anxiety of aged people when they are not sure of the sufficiency of their finances is known to all of us.

I would be very pleased if this superannuation exemption allowed for that kind of understanding so that women who have the opportunity of superannuation can now look forward to continuous income security. This allows for better planning and a better arrangement of their finances. It allows them to exercise more opportunity during their working and retirement life. It allows them a number of other advantages often overlooked. The knowledge of regular income does away with anxiety and concern about where the money is coming from and the pressure to save for the day when something will go wrong. It allows for a planned living. In particular, it allows women to exercise options throughout their lives, options which have not been available in the past and sometimes not available to them when they were thinking about their own prospects.

This is a very important Bill. It goes to the rights of women. It appreciates and understands that they have rights. It is a matter of much more importance than just the specifics written in this legislation. It goes to changing the climate for women in society. It is part of the Government's view on the rights and role of women. In particular, it will contribute to women seeing themselves differently and exercising their options. I commend this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to support the Sex Discrimination Amendment Bill 1991. It provides me with an opportunity to reflect on the program of reform undertaken by the Hawke Government over eight years to ensure that Australian women receive a fair go. In particular, this Bill addresses a major inequity relating to women's access to superannuation. No doubt, many honourable senators will remember the celebrations on International Women's Day in 1984 when women gathered on the lawn outside the old Parliament House to mark the passage of the sex discrimination legislation through the House of Representatives. Honourable senators may remember that at that time there were ominous warnings about that legislation. It was said that it would be destructive to Australian society and to the Australian family. However, seven years on, the Sex Discrimination Act is accepted as providing genuine protection of women's rights. It is also regarded as a landmark reform responsible for heralding much more in the way of progress to ensure that women receive greater recognition across all areas of government administration.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I focus on the positive aspects of this Bill. It is interesting to think that it has taken us until 1991 to acknowledge that superannuation is not a luxury, but a necessity towards ensuring secure old age. It should be available to all workers, men and women. Everyone has the right to access schemes designed to provide income security in old age, and women should not be hindered in this by being penalised because of their work force participation. They usually have to combine their work force participation with a range of family commitments. They should not be discriminated against because of this other great service they give to the Australian community through their contribution to families.

The Bill particularly addresses the area of part time and casual employment. As we know, the great majority of part time employees are women. About 40 per cent of women work part time compared with only 6 per cent of men. Clearly, it is absolutely essential that the amendment Bill take up this issue. Women live longer, earn less and are often out of the paid work force for substantial parts of their adult lives. They are actually disadvantaged by their gender. So it is very important that this Bill address a number of these issues.

One of the very special reforms that followed sex discrimination legislation, affirmative action legislation, equal employment opportunity in the Public Service and a number of policy initiatives across government portfolios was, of course, the bringing together of all these areas into what is known as the National Agenda for Women. As I have said on many occasions in this and other places, the National Agenda for Women is important not just because it is a government initiative but also because it is a commitment of Australia to maintain that national agenda well into the future to ensure that women get considerable recognition for the implementation of those policy initiatives.

The national agenda has noted that less than half of Australia's employees have had superannuation coverage, with only one in four female employees being covered compared with nearly half of all male employees. The agenda objectives for the year 2000 are to assist in significantly increasing coverage and adequacy of coverage for women; to encourage and facilitate superannuation arrangements which are more responsive to the women's work force patterns; to remove discrimination in superannuation on the grounds of sex, marital status or pregnancy; and to provide, through the social security system, adequate retirement income support for those women without full superannuation support.

Five-year action plans aim to reduce legislative exemption of superannuation funds and schemes under the Sex Discrimination Act; to monitor implications for the national wage case decision for women, having regard to their broken work force patterns and occupational segregation; to consider superannuation alternatives in the light of women's dual role as home-makers and members of the paid work force; to introduce standards for the vesting, preservation and portability of superannuation benefits within five years which do not indirectly discriminate against women; and, furthermore, to review the report of the Law Reform Commission on matrimonial property and, if necessary, take initiatives to compensate for the loss of superannuation on divorce.

In relation to taxation concessions, from 1 July 1990 the Government has extended the tax concessions for personal superannuation contributions for the self-employed and those with only low levels of employer provided superannuation. Under the 1989 Budget provisions for improved retirement incomes, those employed for as little as 10 hours per week are now able to contribute to personal superannuation schemes and receive a tax deduction for that contribution. Women having interrupted or part time employment will be able to retain their membership of superannuation funds by continuing contributions for up to two years while outside the paid work force.

It is worth mentioning on this occasion the new superannuation scheme that was introduced for Commonwealth employees which also became effective on 1 July 1990. That scheme overcomes the previous indirect discrimination against women which operated largely because of interrupted part time or short term periods of employment.

It is not enough for government simply to pass legislation and make changes for Commonwealth employees or even to give taxation concessions unless these changes are well publicised. As my colleague Senator Crowley indicated, women in the work force and women generally can often have low self-esteem. They are not used to being recognised and given better treatment. There can be a situation where women are just not aware of their entitlements. I know this from the number of women who approach my office, and I am sure other people's offices, who are not fully informed as to their entitlements.

The better income statement which was released in 1989 highlighted the need to educate the community, and women in particular, on the benefits of saving for retirement. A community awareness campaign was implemented in February 1990 to draw attention to the award-based superannuation contribution by employers and to generate inquiry about eligibility for the practical workings of superannuation. The campaign targeted low income workers and women, with television commercials running for approximately 10 days. A booklet and telephone hot line was provided to give further information. Once this amendment Bill is passed, government needs to continue its efforts to publicise information for women in the work force, particularly in part time positions and those positions where they are more vulnerable through perhaps not being given the kind of equity that this Bill aims to give them. We need to ensure that that information is readily available.

My colleague Senator Crowley touched on the controversial issue of the pension age for women. In concluding I shall run through some comments about this. The lower age for pension entitlement for women compared to men has been criticised by some as discriminatory. However, it is important to make a number of points. Women have much lower labour force participation rates, superannuation coverage-as we have been discussing-and income. Raising the pension age for women may assist in altering community attitudes towards women's economic role but, unless it was raised in line with real improvements in the indicators mentioned above, women would be placed at a considerable disadvantage and in hardship. Further, a change of this sort cannot be introduced in the short term. It requires considerable community discussion and time for older women of work force age to adjust their expectations.

The Government's national agenda for women establishes a framework for considering a raising of the age pension age. The agenda consists of two time periods-the next five years and the period to the year 2000. Amongst other things, it sets various targets for improving superannuation coverage and benefits in employment for women. Raising the pension age can build on the same framework. At the end of the five-year period, a stocktake could be made of progress towards achieving higher superannuation coverage and better benefits for women. This would determine the need for further action. I stress that, given women's position in the work force and the fact that they are still concentrated in lower paid positions and are still dependent in so many instances on part time work, I do not think that it is an area where the Government should rush to introduce changes. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to support the elimination of discrimination against women in the area of superannuation. For many years as secretary, and later president, of a very large trade union, I have been involved in the fight for the spread of superannuation for women. This issue takes on a very important aspect today. We have seen in recent weeks the decision of the Government to reduce the immigration intake and we have seen the declining birth rates. Australian workers and people in general are faced with the stark reality that in 20 or 30 years time when they retire there will not be the number of people in the paid work force to sustain the age pension at its present level.

SPEECH.PARA: What is happening in the area of superannuation is that people are now paying for their own pension. Everybody is paying for that in higher prices. When I say `everybody' I include those people who are discriminated against in the area of superannuation. I refer particularly to the women who are employed but not in the paid work force. They are being discriminated against because they are now paying higher prices for the superannuation payments that are required of employers and the other superannuation payments that are being made today.

Late last year or early this year, I received across my desk a most interesting submission entitled Women &Superannuation: Position paper 1990 by the national office of the Women's Action Alliance (Aust.). Rather than my taking the time of the Senate, I believe that this document is so interesting and raises such important questions about this matter that I seek the leave of the Senate, having shown the document to the Government, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats, to have the document incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
SUPERANNUATION POLICY PROPOSAL
Women's Action Alliance believes that security in retirement should be available to all Australians.

As our population is ageing and our capacity to fund pensions in their present form will be limited in the future, all Australians should have access to and be encouraged to take out superannuation, regardless of whether or not they are in employment.
Schemes should vest funds immediately in the name of the superannuee, and funds should be preserved until retirement.
Single income families should be able to take out superannuation in the name of the non-earning spouse in any scheme to which the earning spouse is eligible, with all the consequent tax benefits.
In these circumstances, the Reasonable Benefit Limit should be based on half the final salary of the earning spouse.

In addition, a means tested superannuation voucher scheme should be available to welfare recipients and those on low incomes to allow them to participate in any scheme to which they may be eligible. Such benefit should be in a form which could be used solely for the purposes of superannuation.
WOMEN AND SUPERANNUATION
INTRODUCTION
Superannuation is an issue which has received increasing attention in Australia over the last few years from a wide range of interest groups.
There is a very valid reason for this interest. Australia's ageing population is a fact which will cause great problems for society unless solutions are found and implemented now.

Currently, the over sixty-five component of the population in Australia is about 10%; by the year 2020 it is expected to reach 16%. At the same time, our birth rate has declined dramatically to the extent that, were it not for immigration, Australia's population would be decreasing.

What does all this mean for those contemplating retirement in twenty to thirty years time? It means that, unless radical changes are made, an increasing proportion of the population will be relying on the age pension, while a declining proportion of taxpayers will be required to support them. The result? An overwhelming taxation burden on future generations of Australians.
For these reasons, Australia needs to be looking to other methods of retirement support, the most important of which is superannuation.
SUPERANNUATION IN AUSTRALIA TODAY
There are basically three different forms of superannuation in Australia today: industry funds, employer-sponsored funds and personal funds.
(a) Industry Funds

This is the newest form of superannuation available in Australia. Basically, an industry fund is one which is award related and to which all workers in a particular industry are eligible. It is covered by legislation which requires certain characteristics of these funds. These include:

* Equal numbers of employers and employees must be represented on the board of trustees. In practice, this usually means that major employer organisations and trade unions will occupy these positions.

* The fund is portable. This means that, if an employee changes employment within the industry, there is no change to the superannuation. If an employee leaves the industry, the funds are normally transferred to a new scheme.

* The funds are preserved until retirement. This means that the employee cannot have access to his/her superannuation until retirement on or after the age of 55 years. This is designed to prevent people from taking their superannuation on changing jobs and spending it before retirement. Funds can also be withdrawn in case of death, total and permanent disablement or on permanent departure to reside overseas.
* The funds vest immediately in the superannuant. As soon as a contribution enters the fund on behalf of the superannuant, it belongs to him/her and is held in trust until retirement.
* All members of an industry are eligible, whether full-time, part-time or casual employees.
(b) Employer-sponsored Funds

These are funds set up by individual employers for their employees. As each fund is separate, they differ in their terms, although there are characteristics which are common to many. Originally these funds were designed to encourage employees, especially senior or management employees, to remain with their employer. Usually the company will match an employee's contribution dollar for dollar or better. There are some disadvantages in belonging to this type of scheme.

* The employer contributions do not vest in the employee immediately but become available under a variety of terms and conditions. A member may have to wait as long as ten years to receiver a share of employer contributions but in some cases may receive a substantial portion after one year.
* The contributions are usually not preserved. (except where changes have occurred since December 1986) The employee receives his/her entitlement on leaving the company.
* The funds in the past have not been portable but this is now changing in line with industry development.
* Eligibility may be limited. In most, casual and part-time employees are not eligible and many are restricted to management employees.
(c) Personal Superannuation

These are private schemes taken out with an insurance company by selfemployed persons or those employees who do not have access to, or who do not wish to participate in another scheme. They require the individual to make contributions which are invested on their behalf. As there is no employer contribution as in the first two types of superannuation, the government provides a tax concession to those who take out personal superannuation.
From 1st July, 1988, the first $3000 per annum contributed is tax deductible plus anything above that up to the level required to fund the R.B.L. (Reasonable Benefit Level-see below).
OTHER REGULATIONS GOVERNING SUPERANNUATION
There are two other regulations governing superannuation which are relevant for our purposes, both of which relate to the final lump sum payment.
* From 1st July, 1990, the first $68,628 of a lump sum payment, taken on retirement is tax free with the remainder taxed at the rate of 15%.
* The maximum payment which can be received from 1st July 1990 is as follows:
- where final salary is $35,000 or less, seven times final salary
- where final salary is $35001-$65,000, five times final salary
- where final salary exceeds $65,000, three times final salary
These figures are indexed.
WOMEN, SUPERANNUATION AND PAID EMPLOYMENT
Superannuation entitlements have traditionally not favoured women in a number of ways.
* Only one in four women have employer sponsored superannuation, compared with one in two men.
* For many years superannuation schemes often did not exist in occupations and industries where most of the employees were women.
* Women are more likely to be employed in part-time or casual work and are less likely to hold management positions. They are therefore excluded from many schemes.

* Superannuation schemes have not, in the past, taken account of the different employment patterns of men and women. A scheme which requires ten to fifteen years before any employer benefit is received was often unattractive to women who tend to spend periods of time out of the paid workforce.
IS SUPERANNUATION RELEVANT TO WOMEN?

Women have often ignored superannuation either because it does not adequately cater to their needs, or because they intend to rely on their husband's superannuation. However, women need to seriously consider superannuation for two reasons.

Firstly, women cannot assume that they will be supported by their husbands in retirement, with one in three marriages ending in divorce. The Family Court's attitude to superannuation is somewhat ambiguous. Although the court usually regards accumulated superannuation funds as joint assets, there is certainly no requirement to take retirement benefits into account in any property settlement.
Secondly, women tend to outlive men, and the majority end their lives living alone. If they rely solely on the age pension they will be living below the poverty line.
WOMEN AT HOME

Currently, women at home are not able to cover themselves for superannuation, yet for the reasons already indicated it is as important for them as for women in paid employment. The assumptions seems to be that these women will either rely on their husbands or will receive the age pension in retirement.

This is unacceptable on two grounds. It ignores the fact that women at home are employed: and the current regulations discriminate against the single income family, making it even more difficult for them.
(a) WOMEN AT HOME ARE EMPLOYED

Leaving women at home in ` `no-woman's land'' with respect to superannuation ignores the fact that they are employed, although unpaid. They perform work which is of measurable economic value to society as a whole. If superannuation continues to be unavailable to them, while it becomes increasingly common for those in the paid workforce, women who work at home will become the new age of social welfare dependants, a burden to society, their years of unpaid service forgotten.
Some method of providing superannuation for these women must, therefore, be implemented.
(b) DISCRIMINATION AGAINST SINGLE INCOME FAMILIES

Leaving a woman reliant on her husband's superannuation places a great drain on the family income, as the level of superannuation needs to be sufficient to provide for both spouses in retirement. In this regard the current regulations discriminate against the single income family in three ways.

(i) Contributions: In a dual income family both spouses have access to superannuation, which means that either both receive the benefit of employer contributions, or each can claim a $3000 plus tax deduction for contributions to a personal fund. In a single income family there is access to only one employer or industry scheme (through the paid spouse) or one $3000 tax deduction where the paid spouse is in a personal scheme.
(ii) Reasonable Benefit Limit: Because the multiple for the reasonable benefit limit decreases as the final salary increases, the single income family suffers considerably.

(iii) TAXATION OF THE LUMP SUM: As the lump sum is tax free on the first $68,628 once again the dual income family, with two superannuation schemes will have the first $137,256 tax free, while the single income family will be limited to one tax free threshold. This means that, even where the actual payouts are the same, the two income family will be $8628.00 better off.
SOLUTION
There is a way to eliminate both the problem of discrimination against the single income family and the lack of recognition of women at home.

The basic requirement is an amendment to the structure of superannuation to allow it to be taken out on behalf of those not in the paid workforce. This would be complemented by a provision in both industry and employer sponsored schemes which would allow an employee to contribute to the scheme on behalf of his/her spouse. In the industry funds this could be required by regulation.

While there is no way to enforce such a provision in employer sponsored funds, such funds should be encouraged to allow contributors the same option, perhaps through some tax incentive. Personal schemes should be available to those not in paid work, increasing the tax deduction for a single income family to a possible $6000.
Such a system would have a number of advantages.
Firstly, it gives the single income family the ability to eliminate the taxation discrimination, as two superannuation schemes would be entitled to two tax free thresholds.

Secondly, it would ensure some provision for the wife should the marriage break down at a later date. While the husband may discontinue payments after a marriage break up, the money already in her account would be preserved for her until retirement.

With regard to the reasonable benefit limit, where the couple have taken advantage of the availability to contribute to two superannuation schemes, the R.B.L. should be calculated on the basis of half the final salary of the paid spouse.

To demonstrate how this proposal would work, let us look again at Couple A. If we assume that Mr A. has contributed 5% of his salary to an industry or employer sponsored scheme for forty years, with his employer also contributing 5%, how would the proposed system affect Mr and Mrs A?
Mr A. would have the option of putting half the contributions (i.e. 2.5%) in Mrs A.'s name, with half the employer's contribution also being on behalf of Mrs A.
This would mean that on retirement, the R.B.L. would be 7 x $35,000 x 2 $490,000. They would also receive the benefit of a total of $137,256 tax free.

Alternatively, Mr and Mrs A. may decide to take out a personal policy on behalf of Mrs A, which would give the same advantages as above. While they would not receive the employer contribution on behalf of Mrs A. they would be entitled to a maximum deduction for contributions of $3000 (plus). If Mr A. had instead been contributing to a person scheme 10% of his salary for the same period, he would be able to divide this into two scheme on behalf of himself and Mrs A, each based on a 5% contribution. Alternatively they may decide to take advantage of the increased tax deductions and R.B.L. by increasing their contribution levels.
As is obvious, this system offers considerable flexibility to the family, and encourages couples to take out superannuation for both partners.
SOLE PARENTS AND THOSE ON LOW INCOMES
So far, nothing suggested would improve the position of sole parents and those for whom superannuation is an unaffordable luxury because their incomes are so low.
There is an argument that these people should be left to receive the age pension.
However, there is an alternative which would provide some dignity for those in this position, and give them the option of superannuation.

A means tested voucher system could be set up. The vouchers could be provided to all those below a set income to be invested in any superannuation scheme to which a person has access. For those in paid employment, this could mean an industry or employer scheme, or a personal fund. Those in receipt of welfare would be limited to the latter, however, as most people are not on welfare all their lives, the other options may well open up in the future.
The voucher would need to be in a form which could only be used for superannuation, and could not be cashed in and spent.
CONCLUSION

Providing for our own retirement is the only way Australians are going to be able to enjoy a reasonable standard of living in the future. For this reason, all efforts should be made to ensure that superannuation is as widely and equitably available as possible to all Australians.
The system proposed here, while appearing complex, is really a way of finetuning the current provisions regarding superannuation to achieve this.
