TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators who have contributed to the debate on this most important Sex Discrimination Amendment Bill 1991. The Bill seeks to achieve certain improvements in the way in which our society deals with discrimination based on sex and marital status. I believe that it does so in a way which obviously has received the support of the chamber, though with some foreshadowed amendments-further improvements, as they are seen, but I will refute that in a moment-by the Opposition and by the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will be aware that the purposes of the Bill are: to remove from the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 the exemption for superannuation and replace it with more limited exemptions; to insert in the Sex Discrimination Act (SDA) a number of exemptions for certain Commonwealth and Territory legislation which is presently exempted by regulations; and to amend the Marriage Act 1961 and the War Gratuity Act 1945 so as to remove inconsistencies with the Sex Discrimination Act.

I note, Mr Acting Deputy President, that you have followed the debate with great interest, and I might say that you have controlled the chamber very well. The major effect of this Bill is to remove most forms of direct discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status from superannuation practices for new schemes. Where funds are unable to comply with the new obligations under the legislation, the reasonable expectations of the members will be maintained and the discriminatory fund will be allowed to continue. However, such funds will not be entitled to admit new members.

Further, members of such discriminatory schemes will generally have to be given an option to obtain nondiscriminatory superannuation benefits. I am not going to rehearse the proposed continuing exemptions. Perhaps I might shortly state that they deal with the following areas: the inclusion in fund conditions of a provision which is based upon actuarial data upon which it is reasonable to rely; the current practices whereby lesser death and disability benefits are provided to members who are single, that is, members who do not have a spouse or a de facto spouse or to members who do not have a child; the possibly discriminatory effects of the current vesting, preservation and portability arrangements in fund conditions; and the protection of the existing expectations of members of discriminatory schemes. The Government believes that the amendments to be undertaken in relation to superannuation funds represent a significant reform, for all the sorts of reasons which were so eloquently espoused by my colleagues, Senator Crowley and Senator Reynolds and supported in large measure by others.

While I am informed that most schemes will be able to comply with the amendments with only minor adaptations to their existing conditions, the amendments will require schemes which have not yet modified their benefits to do so over the next two years or to close off their membership. I understand that the Opposition has indicated that it would like to increase the time period in which superannuation funds will have to comply with the new requirements by providing a further 12 months for the construction of a non-discriminatory option for members of existing funds.

The Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia has been pressing this matter, but those opposite must admit that the Government has already provided a two-year period before commencement of the superannuation amendments and that gives sufficient time for funds to comply. Certainly the Insurance and Superannuation Commission has advised that it permits funds 18 months to two years maximum to amend trust deeds to comply with new requirements. In respect of this Bill, that Commission supported the reduction of the two-year commencement provisions to one year. Mr Deputy President, you can see from that short exposition that the Government has been more generous than its statutory adviser indicated might be quite acceptable.

The superannuation industry has had ample notice of the requirement to construct a non-discriminatory option for members of discriminatory schemes. The Government's intentions to amend the superannuation provisions as provided by this Bill have been under discussion with the superannuation industry for several years. Most of the key policy issues of the legislation have not changed since the Bill was introduced into Parliament in 1989.

The remainder of the amendments to be effected by this Bill concern the exemption for inconsistent Commonwealth, State and Territory laws. The Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances-I do not know whether any Senators here are members of that Committee-expressed strong concern about the possibility of any further renewals of the exemptions by regulation. Consequently, the Government, taking all that into consideration, proposes that the existing provisions of the Act concerning the power to extend exemptions by regulations be repealed. The current regulations will expire on 31 July this year. Nevertheless, the Government has decided to grant indefinite exemptions under section 40(2) of the Act to a number of Commonwealth Acts and they have been listed and are well known to senators in this debate.

For example, the Income Tax Assessment Act uses a number of terms such as `relative', `associate', and `dependant', which are discriminatory on grounds of marital status. These terms are used in various tax Acts and are aimed at preventing tax avoidance and the abuse of tax concessions and therefore the desirability of indefinitely exempting this legislation is obvious. So also it has been argued for the other statutes that are to be exempted.

The other major provision of this Bill is to amend those provisions of the Marriage Act which provide for the marriageable age of females. At the moment, as senators will be aware, the marriageable age for females is 16, but the marriageable age for males is 18. It is the case that the minimum age at which females and males below marriageable age can marry can be varied by obtaining court authorisation. I think it is provided that where the parties have court authorisation, a female between 14 and 16 and a male between 16 and 18 may obtain permission to marry.

This Bill provides for a common marriageable age of 18, with the provision for a reduction to 16 in exceptional circumstances. This common marriageable age trend is a worldwide tendency. There are now at least 38 countries which prescribe a common marriageable age; 24 of these prescribe a marriageable age of 18 years. A table which was attached to the original second reading speech may be of interest to senators and to members of the public.

A survey of marriage counsellors, marriage educators, court counsellors and national marriage counselling representatives was conducted by the Department in 1988. Forty-seven per cent of just over 1,000 persons polled responded. Of those, 65 per cent were of the view that 18 is an appropriate minimum marriageable age for males and 63 per cent were of the view that 18 is an appropriate minimum marriageable age for females. These people who were surveyed have very real contact with those whose marriages are either aided by an education program or have suffered a breakdown, a disruption in the relationship or possibly separation and even divorce. So it is worth taking their experience and views into account.

It may be noted also that in 1989 there were around 117,000 marriages in Australia. Of these, only 1,052 were of females under the age of 18 years. Further, only 13 of these marriages were of females under the age of 16 years and required court authorisation. It seems that the move to a common minimum marriageable age is something which is well supported.

In addition, I understand the Opposition has foreshadowed an amendment to exempt the entire Migration Act. This clearly would be unacceptable as it would permit all forms of discrimination on the basis of sex, marital status and pregnancy in migration programs. The amendment would exempt the Migration Act as in force at any time. This would be inconsistent with the policy of exempting from the Sex Discrimination Act only inconsistent legislation as in force at the commencement of the Sex Discrimination Act.

The other indefinite exemptions provided in the Bill are limited to exempting that legislation as in force at the commencement of the Sex Discrimination Act. The amendment appears to be motivated by Opposition concerns that the requirement in the Sex Discrimination Act that persons in de facto marriages not be treated less favourably than married persons was being used to avoid immigration controls on the grant of residence permits.

Concerns that sham relationships are being used to gain permanent residence have arisen in the context of both married and de facto relationships. These concerns have been addressed by new immigration guidelines, which take a stricter approach to application for permanent residence on the ground of married or de facto relationships. Those guidelines provide that married applicants must produce a marriage certificate and de facto applicants must produce evidence that the de facto relationship is of at least six months duration, unless there are certain exceptional circumstances such as a substantial long term joint financial obligation, a previous marriage with the same person or a co-resident child of the relationship. Both married and de facto applicants must produce evidence of the partner's Australian citizenship or permanent resident status and two statutory declarations attesting to the genuine and continuing nature of the relationship.

Those guidelines have been formulated to be consistent with the Sex Discrimination Act. They are also expected to be effective in reducing the potential for sham relationships to undermine residence controls. Therefore, the Government believes there is no need for the Migration Act to be exempted for this purpose from the Sex Discrimination Act.

In relation to the foreshadowed amendments of the Australian Democrats to taxation and social security legislation, which were put forward by Senator Powell-the proposal to exempt tax laws from the operation of the Sex Discrimination Act, we believe, in the form foreshadowed, could not be well supported. In late 1987 the Australian Taxation Office completed a review of laws administered by the Commissioner of Taxation, which identified those provisions which were discriminatory in terms of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984. The Government subsequently agreed to amend many of those provisions so that they complied with the SDA. Those amendments were included in the Taxation Laws Amendment Act 1990.

It was decided that some other discriminatory provisions would not be amended largely because of the serious revenue consequences or inequities that would result. Once again, I will not go into these in detail. However, those provisions fall broadly into four categories: first, anti-avoidance provisions which are essential to the protection of the revenue; secondly, some concessional rebates-the spouse and housekeeper rebates, which the Government decided should not be replaced; thirdly, provisions giving effect to international agreements which could not be amended without placing Australia in breach of the agreements; and fourthly, provisions in the tax law, which are no longer applied but for which some assessment may still need to be issued, for example, gift duty law. Any amendments would place those persons assessed after the application date of such an amendment in a position different from those assessed before or vice versa.

All tax laws passed after the commencement of the Sex Discrimination Act are not subject to the Sex Discrimination Act but are drafted with a policy of the Sex Discrimination Act in mind. Accordingly, the permanent exemption for the tax laws only has effect in relation to tax laws existing prior to the commencement of the SDA. In reaching the decision to permanently exempt the tax laws listed in the Bill, the Government consulted with the sex discrimination commissioner. Having understood that this Bill will now go to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, I do not think I need to go into any more detail in relation to that matter.

As to the removal of exemption of the Social Security Act, which is foreshadowed by the Australian Democrats, it seems that they have not quite fully appreciated that the areas of discrimination which remain in the Social Security Act generally favour women rather than men. An amendment of the sort proposed by the Democrats could operate to the disadvantage of women and it is questionable therefore whether the amendment would achieve what the Democrats might wish. I give only two brief examples. As to family payments, the Act currently provides that a dependent child for family allowance purposes generally shall be deemed to be a dependent child of the wife and not the husband.

The amendment would presumably require the family allowance to be made non-discriminatory and be paid either to the husband or to the wife depending on who claimed the payment or would require the family allowance to be split between the husband and the wife. Making family payments such as family allowance and family allowance supplement to wives is an attempt to ensure that assistance for children is directed to the woman who is usually the primary care giver, and we would not want this to change.

As to the age pension it is paid to women aged 60 years and over and to men aged 65 years and over, subject to income and assets tests. The amendment would require that the age pension be non-discriminatory by either lowering the age pension for men to 60 or raising it for women to 65. With an ageing population the costs of lowering the eligible age for men would preclude that option.

In the August 1989 statement on retirement income policy, the Government stated it would monitor the progress of women's participation in superannuation and the labour force before considering an increase in their pension age. Recent labour force surveys by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) indicate that only about one-third of women aged 55 to 59 years are in the labour force and almost half of these work part time. In addition about two-thirds of women in the age bracket prior to the current age pension age rely on income from sources other than work.

An increase in the age pension age for women to 65 years would simply force most affected women to seek other forms of income support such as unemployment benefits. It would also prevent many women retiring at the same time as their husband. There is also concern for the adequacy of women's retirement incomes. The ABS superannuation survey of 1988 estimated that only 37 per cent of women and 19 per cent of part time workers were covered by superannuation. With the advent of award superannuation these percentages will increase but it is still the case that women currently nearing retirement age have less capacity than similarly aged men to provide for their retirement.

In the light of this, now is not the right time to consider an increase in the female age pension age. Only in a few years when improved vesting and preservation standards apply, and labour force participation rates for older women have improved, should the issue be open for serious consideration. However, any increase in the pensionable age for women will need to be phased from a date well in the future in order to give adequate forewarning to those affected.
I foreshadowed in some detail some of the answers to matters which have been put forward by the Opposition and the Democrats to be considered in more detail no doubt at the committee stage.

In relation to the matters raised by Senator Crowley, I will also be able in that forum to provide a fuller answer. In relation to Senator Harradine's comments, no doubt the particular document to which he gave so much weight is worthy of consideration. Whilst I do not think it affects the full drafting of this particular Bill, nevertheless it is well worth reflection. I commend the Bill to the House.

The Opposition's amendment removes that section of the Bill that refers to the Industrial Relations Act 1988. It leaves intact the amendments that relate to the Defence Act 1903 and to the Industrial Chemicals Notification and Assessment Act 1989, and the later amendments that relate to the Trade Union Training Authority Act 1975. However, it is the amendments that relate specifically to the Industrial Relations Act to which the Liberal and National parties take strong exception, as I indicated in the second reading debate last night. This is because we believe that this part of the legislation is the first step towards the establishment of a separate labour court, which could well have the effect of removing the jurisdiction over industrial relations from the Federal Court of Australia and the High Court of Australia, where the Opposition believes that it should properly remain.

The clauses that we seek to remove inculcate within the Australian Industrial Relations Commission new classifications that are clearly linked to the industrial jurisdiction of the Federal Court and the future creation of a labour court. Under the amendments that the Government has proposed in this legislation it is intended that the new senior deputy presidents will also sit as judges in such a labour court. Yet, we argue that members of the Industrial Relations Commission, however well qualified in the law, are not judges.

Of course, the proposal for a labour court was on the Government's agenda back in 1987. As I said last night, it was removed as a result of strong community opposition to that proposal contained within the draft legislation to amend the then Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1987, as was the proposal for instituting a minimum size for unions, to facilitate the creation of mega-unions. Just as the Government last year passed legislation through this Parliament to put mega-unions back on the agenda and specific legislation to assist in their creation, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has now indicated that the future creation of a labour court is back on the agenda.

We believe that it is quite unacceptable to have a special labour court judging matters of law in relation to industrial relations. Undoubtedly, and indeed as this legislation would indicate, members of such a new labour court would be appointed from the Industrial Relations Commission or related networks, which have been weaned on the ethos of the industrial relations club. Obviously, matters of industrial relations that are taken to court for appeal are matters of legal interpretation of the industrial relations legislation or of Industrial Relations Commission decisions.

In this case, if the Industrial Relations Commission's decision itself is under appeal to a court, obviously it would be a case of Caesar appealing to Caesar if that appeal were dealt with by a labour court so specially constructed rather than by the Federal Court or the High Court, which we would regard as being a more appropriate venue for such an appeal to be heard. There is also the possibility that the establishment of a labour court could be used to remove the right of resort to common law actions, which have been very successful in recent years in solving disputes and beating union intimidation. I gave examples of those last night in the form of the Dollar Sweets and Mudginberri disputes as being very successful in that regard.

We believe that this legislation is not only unnecessary but in fact is directing industrial relations completely down the wrong road; that there ought to be industrial relations legal interpretations directed towards the existing court structures, where that is appropriate. We believe that there is simply no need, and indeed it is a backward step approach, to look towards the establishment of a labour court. Rather, we would urge that the Government get on with solving some of the real problems of industrial relations, to build a more competitive industrial relations structure, a more productive industrial climate in Australia, and deal with the problems that are very much in evidence in our industrial relations system at the moment.

I refer, of course, to problems relating to the waterfront. The waterfront was referred to by Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) during Question Time today, when he claimed that the Opposition was misrepresenting the situation with regard to the number of redundancies that had occurred. He claimed that, rather than the relatively small number which the Opposition claimed had occurred with regard to redundancies on the waterfront, in fact some 1,200 redundancies had taken place since the Government's waterfront reform program had been initiated. However, in virtually the same breath he then admitted that some 600 of those redundancies were redundancies by way of attrition-in other words, redundancies which would have happened anyway, whether or not any specific proposals for waterfront reform were under way by the Government.

That indicates the way in which the Government is, if you like, running scared with regard to its achievements on waterfront reform. Within the successes which it claims to be achieving it is counting the numbers of redundancies which would have occurred anyway, irrespective of any reform process being undertaken. That is an area of industrial relations reform which needs much greater and more urgent attention.

There is also the need to get rid of the cosy but illegal arrangements regarding trans-Tasman shipping, which not only make it unprofitable to ship Australian cars to New Zealand compared with the cost of shipping them direct from Japan but also, at a time when they can ill afford it, threaten Australian wheat growers with the loss of the traditional markets that they have for wheat in New Zealand. It is already difficult enough for Australian wheat growers to compete with subsidised American wheat but when they now have to compete on the basis that it is cheaper to ship wheat from the west coast of the United States to New Zealand than it is to ship it from Australia to New Zealand because of the continuation of this trans-Tasman accord-which precludes other than Australian or New Zealand shipping from transport across the Tasman-it simply exacerbates the very serious situation which our wheat growers are facing.

As I said last night, what we really need in this country is genuine enterprise based industrial relations, not the Clayton's enterprise bargaining which this Government is currently instituting-adopting the language of enterprise bargaining but not the reality. We want this Government to get on with establishing genuine and real enterprise bargaining.

These are some of the areas that the Government should be directing its attention to-not putting up legislation such as this which simply further entrenches the centralised industrial relations system with the potential creation of a labour court. It is for that reason that the Opposition moves the amendment which seeks to remove part 3 from this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

SPEECH.PARA: Later this year it may be that the Government brings back some legislation for a labour court; it may not be. Those matters are not determined at this stage. The Government cocks a genuinely interested ear in the views of the parties so that any legislation that might be forthcoming can be legislation which incorporates their views and is, as much as possible, a consensus proposal.

A further cheque was received for $10,000 and drawn on 24 October 1980 on the Ainsworth distributors account, made out to and received by Caspalp promotions. There was a further cheque for $10,000, so a total of $30,000 in all was drawn on the Ainsworth distributors account and made out to Caspalp promotions.

I mention these matters because I was the President of the Liberal Party in Queensland at the time. Vibert approached me and tried to bribe the Liberal Party in Queensland to change our attitude towards poker machines. I have not mentioned this previously in a public arena. I threw him out of the office. Honourable senators could understand Senator Macdonald's agitation today when Senator Robert Ray made allegations about the Liberal Party in Queensland, saying that we were prone to accepting money of a tainted nature when the very opposite occurred.

It is documented, recorded and acknowledged by the ALP in Queensland that it received $30,000 from the Ainsworth poker machine lobby in the presence of Vibert. The only thing that is not acknowledged is that it changed its policy in relation to poker machines, but it is evident from the chronology that one would have to be more than somewhat sceptical of that denial when prior to that time the Labor Party was not in favour of the development of poker machines in Queensland.

I rise to record in the Senate the occurrence of those events; the fact that Vibert tried to bribe the Liberal Party in Queensland; the fact that the Liberal Party rejected that bribe and in fact threw Vibert out of the office; and the fact that money was received by the ALP in Queensland and $30,000 in all has been acknowledged and recorded by the Criminal Justice Commission. It is a travesty for Senator Robert Ray to make that jibe about the Queensland Liberal Party in this chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
